DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Report on the visit of the Defence Sub-Committee to Exercise Kangaroo 95, 8-11 August 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am chairman of the committee I was not present for the visit. I would like to call on the deputy chairman, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), to present the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I extend my thanks to the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), and to Mr Matthew Mason-Cox who prepared the report. Kangaroo 95 was one of a series of major Kangaroo military exercises that have been held since I was minister. They are essentially the major Australia directed joint exercise staged recurringly. This particular exercise was designed to emphasise the joint nature of operations, operations at the tactical level of war, and to further develop the procedures required for civil and military cooperation during short-warning conflict in the defence of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The enemy forces were drawn from the fictitious island nation called Orangeland. Under the exercise scenario Orangeland mounted Operation Trojan Horse against Australia. Interestingly, the scenario designed by Orangeland was to obtain a rightful share of the region's non-renewable energy resources. I found that paradoxical because the Orangeland forces were headquartered at Nabarlek where we have one of the world's major uranium deposits. Thanks to the government's three-mine—I should say two-mine—policy, Nabarlek is in the process of being taken back to where it was with no mine. The headquarters of the Orangeland forces were stationed at one of the major sources of Australia's energy.

Defence elements from seven nations were involved in Kangaroo 95 in varying degrees. There were contingents from the United States, the United Kingdom, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Papua New Guinea. Unfortunately, we only saw in passing the hovercraft operated by the United States marines. As we comment in the report, the hovercraft cost about $20 million. It is apparently extraordinarily fast and seems to be very mobile, but I think it is quite impractical from Australia's point of view. We would have liked to have seen something of the other forces.

There are several aspects of the exercise that are worth commendation. Without any doubt, the first is the degree to which Australian forces took care of the environment—I refer not only to the portaloos, which were not camouflaged, which were apparent everywhere that the exercise was conducted but also to environmental practices with respect to the use of water and the fact that people were required to wear hats and so on. It was all a very important part of our approach to an exercise setting. It was worth while for other countries to see that and recognise the human rights values which Australian forces apply.

For that reason, I am totally in disagreement with the dissenting report by Senator Margetts. Indeed, she has made an observation about the participation of Papua New Guinea which, to my mind, is not only wrong, but—

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous!
—It is quite outrageous, as the honourable member for Calare says. I also wish to dissociate myself from this concern expressed at the last dot point on page 11 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Before and during the Exercise there was concern expressed by some sections of the community about the participation of foreign forces in the Exercise . . .

Of course, that is an accurate observation. There was concern, but it was an inaccurate concern that did not reflect the fact that the more countries of our region which can exercise with Australian forces, the better chance they have of understanding the values which Australians apply in so many fields of endeavour. I think it is only through exercising together that there is any chance of that being passed on to other nations.

PARA.TAB: We visited pretty well all the facilities. Our one initial concern, as we mentioned in the report, was that, unfortunately, we did not get an overall brief on the exercise at its beginning. We would suggest that, on any future visit by a parliamentary committee, a briefing such as the one given to us when we visited Darwin should occur at the very beginning of the exercise. That briefing was excellent. It was provided by Brigadier I.J. Bryant, Director-General, Joint Exercise Planning. Had we had that briefing at the beginning of the exercise, I believe the visit could have been even more worth while.

I only want to pick up a couple of other aspects of the report. We did meet a diverse cross-section of uniformed personnel. We were concerned about some of the problems with family separation, particularly with respect to the 51 Far North Queensland Regiment. We have picked up a recommendation regarding problems with separation. We suggested they could perhaps use a light aircraft and a reserve pilot in order to improve mobility in that far-flung part of North Queensland, Cape York Peninsula. Of course, it would have to take account of the weather, particularly the cyclonic depressions that come through there from time to time. Also, some account needs to be taken of the problem there seems to be regarding the ratio of regulars to reserve personnel within the 51 Far North Queensland Regiment, particularly with respect to Q stores. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the parliament for allowing me the privilege of attending the Kangaroo 95 exercise. I would like to say, as members of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade always find, how impressed we were with the calibre of the people in our defence forces. That cannot be questioned. I was pleased to see the army reserve playing a great role there. As a former member of the reserve, I have always felt they were undervalued. I see that they are now playing an increasing role. I think that will be even more significant in the future.

PARA.TAB: I, along with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), was surprised that we did not have a briefing when we first arrived on the scene. I understand that in future that will be taken care of.One thing that I was a little concerned about, having spoken to naval ratings—about which the member for New England has already spoken—is that some time ago when young people enlisted in the navy it was in order to go to sea. Now, going to sea is considered fairly onerous because most people can purchase a ticket to go overseas at any time, such is the nature of our country and our standard of living.

One naval rating said to me that he found that when he came back from being at sea, the shore jobs that may have been available were not available anymore. He was spending a great deal of his time at sea. This places a great deal of pressure on family life. If we were on a war footing this would no doubt be better accepted, but I think the navy must look at this situation because there is ever increasing pressure on those naval families. The shore jobs, for whatever reason, do not seem to be available anymore.

I would like to dissociate myself from the dissenting report. It may be that the senator who put forward the dissenting report had contact with people before we arrived on the scene, but every person to whom we spoke was only too pleased to see our forces in the north and would welcome them back at any time. Certainly, no-one said to me that they were worried about foreign forces being in northern Australia. If we all wanted to put in dissenting reports, we could perhaps give a dissertation on the Steyr rifle, the type of ammunition being used, or that we were not happy with the chefs that were available. We could all do that, but we were there as part of the Defence Subcommittee to observe Exercise 95. If we want to put forward a particular philosophical view, this report is not the place to do it.

I was surprised the other day listening to a person who is actually doing some defence studies saying that we have no problem in Australia of any potential enemy for the next 15 years. I do not know who has been lecturing him, but I would say we really have to be on guard at all times. We have to make sure that our defence is secure, and exercises like Kangaroo 95 will do that. I am sure the value is there and, of course, there will be a critical analysis of the exercise in the future by other people more expert than I am.
I would like, once again, to thank the parliament for the privilege of being able to attend this exercise and to comment on the calibre of the people in our defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to support the comments of my colleagues, particularly the acting chairman, the leader of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I would briefly like to make a passing reference to the dissenting report and express my disagreement with the tenor of it.

PARA.TAB: On page 11 of the report there is a correct reference to the concern that was expressed both before and during the exercise by some sections of the community about the participation of foreign forces in the exercise, including Indonesian forces, and I think that reference should be taken into account. In my view, the dissenting report does have the potential to create in some people's minds the belief that the defence committee was engaged in an analysis of the whole defence posture of this nation. Of course, that was not the case and the report tabled here today that we are talking about has nothing to do in that broad general sense with the defence posture and it should be seen in that context. I hope that, when Senator Margetts speaks in the Senate, she makes it absolutely clear that the task of the defence committee in going to operation Kangaroo was to observe and to report.

I was delighted during the exercise to be able to meet a young naval officer whom I saw when he left school in Albury-Wodonga and to whom I was able to give some assistance and advice in his pursuit of entering the naval services. I refer to Lieutenant Andrew Greg who was the executive officer on the HMAS Labuan which transported us very efficiently to the Tobruk. I was very pleased to see the calibre of Lieutenant Greg and his colleagues and the way in which he is advancing in the naval forces. It is particularly pleasing to see someone from one's own electorate doing so well and I congratulate Lieutenant Greg and his colleagues.

The other point I wish to raise briefly is the strong impression that I got that we must always be very vigilant about our defence. Seeing the vastness of northern Australia and operation Kangaroo 95, it was very obvious to me that we have to make absolutely certain that the Australian defence forces are maintained and supported because of the immense task that we would have in the event of an emergency, in the event of an unfortunate incident with another country, of defending our shores. That is why operation Kangaroo and the involvement of the Australian forces with the other nations is absolutely important—it is an opportunity to test out and to evaluate, out of which we learn many things.

I was also very pleased to see the presence of reserve forces. Being a former member of the reserves myself and having a strong, continuing interest in the potential of the reserves, I was interested to have brief conversations with some of the reservists. That confirmed my view that a lot more should be done in our defence policy to involve the reservists more and more. There is an enormous potential for that and that was confirmed by my observations and discussions with some of the people.

It was also a great opportunity for members of the defence committee to speak directly with personnel. For example, one naval personnel member told me that he had a master's ticket, obtained by private study, which was accepted by the Maritime Services Board but that that certificate and qualification was not accepted by the navy.

I found that situation to be rather intriguing. I therefore just mention that incident as an opportunity, as a member of the defence committee, to get a deeper understanding of some of the issues that cause members of the services to be a little resentful and to question whether their career path is adequate. Sometimes it even leads to us losing some of these people who have been trained in certain areas. It is an opportunity for us to evaluate what is going on and for us to hear information directly.

It was interesting to see how readily the members of the various defence forces took the opportunity to speak informally to us. That is another indication of the value of operation Kangaroo. It does give them the opportunity to speak directly to parliamentary representatives from all parties who have an interest in defence. I commend the defence forces for their contribution to this exercise. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak briefly to this report and associate myself with the remarks of my colleagues the member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) and the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) and also to emphasise that I fully dissociate myself from the dissenting report by Senator Margetts. I think enough has been said about that.

PARA.TAB: What all of us found in looking at Kangaroo 95 was that we were very impressed with the professionalism and the dedication of the defence forces of Australia. I think our troops performed extremely well in their role in the Kangaroo 95 exercise. When it comes to training and equipment in the current situation I think all of us were very impressed. I did have a couple of reservations that I would like to briefly touch on. The first one is whether or not we have sufficient troops to properly defend Australia; the second is the question of command coordination and whether or not that is sufficient.

I think one of the things that does come through is, notwithstanding the last 10 years of moving towards an integrated defence force, there are still very clear distinctions between the army, the navy and the air force. I do wonder whether or not this may create some interference with proper command and control. While I think the complexities of modern defence planning are well known, the fact is we still have to question whether the government has put sufficient effort into planning.

To come back to my first point, the personnel numbers are reaching a critically low level. I think if we were to allow them to fall any further we could create some very serious problems in having sufficient troops available to respond were there a threat to our sovereignty. I think the other point that has come through very clearly in talking to members of our defence forces and to their commanders is that the cutback in numbers has led to an increase in stress amongst many of the troops, both the regulars and the reservists.

What was demonstrated was that with the lack of backup personnel in some units many people were forced into undertaking additional service requirements often to the detriment of their family. It was pointed out that marital breakdowns are all too high. I do not wish to in any way denigrate the efforts of our service personnel, because I think dedication to the service remains a matter of some pride amongst them, but we do have to acknowledge that they need realistic numbers to be able to do the job adequately.

Again, this is not to decry the enormous investment Australia has made in modern equipment, such as the locally made Anzac frigates and the Collins submarines, and the purchase of our FA18s and F111s. The point is we do have to get a balance. We have to recognise that personnel are needed and the training required these days means that you cannot recruit overnight. Therefore, we have to acknowledge this is one very serious concern.

The committee in the report's final remarks has covered most areas. There are 12 points made on page 13 and 14 which go into some detail on the observations we made. There is no doubt that there is concern about the possibility of the likelihood of paying off the HMAS Tobruk, particularly given that it is a relatively modern ship and the important role it plays in moving personnel and equipment around Australia and where needed. The other concern was shortages in personnel, which are causing problems in the home lives of those in our services. This will have to be addressed.
Australia is well served by its personnel. We have every reason to be proud of their professionalism and the contribution they make to ensuring that this country remains a free country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues from the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in commenting on the committee's visit to Kangaroo 95 this year. I do not want to delay the proceedings of the House a great deal except to say that, like my colleagues from both sides of the House, I totally dissociate myself from the agenda and the comments of Senator Margetts that are included in the minority report associated with this report that has been tabled today.

PARA.TAB: One of the great joys of belonging to this subcommittee is working with a group of people right across this parliament in a way that the general public is not necessarily convinced happens in this parliament very often from the 30-second grabs they see on television each night. Here is a good example of a bipartisan approach taken to a very important defence issue. We are fortunate indeed that virtually every member of the committee has a great interest in defence, some of us having had the privilege of serving as part of the executive in the portfolio of defence at one time or another and other people having the opportunities because of the location of defence bases within their electorates to have some direct involvement as well.
One of the things that made me very proud during the visit—going back to my time in 1989 when I was Minister for Defence Science and Personnel—

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very good one.

—Thank you. Once again seeing our troops in action made me feel very proud of the professionalism adopted by the Australian defence forces. There are always going to be stresses and strains associated with operating a modern defence force in a time when there are always pressures on the military budget. But again, during this exercise, apart from the odd hiccup that some members have commented upon, we saw a very professional group of men and women who did us proud in serving, and paying great attention to, the profession of arms. It is a noble profession which we as members of parliament should be proud to support. I commend to the House the sentiments expressed in the majority report.

—by leave—There are several things I should say. Firstly, the need for a lead joint commander we have addressed in the report. There are problems because it appeared that the flotilla's commander of the amphibious task group was not responsible to the commander, northern command, but to the maritime commander. I believe that needs to be addressed in future exercises. Secondly, there is the problem of air mobility for the army. There is no doubt that there were difficulties with the grounding of the Nomad aircraft and problems with the Black Hawk helicopters. Also it is essential that we look at the early acquisition of airborne early warning and control aircraft—again matters which were identified in the report.

PARA.TAB: The third matter is the strong integration of women. Given the difficulties there have been in some sectors with the role that women will play in the Australian Defence Force, we were delighted to see women in a range of environments during the exercise. They should be commended, as should the relationship between the sexes. I trust that the final remarks on page 13 and 14, which the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) raised, and the particular recommendation in the report do generate a response from the ministry. There are matters within those comments which are worthy of long-term consideration.

The subcommittee looks forward to a full briefing on the outcomes of Kangaroo 95, the report of the Australian Defence Force and its own debriefing on the exercise in due course. I publicly express our appreciation for the opportunity to attend exercise Kangaroo 1995 to the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, and to all those within the Defence Force for the efforts which made our visit such a success.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, I present the committee's report entitled Report on the reviews of the 1993-94 annual reports of the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, together with the minutes of the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report deals with the committee's review of the 1993-94 annual reports of the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The report focuses primarily on the Reserve Bank. However, a major issue dealt with in the course of the review is the use of financial derivatives. As derivatives are used in all areas of the financial services industry, the committee felt it appropriate to also seek the views of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission regarding the supervision of the derivatives used in the insurance and superannuation industries. The outcome of those discussions is included in this report.

PARA.TAB: Before outlining some of the matters covered in the report, I would like to make a few comments on the importance of this process of reviewing the Reserve Bank of Australia's annual report. The committee regards the opportunity of using the authority the committee has under standing order 28(b) to examine annual reports to be a very valuable tool for committees to improve the accountability of departments and agencies to the parliament.

This is the second report that the committee has made on matters arising from the RBA's annual report. This process has facilitated increased scrutiny of the role and functions of the Reserve Bank. It has also enabled the committee to continue to oversight issues and developments in the banking industry, as well as in the wider financial services industry.

The central role played by the Reserve Bank in supervising the banking industry and the bank's important role in setting monetary policy underline the need for parliamentary accountability. This process provides a rare opportunity for members, through the committee system, to canvass issues with the Reserve Bank and to seek the views of the governor first-hand. While it was not the primary focus of the review, the committee continued to take advantage of the governor's appearance to canvass a number of issues related to the economy and monetary policy. Most of the matters discussed were of a general nature and are not canvassed in this report.

There were two matters that the committee felt worth reporting: the Reserve Bank's two to three per cent inflation target; and the use of prudential requirements to restrict lending for housing where the loan was for more than 80 per cent of the value of the property. With regard to the latter, the committee was not particularly concerned at the use of prudential measures for macro-economic purposes. It was concerned, though, that this measure had the potential to impact disproportionately on those members of the community who were not in a position to save for large deposits. It was not clear that this factor was taken into account when the Reserve Bank made the decision. This is an example of where parliamentary scrutiny can make the RBA more accountable for its decisions.

On the subject of economic policy, the committee has also concluded that an increased focus on monetary policy issues in future reviews will assist in meeting the committee's broader objective of improving the process of accountability to the parliament. The committee is of the view that there is an imbalance in parliamentary accountability on the development of monetary and fiscal policy. Through the appropriation bills, parliament extensively debates fiscal policy but no such scrutiny is afforded to monetary policy.

The committee believes that it can play an important role in this process by requiring senior Reserve Bank officials to appear regularly before the committee and by inquiring into and reporting on contemporary issues and debates concerning monetary policy. The committee will begin to develop this process in the next review. However, I must emphasise that this does not mean that the committee will be moving away from its concern with prudential and consumer issues.

The major topic dealt with in this year's review was the use of financial derivatives. The committee took detailed advice from both the Reserve Bank and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The committee recognises the importance of derivatives as risk management instruments. Nevertheless, the importance of supervision was clearly demonstrated with the sudden demise of Barings earlier this year. There is no possibility that the Reserve Bank or, indeed, the other financial supervisors will ever be in a position to be thoroughly familiar with all the new products being developed in the field of derivatives.

Since 1986 the Reserve Bank has been monitoring the involvement of banks with derivatives. Over recent years, it has intensified that monitoring and has developed a comprehensive approach to regulating their use. (Extension of time granted) The Reserve Bank has participated in the international approach to regulating the use of derivatives through the Basle committee on banking supervision. The thrust of the approach adopted by the RBA has been to require that adequate capital is being held against risk and to ensure that banks have appropriate risk management regimes in place.

The committee is satisfied that the Reserve Bank has adopted a responsible and thorough approach in dealing with the potential risk that derivatives pose to the stability of the financial system. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission has only just begun to address the question of derivatives. The ISC has issued a series of discussion papers for the insurance and superannuation industries. The committee is generally satisfied with the ISC's approach; however, there is some concern with regard to superannuation. The reason for that concern is that the ISC knows very little about the extent to which superannuation funds use derivatives products. The principles set out in the discussion papers are fine; however, they are still at the discussion stage.

The emphasis now being placed on superannuation and the fact that it will represent the life savings of many Australians make it imperative that those savings be afforded the maximum possible protection. The committee is of the view that the process initiated with the release of the discussion papers needs to be advanced as a matter of some priority. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the Treasurer monitor the implementation of the ISC's proposals for the use of derivatives by superannuation funds and report to the parliament at the first opportunity in 1996. The committee will also be following up this process after the ISC's 1994-95 annual report is tabled.

There are a number of other issues canvassed in the review process. The committee has a longstanding concern that the effectiveness of the Australian banking industry ombudsman scheme could be improved by increasing to a more realistic level the monetary limit placed on complaints and by increasing the scope of the scheme to include small incorporated bodies, such as small business and rural producers. The committee has held discussions with ombudsmen from the UK, New Zealand and Ireland. The schemes in those countries address the issues of financial limits and incorporated bodies. Their apparent success indicates that the reasons put by the banking industry for resisting change are of doubtful validity.

The committee has also pressed for an increased use of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms by the banking industry in order to avoid unnecessary resort to more formal and costly legal processes. The banks have all agreed with the need to avoid litigation where possible. The committee believes that it is time to have a look at the processes that they have developed and implemented. The committee has recommended that it be provided with a reference to inquire into the effectiveness of alternative dispute resolution in the banking industry, including the role played by the Australian banking industry ombudsman.

One pleasing aspect of this review was the fact that the banking industry, through the Australian Bankers Association, took the opportunity to raise a number of issues of broad concern to the banking industry. While the committee was not in a position to examine those matters in detail, it will take them up in the next review. Two issues that the committee has highlighted in this report are the proposal by the ABA for the right for banks to have retirement savings accounts and concerns over the levying, by state governments, of the financial institutions duty and the debit tax.

The committee was impressed with the proposal to introduce retirement savings accounts and is of the view that it warrants further investigation. The committee has recommended that the Treasury examine the proposal for the establishment of RSAs and provide a response to the committee in the course of its review of the RBA's 1994-95 annual report.

The committee will be interested to learn more about the strategies being developed by Australian banks to service Australia's trade with Asia. We endorse the ABA's views that Australian banks are dragging the chain in participating in trade growth with Asia and in servicing those customers who are becoming more involved with trade with Asia.

The issue of interest rate margins and fees was prominent this year. The committee did not pursue those matters due to the conduct of an inquiry by the PSA. I do anticipate, however, that members may wish to follow that up when we next meet with the Australian Bankers Association.

Finally, I thank the members of the committee for their active participation in the review process and the secretariat, led by Chris Paterson, for its work in producing the work. I also express the committee's appreciation for the positive participation of the Reserve Bank, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the Australian Bankers Association. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I echo the remarks made by the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, the member for Calare (Mr Simmons), in respect of the committee secretariat and Chris Paterson. I also commend him for his chairmanship of the committee. It continues to be a very good, hardworking and productive committee.

PARA.TAB: Our consideration of the annual report of the Reserve Bank gives the committee a very worthwhile opportunity to discuss with the Reserve Bank a matter which is vital to the public interest: the ongoing integrity of Australia's banking sector, which affects all Australian citizens to a greater or lesser extent. As part of this process, the committee also meets with the Australian Bankers Association and from time to time also takes the opportunity to meet with executives from the main banks.

The parliamentary scrutiny of the Reserve Bank's annual report gives members of this committee and the parliament an opportunity to debate a number of important matters. The state of Australia's economy is a matter for constant debate in this place. There is widespread and understandable concern about the current account deficit and foreign debt. The Reserve Bank plays an important role in setting and administering monetary policy. Therefore, it is vital that this parliament has some direct interface with the Reserve Bank. The Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration provides that opportunity.

Monetary policy is one of the vital tools—or levers, if you like to adopt that terminology—which a government has to manage the economic affairs of this nation. The Reserve Bank indicated to us, and this is confirmed in its report, that it is committed to the maintenance of a low inflation regime in Australia—a rate of around two per cent to three per cent per annum. The bank commented on the difficulty of getting people in this country to think in terms of low inflation, especially with an environment where home owners in particular have had in the past an expectation that higher rates of inflation were beneficial—an argument that I think can be shown to be somewhat fallacious.

Obviously, it is difficult for the government to achieve lower unemployment, lower inflation and low current account deficits in the present environment. I am sure that the committee, when it meets shortly with the Reserve Bank Governor, Mr Fraser, will be interested to raise with him the comments of one of his directors, Professor Bob Gregory, who noted in the past few days that growth rates of between 3.5 per cent and four per cent will lead inevitably to rising inflation as well as a falling Australian dollar and rising foreign debt. I am sure that will be hot on the agenda for our next meeting with the Reserve Bank.

A number of matters have been discussed by the committee specifically. Some of them have been referred to by the chairman. In respect of housing lending—this matter affects most Australians—the bank expressed concerns that the extent of the growth rate in this business was a worry. To quote the Governor, `because of the risk of sloppiness creeping in', the risk weighting for housing lending was increased to 100 for lending more than 80 per cent of the value of a property. This action was criticised by the ABA, which took the view that this action was more an attempt at demand measurement than a prudential measure. The committee takes the view that public policy should facilitate home ownership wherever possible. It is a desirable investment for Australian families and individuals.

The chairman mentioned the considerable time that the committee devoted to the question of derivatives. In the present context, there are some very legitimate concerns about derivatives. In the end, the committee concluded that it was reasonably satisfied with the Reserve Bank's approach to focusing on ensuring that adequate capital is being held against risk and that banks have appropriate risk management regimes in place.

The ombudsman scheme came up for discussion again. Once again, the committee came down with the view that it is satisfied with the scheme, although, as the chairman mentioned, we are recommending some changes, particularly to increase the scope of the ombudsman's activities to include incorporated bodies and farmers. The ombudsman scheme is very important, although it is fair to say that most banks—as most responsible business citizens are—are motivated to solve problems with their customers. The ombudsman scheme is an important adjunct to that process, as is the code of practice, which is largely being implemented. I notice that it came up in question time last week on the matter of the uniform credit legislation which needs to be introduced in each state to effectively facilitate the extension of that code of practice to all banks. I understand that that is happening.

The question of superannuation remains a very important one on the agenda for public policy debate in this country. (Extension of time granted) The Australian Bankers Association has expressed the view that banks should be able to offer a retirement savings account as part of that superannuation regime. I am pleased that the committee essentially agrees with that view and has recommended that a closer look be had at that issue.

One issue that the committee devotes a lot of time to and which is also of concern to the vast majority of Australians is the question of margins, fees and charges. The Prices Surveillance Authority, as the chairman said, has devoted considerable time this year to that matter and has made a number of conclusions and recommendations. These will come into focus as we discuss the bank's latest report in the next month or so. It is obviously a hot political potato. I am sure that, in the end, the committee takes the view that the banks are entitled to make profits. It is in the best interests of everyone to ensure that the banking sector is strongly competitive.

It is interesting in that context to note the Trade Practices Commission's latest decision to allow Westpac's bid for Challenge WA to go ahead on the basis that it would not substantially reduce competition. A decision came down virtually at the same time by the WA government to sell Bankwest to the Bank of Scotland. Certainly the committee takes the view that it is in the best interests of Australians for the banking sector to be as viable and competitive as possible.

I notice the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) in the House at the moment. I observe as an aside his almost bordering on hysterical criticism from time to time of the banks for some of their activities. He went a little short of suggesting the nationalisation of the banks. The committee has to view these things objectively. As I said at the outset, this committee does its job thoroughly. It focuses on the facts. In response to questions of the Reserve Bank about the facts in some of these matters, it came to light that Australia, in many respects, is fairly much lineball as far as international comparisons on these sorts of issues are concerned. I commend the work of the committee to the honourable member for Lilley in particular if he wants to make himself aware of the facts in relation to margins, fees and charges.

The mobile phone issue has been on a crescendo in the electorate of Dunkley. I have a letter here from some people in Pearcedale, in which one of these towers is proposed. The letter says:

On our visit to the Council we learned the station to be erected at Lloyd Park Langwarrin is in fact Vodafone—which results in two Vodafone stations, a mere 5 KM separating them, not as we thought 30KM.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not found out as yet why Vodafone would want to put two stations within five kilometres of each other, but I shall be determining that. For example, if the station is in a valley, there has to be an extra station. But I do not know why Vodafone has to have just five kilometres separating the two stations. As I have said before, base stations are going up all over the place. Telstra and Optus also want five kilometres between stations.

PARA.TAB: These towers are most unattractive, especially to people who choose to live in areas of natural bush or with wildlife, and properties will immediately be devalued. It has been estimated that you lose 25 per cent of your property value if one of these towers goes up. So that is something else people should watch. These towers also raise transmission problems.

It was interesting to note that Rupert Murdoch's mother joined in the protest against the erection of the Vodaphone tower in Pearcedale. Dame Elisabeth said at a gathering of concerned residents last week:

SPEECH.PARA: I feel for their anxiety. I just feel when so many people come together they should be supported.

We have a good supporter against mobile telephone towers when the mother of the head of the largest communications empire in the world is against it. In the future when satellites are used it will be argued by Optus, Vodaphone and Telstra that they will have to keep those towers there to pay for their investment. We are putting up obsolete technology that will be replaced by satellites. The moratorium on their erection must be enforced. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 June I placed a question on notice to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) raising concerns held by many people in my electorate about the recent and uncontrolled proliferation of telecommunications towers in Adelaide. I have not received an answer. On 26 July I wrote to the minister asking, amongst other things, when he expected a revised national telecommunications code to be finalised. I have still not received an answer to that.

PARA.TAB: My constituents want to know what the minister is going to do to protect their rights which have been totally eroded by the government's decision to exempt telecommunication carriers from state and local government planning laws. They are still waiting for answers. Such is the failure of this government to respond to legitimate community concerns.

There is widespread public concern about the government's decision to exempt carriers from the planning laws by which other developers abide. The chairman of the Austel review of the existing telecommunications national code has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The weight of opinion expressed to me during the public hearings has been strongly in favour of local government being given a role in the decision making process.

Under the existing code, the role given to local councils in this process is little more than tokenism. In my electorate, local councils that have tried to stop towers being constructed have found themselves ignored by the carriers. In the Enfield City Council area of my electorate a telecommunications tower was erected at Days Road. It was erected in one day in the rain contrary to the wishes of residents and council.

PARA.TAB: The present code allows a community, through its local council, to have a tower proposal reviewed by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, to which carriers are answerable. But, in practice, this mechanism does little to curb the power of carriers.

Firstly, councils that have been notified of a proposal to erect a tower have a mere 30 days to notify and consult with residents and, if required, formulate an objection. This is simply not enough time for councils to exercise what little power they have. Secondly, the cost of such an undertaking is also prohibitive since there is no compensation for councils which engage in the consultation process. The arrogance that the government has cultivated amongst carriers is well illustrated by the circumstances surrounding the proposal to erect a tower at 29 Grassmere Road in the Prospect City Council area of my electorate.

Last week I received a call from an Adelaide businessman, Mr Cruse, who owns the site at Grassmere Road on which Vodaphone is insistent it shall build a tower—contrary to council and resident opposition. On the remainder of this site the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service engaged Mr Cruse to design, construct and lease to it a building. Subsequently, the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service decided that it did not wish to proceed because of the tower that was to be co-located on the site. Keeping in mind that Mr Cruse has not signed a binding agreement with Vodaphone, it is clear that it is in Mr Cruse's interests to stop the use of his land by Vodaphone if that is what it takes to ensure the future of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service project.

Perhaps, not surprisingly, Mr Cruse has found himself powerless to stop the construction of the tower on his land. The current disregard for communities' rights being displayed by telecommunications carriers has been allowed to go on for too long. People have found their local environment disfigured by mobile phone towers emitting microwaves—microwaves which have not yet been definitively proven to be harmless to those who are continually exposed to them. The laying of cables by carriers is beginning to pose a similar set of problems for communities.

The existing code which regulates the behaviour of the carriers involved in the roll-out of telecommunications networks is simply not adequate. A new and tighter code with more power for local councils is needed—and it is needed now! This government cannot continue to use reviews as a way of avoiding action. The latest review of the telecommunications national code must be completed within the next few months. Left any longer, it is obvious that the introduction of a revised code will be placed on the backburner by the onset of an election campaign.
My constituents are not asking that the roll-out of telecommunications services be stopped. They are merely asking that their interest be taken into account—and this is not too much to ask.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Easson Mrs M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to speak today on the siting of telecommunications towers to facilitate mobile telephone services. There are two concerning issues that I would like to raise.

PARA.TAB: The first issue relates to a rally which took place recently in my electorate on the siting and construction of a telecommunications tower at All Hallows School in Five Dock. The system, as outlined in the telecommunications national code, did not work adequately in this situation. The local council claimed ignorance in relation to their rights and obligations in this matter.

I believe that this information should not just be provided to councils via general administrators but rather to mayors, councillors and aldermen who must be made aware of and responsible for not only these rules but also their obligations. There is no question that under the telecommunications national code councillors do have a right and/or an obligation if they have any concern about these towers to thus take up the matter with the Environment Protection Authority and also, from there, the Australian Radiation Laboratory. This was the case in Harbord but not in Five Dock—and, therefore, no residents were consulted about this tower.

I notice that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) has written to councils reminding them of their obligations, and I too will be writing to councils in my electorate to inform them once again of their rights and obligations under the telecommunications national code. If councils raise obligations to these towers on their potential effects on local residents, this at least causes some consultation with the local community. Adequate consultation with the local community was totally absent in Five Dock.

Vodaphone, the company involved, is also a signatory to the guidelines—guidelines which were developed in association with the Municipal Association of Victoria—which require carriers to consult with the local community in a situation where they are placing a tower in a high impact area. I would think that next to a school is a high impact area; certainly, next to a school or a child-care centre where children are playing outside for prolonged periods must be deemed to be a high impact area. This consultation should have occurred via the carrier in the case of Five Dock, irrespective of council's failure to act in this issue.

All three carriers have said that they will abide by the guidelines of the Municipal Association of Victoria, yet in this case—although Vodaphone had consulted with the priest at All Hallows, who had then consulted with the parish council and other parishioners—Vodaphone had not undertaken sufficient community consultation prior to the contract and the construction of the telecommunications tower. This consultation could have taken place in a number of ways: via a letterbox drop, doorknocking, an advertisement in the local press or a public meeting.

The meeting against the siting of this particular tower was exceedingly unpleasant and nasty for all of those involved—and I am sure that no carrier would want to go through that experience again. People need to be consulted where any potential question of safety hazards is involved. My understanding is that the work on the tower has now ceased. Certainly, I would be failing in my duty as a representative for my electorate and community in Lowe if I did not bring to the House the stress, angst and frustration which the construction of this tower has caused in my electorate.

I have taken the step of writing a submission to Austel, the organisation which has been conducting an inquiry into the placement of towers and an appropriate code of conduct, and I would like to read part of it to you. Certainly, before doing so, I should point out that we all realise that mobile phone usage is growing, that people want an effective and low priced system and we know that these towers have to be placed somewhere. But the CSIRO at this stage is saying that there is insufficient scientific evidence. In my submission to Austel, I have said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although there is no evidence which categorically links the transmissions from telecommunications towers with risks of disease the general public has made this association. Given the fact that this is new technology and no iron-clad guarantee can be given that electromagnetic transmissions won't result in cancer or deformity in ten or twenty years time there is only one real option.

The Telecommunications National Code must be modified to deal with public demands for greater caution. Common sense dictates that we must at least tread a cautious path where there is even a remote threat of the well-being of infants and children in our community.

I am therefore strongly recommending that the Telecommunications National Code be modified to ban the construction of telecommunications towers within 300 metres of schools and childcare centres or other potentially high impact areas where children regularly congregate.
Or, for that matter, where adults regularly congregate. I continued:
I trust that these genuine concerns will be given thorough consideration during your revision of the Telecommunications National Code.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the mover of this motion, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), who has taken the time, despite the fact that he is not speaking on this motion today, to come in and listen to the debate on his motion. As he and other members have already indicated, the proliferation without control of mobile phone towers in recent years is causing a great deal of concern in the community. Nowhere is this concern more obvious than in my electorate of Moore.

PARA.TAB: Moore, which takes in the municipalities of Stirling and Wanneroo—Wanneroo being one of the fastest growing municipalities in the country—has been virtually besieged by plans for more and more towers and other installations. To the incredulity of my constituents—people who virtually woke up one morning to find a 60-metre tower on their front lawn—it is becoming obvious that they can do little to nothing to stop this practice. Their local councils are virtually powerless to stop them.

Public opinion seems to be the only force which can have any effect on the plans of the telecommunication carriers to build these sometimes grotesque structures. For example, three carriers recently planned to erect a facility on a disused water tower in North Beach, at the southern part of my electorate. On the face of it, that might seem a reasonable course of action were it not for the fact that the tower has been restored and is used by the local historical society as a museum.

This decision was strongly opposed by concerned local residents, the North Suburban Historical Society and the Coastal Heritage Society. I too am opposed to the erection of the tower, continuing my efforts to have the federal government rethink its communications policy which sees telecommunications companies able to build such facilities in any location without the permission of local residents and councils.

When the decision was announced to place a transceiver on the Mount Flora tower, I released a media statement calling on greater consultation between the company involved and the Stirling City Council. In addition, I wrote to the council to voice my objection to the structure. Subsequently, the company, under pressure of public opinion, agreed to co-locate the communications equipment it needs on the nearby police tower. I am pleased in this case that community pressure was able to obtain a satisfactory resolution to this problem on this occasion.

This success seems to be a rarity if the number of plans to build towers that have surfaced in recent months is any guide. In fact, my opposition to the erection of such towers with community consultation goes a long way back. When another company announced it would build a freestanding tower in the centre of Joondalup over a year ago, I immediately wrote to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to express the concerns of local residents.

The minister told this House, in answer to a question about this matter, that he had agreed to require phone carriers to pursue greater community consultation in future plans. Unfortunately, I have to say that that promise seems to have been rather empty. It is similar to some of the other promises peddled by the three major phone carriers. In frustration, in November last year I placed a private member's motion on the Notice Paper in the House which called on the government to allow councils a veto over objectionable plans by big communications companies. Hence I am pleased to support the motion moved by the member for Warringah.

The effects towers are having and may have on my constituents are growing rather than receding. Take, for example, the Barnes family in Ocean Reef. This family contacted me on learning that they had no way of arguing against a 35-metre high tower that was to be erected 60 metres from their property line on a nearby hillside. Mrs Barnes wrote to me saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly protest that the tower will be less than 60 metres from my property and will have a detrimental effect on the value thereof.
She went on to say:

When I open my bedroom window (which faces the hill) I don't want to see a tower 35 metres high staring straight back at me. I'd much rather see trees and nature. That is another thing you (the phone company) don't realise . . . that you are destroying the homes of animals and birds that might have nests in trees nearby . . .

Mrs Barnes is right, of course. She bought her property in good faith, knowing there was an existing tower on the other side of the hill beside her house. She accepted that when she paid for her house. What the Barnes family cannot understand, and what thousands of other families across this country cannot understand, is that mobile phone service providers can arbitrarily erect a structure anywhere they want without recourse to local councils, state government and, for that matter, the federal government itself. The Barnes family and dozens of others who have contacted me are also wary of the possible health hazard an uncontrolled proliferation of facilities may cause. I refer to some of the comments made by the member for Lowe (Mrs Easson) in relation to the waves that are emitted from these towers.

PARA.TAB: We need to change the telecommunications regulations to give local councils, which are closer to the needs of the people than the managers of the carriers could ever be, the power to veto proposals in the public interest. This motion simply calls on the government to admit they got it wrong. The minister erred when he granted carriers these draconian and unlimited powers to proliferate their facilities mindless of the legitimate concerns of the community. I commend this motion to the House.
