TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)endorses the actions of the 35 Australian members of parliament who travelled to Tahiti to participate in protests against the decision by the French President, Jacques Chirac, to resume nuclear testing in Polynesia;
(2)congratulates Franca Arena MLC for initiating the venture which grew to include Australian MPs from most political parties and most legislatures as well as MPs from seventeen other countries;
(3)endorses the creation of Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapon Free World at Nuuroa Beach Park, Tahiti, on Sunday, 3 September 1995, and urges all parliamentarians to join it;
(4)congratulates Oscar Temaru on being elected the inaugural president of the organisation and Australian Senator Bruce Childs on being elected the inaugural secretary;

(5)congratulates Senator Tom Wheelwright and Ian Cohen MLC for their courage in joining a small Greenpeace vessel to sail to Mururoa Atoll in order to represent Australian MPs and to enhance the effectiveness of the protests against the tests; and
(6)calls on President Chirac to halt these acts of violence against the people of the Pacific and against the conscience of the world.

To a very large extent the motion speaks for itself. I have taken the opportunity in the wording of that motion to congratulate Franca Arena for her initiative in seeking to arrange an appropriate form of protest by members of parliament throughout Australia in Papeete, Tahiti. I have congratulated Oscar Temaru and Bruce Childs on the responsibilities which they have been given in relation to a new organisation, Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapon Free World. I have also congratulated Tom Wheelwright and Ian Cohen on their courage in going on a relatively small vessel to Mururoa Atoll in order to extend the protest and to make it more effective.

PARA.TAB: The crux of the motion, the essence of the motion, is that it calls on President Chirac to halt these acts of violence against the people of the Pacific and against the conscience of the world. I have referred to some particular people in the wording of that motion, but I want to refer to others—other members of this parliament who, on their own initiative, went to Tahiti to join a world protest against the resumption of those tests. In addition to me, there were Robert Bell, Bob Charles, Bruce Childs, John Coulter, Paul Filing, Chris Gallus, Clyde Holding, Colin Hollis, Bob Horne, Peter Knott, Dee Margetts, Allan Morris, Shayne Murphy, Sid Spindler, Tom Wheelwright, Harry Woods and Trish Worth. I emphasise that there was no compulsion on those people to go to Tahiti in order to participate in that protest. They did it of their own volition.

I want to emphasise as well that it was representative of every major political grouping in this parliament, including Independents. It does not include the National Party. I think that was more coincidental than anything else. I do not believe and I hope that the National Party did not boycott the protest. Arising from that initiative by Franca Arena, in addition to Australia there were other countries represented on that small island out in the middle of the Pacific that day. People came from all around the world to participate in that protest and to march arm in arm and hand in hand, singing in unison in order to protest against this abominable decision which has been taken by the French President in order to continue those tests.

I want to recognise as well that, arising from that initiative by Franca Arena, not only were there parliamentarians from Australia but also parliamentarians from Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Denmark, the European Parliament, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Peru, the United Kingdom and the United States. From all of those countries members of parliament went to Tahiti to record their protest.

It was inspiring and encouraging to be in Tahiti. On Saturday, 2 September in Papeete, the capital of Tahiti, 10,000 people marched in protest. At least 9,500 of those people were not from other countries in the world. At least 9,500 of them were Polynesians. As I have said, there were 35 members of parliament from Australia, including those from this federal parliament whose names I have previously indicated.

On Sunday, 3 September in Nuuroa Beach park, Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapon Free World was formed. Oscar Temaru is the inaugural president and Senator Bruce Childs is the secretary. With this decision to resume the tests, France has earned the wrath, the condemnation and the outrage of the world. It has broken its own nuclear test moratorium, which it entered into last year with the United Kingdom, Russia and the United States. It has threatened the possible success of the comprehensive test ban treaty scheduled for next year. It has encouraged and provided some legitimacy to China in the resumption of its tests. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—It gives me great pleasure to follow the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) in this debate. In general, I support the thrust of his motion. I want to refer to the effect that these tests which France will carry out in the South Pacific are going to have. France is sending a message to the non-signatory nations of the non-proliferation treaty that atomic weapons are important. France is in the privileged position of having nuclear weapons and of supporting the non-proliferation treaty for those countries which have signed and which cannot have them. However, at the same time it is sending another message to countries like India, which is a non-signatory to the treaty, that nuclear weapons are important and that it will continue to use them.

PARA.TAB: Why would the other countries not ask of France: if it is so important for you to have nuclear weapons, why shouldn't we? The message that France is sending to the world is that it intends to keep its nuclear arsenal and that it sees it as an essential part of its own protection. We might ask why France sees that as necessary. Who is the enemy that France has in mind? If it cannot specify the enemy at present, why is the same condition not applied to other countries? France has sent a very negative message to the rest of the world on this issue.

In relation to the Pacific, France has shown a total disregard of its wishes. That is not to ignore that there are people in Tahiti who support France's position on this. Perhaps one of the saddest things that I saw in Papeete was a sign which said, `The bomb means jobs.' I think that is a comment on the legacy that France has left in Tahiti. That island is dependent for 20 per cent of its economy on the testing of nuclear weapons in the Pacific.

I turn to the environmental effects these tests will have in the Pacific. Why did France not choose to carry them out in France? I think the answer to that is clear. Can you imagine France doing it in the Pyrenees and being able to get away with it? Physically there would be no difference, but can you imagine the outrage of the French citizens and the rest of Europe if France tested its bombs in Europe? Instead, it will carry out the tests in the Pacific, where the people of the Pacific have less power. The environmental effects may not be immediate, but it is concerning that iodine 131 will remain in the area for a week. France has claimed that this is contained in the atoll, but there are fissures in the atoll and there is a definite and clear chance of both leaching and leakage. Of that, we have strontium 90 with a half life of 29 years and caesium 137 with a half life of 130 years. If these two radioactive substances leach into the Pacific, there will be a definite environmental effect on the marine life of that area, not to mention the flow-on effects to the Pacific islands.

Briefly, the message sent out by this group of parliamentarians who chose to participate in the demonstration at Papeete has been very positive. It has helped to focus the attention of Europe on what is happening in the Pacific and on this wider issue of France thumbing its nose to the rest of the world by testing these nuclear weapons and setting a double standard with respect to the nuclear proliferation treaty. So, if nothing else, what we did by going to Papeete was to keep world attention focused on what France is doing in the Pacific and to give the people of the world the opportunity to say no to France on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will recall the difficulties experienced between Australia and France over French testing in the mid-1980s. I also note that actions were taken before that by New Zealand. When I was France in 1992 the issue of French nuclear testing was raised with me by members of the French-Australian Friendship Parliamentary Group. At that stage, Mitterrand was backing off on the tests, and the difference that course of action made was enormous. At that time, the programs between our two countries were very strong and we were developing a rapport. It has been absolutely appalling in recent times to watch that relationship being shattered by the actions of the French President and not the French people.

PARA.TAB: It is extremely important that during this quite difficult period we set three objectives. First and foremost, we must maintain solidarity with our neighbours in the South Pacific. We are one of many countries in the South Pacific. At the moment, we chair the South Pacific Forum, and that responsibility is a very important one. It is important that we act in unison with the people and the countries of the South Pacific and that we represent them as best we can.

Secondly, it is critical that we differentiate between the views of the President of France and those of the French people. That is fundamentally important. From my experience—and I have been in contact with French people for a long time—I do not believe that they would agree with what he is doing. Thirdly, we should seek to unify world opinion against the French President, and that is already happening. In that context, the visit by parliamentarians from all over the world to Tahiti a few weeks ago assisted in the attainment of those three measures.

Firstly, our visit instilled enormous pride in the Tahitian people because of the fact that people from other parts of the world were interested in seeing them and talking to them. That gave an enormous boost to their morale. I found them to be very gentle people. As someone commented earlier, they are the pacifists of the Pacific. They are very undemonstrative people, which is why the events of some weeks later were so appalling. They sought very little. When talking to them individually, particularly the younger ones, we found that they were extremely grateful that we thought enough of the issue to actually visit them.

The other poignant point relates to the Japanese. Japan is unique in the world in respect of its experience with nuclear energy. It is the only country that has been a victim of it, and it has a special right in my view. The comments by a female survivor of Hiroshima, who was at the meeting on the Saturday night, were extremely poignant and very important to all of us. The Japanese nation has focused on these tests like never before. What Chirac has done to France in that context is absolutely irresponsible. He has made France the focus of not just world attention and world concern but also anger. The French people do not deserve that; they do not warrant that.

The motion refers to the formation of a parliamentary group, which is an enormous initiative and one which has importance here and now. The removal of atomic weapons from the world arsenals should be a major concern for all of us, and I am sure that it is. In his own way, Chirac has given a boost to that movement, and I am sure that in the time ahead parliamentarians around the world will get stronger and will work more closely together.

I cannot speak in this debate without making some comment about the domestic situation in Tahiti. When I was in France the French parliamentarians raised with me the question of indigenous people—as they should; when we visit countries, we raise with those countries our concerns, whether they be human rights in East Timor or situations in Europe or eastern Europe. We do not normally interfere or involve ourselves too strongly in the domestic politics of a country, but many people in Tahiti would like Australians to think about what is happening there.

What is sinking in, and what is becoming quite clear, is that Tahiti is now part of Europe, in French terms. It means that any European can visit Tahiti without a visa and can buy and settle within three months. A French citizen in Tahiti can vote and any European citizen has a right to vote in Tahiti after six months residence. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support in principle the motion by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and to congratulate him on bringing this issue before this parliament. Several weeks ago, when it became apparent that the French President, Jacques Chirac, would defy world opinion and continue with nuclear tests in the South Pacific, though they had been abandoned some time ago, I put a petition in various spots in my electorate. In less than two weeks, over 6,000 of my constituents signed the petition, abhorring the actions proposed to be taken by French President Chirac.

PARA.TAB: When it was proposed that Australian parliamentarians from both state houses and this federal parliament proceed on a ship to Mururoa, to Tahiti, to protest together with other parliamentarians from around the world against this action by the French, I was delighted to represent my constituents and my own views, and I continued on the aircraft to Papeete.

For me, a protest of this nature was a first. I have never protested before. It was a unique experience. I am told that my friends from the left do not often see supposedly right wing politicians in such protest marches. On that Saturday morning, the heat, the light and the colour, and the sound, the vibrancy and the smell—the atmosphere associated with that protest—were beyond description. It has meant for me a memory that will live with me all my life.

There were parliamentarians from Australia, New Zealand, Japan, from all over central Europe, from Scandinavia, from North America and South America—and, of course, many from South Pacific island nations. I thought one of the most important things about the protest march itself was the array of international politicians joined together at their own expense in protest at an action that we all feel—and most of the world feels—is simply wrong.

Two years ago I had the opportunity to participate in my one and only parliamentary representation visit, to five Pacific island nations. We visited Papua New Guinea, Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, Western Samoa and Tonga. During that trip I came to the view that Australia, for a very long time, had seen itself as a piece of Europe, somehow transposed in this huge island in the South Pacific. Today our Prime Minister, Paul Keating, would like us to think of ourselves as a piece of Asia. I think that both of those views are flawed. We are the biggest player in the South Pacific. We are a South Pacific nation. We are a country which is perhaps the greatest melting pot of the world's humanity that the world has ever seen—and a very successful one—and we represent the views of the world. In this demonstration and protest, when we went to Papeete, that is what we as Australian politicians were doing.

I believe that we have a responsibility for those little Pacific island nations out there. They have a tough time trying to make the transition between market economies and today's modern, highly competitive and highly mechanised industrialised world. It is very difficult for them. The Pacific island image that we have in our heads perhaps no longer exists and, unfortunately, may never again exist, not as we would wish it to be. It is part of our responsibility to try to help them with this transition. In that respect, France has no place exploding nuclear weapons in our part of the world—in our patch—and against the wishes of the native islanders throughout the Pacific and the now native islanders on the biggest player of them all, Australia.

I was proud to have been a part of the delegation; it was a tremendous experience. I hope that the new organisation which was formed out of that visit will help do great things in the future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already had the opportunity in the grievance debate to put on the record many of the experiences that I had in Papeete. But I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) for putting up this private member's motion today and to say that I certainly agree with the spirit of that motion. Perhaps I would have worded it slightly differently, but I think it gives members from both sides of this House—and an Independent as well—an opportunity to come in here and speak on an issue which is important.

PARA.TAB: We are elected to this place to represent those people in our own districts and our own areas. In the time that I have been in this place I have never found an issue that has so united people of different age groups and different backgrounds with their strong opposition to nuclear testing. Peace is a fragile thing, something requiring vision to achieve and something that requires some effort to achieve.

The world is becoming a smaller place, with communications becoming more sophisticated, but there was nothing terribly sophisticated about our protest. We went to Tahiti as individuals and, as the mover of the motion said, Franca Arena is to be congratulated for having the initiative. I am sure that at times the organisation was lacking. That was no-one's fault in particular. It was just that there were people coming from all around the world—from all the countries that have been mentioned.

When we gathered for that protest march there were doubts in my mind as to whether we would ever get under way. But it all happened. Many of the locals were very smart, because we covered the whole distance in that heat and they joined in along the way. Part of what made it so spontaneous was the fact that people came out of their homes, they lined the street, they greeted us and they were warm towards us. There was no hint in the time that I was there of any of the violence that was to follow as we flew out and the French exploded that bomb. The protests that were beamed around the world were really quite a shock, certainly to me and I am sure to others.

The important thing was that we came together from around the world to give the French government a very clear message. As other people have said, I do not believe that we hold any grudge against the French people; they have a government that is letting them down very badly. I hope that they make their protests known and known very strongly.

It was a good experience to meet with delegates from countries such as Germany and Denmark, who are closer geographically to France, but I also felt that we were very much part of the Pacific. Countries such as Japan, New Zealand and Australia obviously feel very strongly about this issue. While I went there without giving a great deal of thought to the local politics of French Polynesia, one certainly could not help but be affected by it, because the reality is that this French testing would not be taking place there if French Polynesia was not a colony. While the majority of people there at this stage claim to support the French and say that they are French, as the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) said, the fact that there could be signs up to the effect that they relied on the economy of the bomb is a sad reflection on the inheritance that they are receiving from that French colonialism.

The true issue for the world is that we must be creating an environment where nuclear tests will not be held and where nuclear weapons will not be produced. That is not to say that—along with many others, I am sure—I do not recognise that since the end of World War II possessing the bomb has been a disincentive to further warfare but I would like to think we have moved on from that. I would like to think that many parliamentarians will join in this group to be known as Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapon Free World. While it might take some time to work through a number of issues to achieve that, that should be our aim as members of parliament in this place representing those people in our electorates who feel so strongly about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I went in the delegation with the other 35 members, and it was a privilege to be there in Papeete. Perhaps I should state initially that, whilst we are all united on the view that nuclear testing should not take place, I will not go as far as saying that we might all be united on the view that there should not be nuclear weapons because I am not sure on that point. But I go a little bit further than most of us are able to go.

PARA.TAB: For 25 years, I and many people like me have been substantially against the nuclear industry in total. To my young children and to people who do not really wish to get into the technical aspects of nuclear testing and radioactivity, the argument against the nuclear industry overall can be put into a very simple argument. If you have a house on a quarter acre block with a fence and, instead of using your toilet you use your backyard, eventually you will get sick. I know it is very base imagery; nevertheless, it is true.

That is where my opposition to the nuclear industry lies, because there is no nuclear toilet. There is no safe way of disposing of radioactivity. There is no safe way of shielding human beings from the biological effects that radioactivity has upon us. Sure there is natural radiation in our environment, but I would suggest to you there are also natural cholera viruses, et cetera. There is no point in exploiting, enlarging or enhancing them.

Basically, the world, though it be a big place, is very small. Eventually the actions of the French at Mururoa and Fangataufa, the actions of the Americans, the actions of the British, the actions of the Chinese and the actions of our own Australian people in the nuclear industry will have horrendous consequences on the biological entities that we humans are.

The second point I would like to make is the position of the French in the world today. Why is it that we object to them having a nuclear testing program and nuclear weapons? I cannot speak for other people but I can speak for myself. My grandfather left one lung, two-thirds of his other lung and 35,000 of his mates on the shores of France in the First World War. My family was also involved in the Second World War fighting for France and freedom and democracy—the place where all of us believe democracy first started in the modern world and where the people of France stood up said, `We are the people. We are going to have liberty, fraternity and equality.' What has happened? What has happened to the 35,000 bodies in the First World War that are buried there as landfill in France? At Villers-Bretonneux they said, `We will never forget you, Australia.' Well, unfortunately, the government has. Unfortunately, Jacques Chirac has forgotten the sacrifices that were made by people not only from my country but from countries all over the world to stop fascism.

It is quite outrageous to the memory of all those people who died in the First World War and Second World War to enable the French people and the people of France to have democracy that fascism is rising up in that country. I have nothing against French people nor France. In fact, as was pointed out by one of the officers when I was arrested in Tahiti, 65 per cent of the French people are on our side.

The final thing that I would like to say before my time for speaking runs out is that the French, with their fascist attitude and derogation of world opinion, now are going to put the Maohi people in the position where their human rights will be taken away. Unless the eyes of the world stay on French Polynesia, I can assure you there will be a bloody coup of the worst sort as seen in El Salvador, Honduras or Guatemala.

If we do not stand up for those people who we engaged and talked to, then those people are going to truly die, because they have a fascist government over the top of them led by Jacques Chirac. He has to be told by the world that we will not tolerate his looking upon himself as King Louis XV or XVI or King Jacques Chirac XVII. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I journeyed to Tahiti with my colleagues for the purpose of representing, in the first instance, not merely my own views but the views of my electorate. I have been in politics for some time now, both in state and Commonwealth parliaments, and the strength of people's feelings was driven home to me when in a matter of four hours outside my electorate office in Melbourne Ports some 6,000 people lined up to sign a petition against nuclear testing.

PARA.TAB: Another thing I enjoyed and felt was significant was that this event was the one occasion that I can remember in the history of Australian politics where a delegation represented basically every political position in Australia. That is something we can all be proud of. We are used to having disagreements about all sorts of issues, but amongst those of my parliamentary colleagues at state and federal levels there was a uniformity of view and a commitment. Friendships were born in that situation. We found ourselves reaching out to each other, with the support of the indigenous people, on an issue which has truly embraced not merely the people of the Pacific but the people of the world.

It is unfortunate and sad that France, under the existing government, has denied, in a sense, its own history, its own culture and its own contribution to world civilisation by the actions in which it is now involved. The reality is that we met with people in the local assembly who described themselves as French who had dissociated themselves with the independence movement. They made it perfectly clear that, despite their very best endeavours, they were unable to debate this very important issue in their own assembly.

The assertions made by the existing government of France—which does not speak for the French people on this occasion—that this is really a domestic issue is polemical and political nonsense. When we first got off the plane, the first question I was asked was, `With respect, what right have you to be here interfering with our politics?' The answer is simple. The answer was given in 1914. The answer was given in the last war. You have only to journey to Villers-Bretonneux, a decisive battle in which the Australians figured large, to see the ages on the gravestones of young Australians. You have only to look at the list of some 11,000 Australians who are missing and lying in unmarked graves.

That is our right, and I am not going to accept any assertion that says on an issue as important as this is to our region that we do not have a right. Not only do we merely have a right but we have a duty to speak on this issue, as we have spoken with one voice and with one principle. I found it interesting that, having been on many of these demonstrations over a period of time, some of my political colleagues felt the solidarity and the comradeship that grew out of this very significant political event.

Perhaps there will come a time when other events in our own internal domestic politics will enable us to speak with one voice. On this occasion I think one can say that all members of this delegation, coming as they have from the cross-stream of Australian politics, spoke generally with one voice and with one commitment on behalf of the people of this nation. To be part of that was to not merely fulfil one's duty as an Australian parliamentarian, but it was a positive assertion that we are all part of mankind and that we are not going to sit back and see one group of people being dealt with in the way in which the local people are being dealt with.

It is unfortunate that France is locked into its own polemic on this occasion, but it is a polemic which has a face which will not survive the emerging forces that are appearing in our own region. I thank all my colleagues who participated in this important event. I thank them for their comradeship. I thank them for their commitment. Perhaps—I hope not—we may well meet again in Tahiti on a future occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion. I concur with the comments of the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) that one of the great features of this particular visit was the solidarity of members who may have had some differences of opinion on the aspects of the independent issue but were united on the central matter of the tests. We were unified. At the demonstration on the Saturday, and the consequent meetings, there was consensus that reflected the widespread community opinion in Australia opposing the resumption of these nuclear weapons tests—tests which are opposed by more than 60 per cent of the French population.

PARA.TAB: I took a great deal of pride in presenting to the high commissioner of French Polynesia a letter from the mayor of the city of Wanneroo—the largest municipality in my electorate—representing the views of the city which is quite fundamentally opposed to the tests. I was proud to have the opportunity and the ability to join my colleagues and represent the views of my constituents in such a way. It allowed people to see that, even at a time when they perhaps think that no-one else is listening to them, their voices are heard at the very centre of where these things are being decided and enacted.

My wife is French and I have a number of French in-laws who share my views and the views of our delegation about the tests. By and large the French are a very civilised nation. Unfortunately, Mr Chirac's government is out of kilter with public opinion which is quite clearly against the resumption of these tests.

I might say that these tests have more to do with domestic French politics than anything else. In recent times we saw some very serious incursions in the municipal elections by Le Pen National Front—the extreme right-wing political force in France which has been steadily gaining influence at the expense of the traditional right. This has obviously caused Mr Chirac to bring these tests back, under pressure from the French military, at a time when quite clearly there is absolutely no reason for nuclear weapons testing by the French—except, I might say, if you were to look at the cynical aspect of the initial test and the much more powerful one they have announced that they intend to conduct in the next couple of days.

There is talk of the testing of a neutron bomb by the French. For those who are not familiar with a neutron bomb, it is a nuclear weapon that does not destroy property but issues a tremendous dosage of radioactivity sufficient to cause extreme radiation sickness. People become ill very quickly and die within a very short time after the exploding of the weapon. It was designed for the European theatre of war during the Cold War. If the Russians had invaded western Europe, presumably the neutron bomb would have been used as a means of stopping the Russians from going any further. It was a weapon that was developed in the first instance by the United States. The United States, however, recognised the immorality of such a weapon and stopped development of it. On the scale of all nuclear weapons it would represent the worst case. I am not suggesting for one minute that the others are more acceptable. I am just saying this one happens to be a particularly perfidious example of nuclear weapons.

So here we have the French government resuming nuclear tests at the expense of the people who live in our region—at the expense, quite clearly, of the Polynesians who will be depending very heavily on tourism as a principal source of revenue in years to come and, of course, will have seen that opportunity to extract revenue from their tourism industry diminished by the fact that within their island group they have had these tests conducted.
I might also point out, Mr Deputy Speaker, my grave disappointment at the behaviour of the British government on this matter. They have been absolutely pitiful.

Also there is a necessity for us to make sure that our protests are heard loud and clear in relation to the Chinese nuclear tests. The difference is: one country has a democratic system and the other one does not. One asks oneself how many Chinese citizens have had the opportunity of registering their view about these tests conducted in their midst.

Finally, I congratulate the members of the delegation who went to Papeete and the tremendous effect we had on the issue. Quite clearly, the French would like to say we stirred up the problems that have occurred since.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The time allotted for this debate has also expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this house:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)acknowledges that attention deficit disorder (ADD) is a medical condition rather than a behavioural disorder;
(2)expresses concern at the limited resources with federal and State government funding dealing specifically with ADD;
(3)notes that an unreasonably large percentage of the community is affected by the medical condition ADD;
(4)expresses concern at the ongoing social ramifications of ADD and the inadequate response of policy makers to cope with the condition;
(5)expresses concern at the lack of specific funding within special education expenditure for children suffering ADD; and
(6)calls upon the Government to review education expenditure with the intention to improve resources available to adequately address the needs of children suffering ADD.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I bring before you and fellow members of the House a health issue—in fact, a chronic health problem—that profoundly affects some 20,000 Australian young people, in addition to an indeterminable number of `undiagnosed' or `misdiagnosed' adults.

PARA.TAB: I am speaking of attention deficit disorder—commonly referred to as ADD—a rather simple but somewhat misleading term that encompasses a medical menagerie of symptoms ranging from aggression, anti-social behaviour, domestic violence and criminality through to complex psychiatric disorders.

I have spoken to the House on this issue before. However, for now, let's turn our attention to the raw facts about ADD. It affects at least five per cent—yes, one in 20—of every school aged child in Australia, in addition to at least two to three per cent of adults. Overall, it affects at least 20,000 children—who will soon become 20,000 very lost, confused and misunderstood adults.

Sixty-five per cent of these children will have more middle ear infections than any other member of the population—and subsequent short-term, recurrent hearing loss. Sixty per cent of these children have some bi-motor difficulty. The condition is likely to become more widespread, as it is proven to be genetically passed from one generation to another. Some 20,000 today—but how many more when these children reach maturity, and the age of child-bearing and child-rearing?

However, the facts and figures dehumanise this particular condition. These children suffer—and suffer greatly. So profound is their lot, that they cannot even understand reality as we know it. Their normal day is a nightmare of disjointed thoughts, with an obscure relationship to time. Medical experts are only now beginning to unravel the threads, symptoms and expressions that together weave the pattern of ADD.

This issue is not about pointing a finger at who is responsible or not. This issue is not about under whose portfolio this issue arises or relates. This issue is not about politics, government or factional distinctions. This issue is about children and their right to the best quality of life we, as a society, can offer. This is about the future—and ensuring that we are providing every opportunity for Australians to be as healthy as possible.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I urge you and my colleagues to undertake the following actions: acknowledge that attention deficit disorder is a medical condition, rather than a behavioural disorder; express concern at the limited resources with federal and state government funding dealing specifically with ADD; note that an unreasonably large percentage of the community is affected by the medical condition ADD; express concern at the ongoing social ramifications of ADD, and the inadequate response of policy makers to cope with the condition; express concern at the lack of specific funding within special education expenditure for children suffering ADD; and call on the government to review education expenditure with the intention to improve resources available to adequately address the needs of children suffering ADD.

By responding to these issues we will ensure that ADD is not only recognised but accepted as a real condition. With such acceptance comes tolerance and understanding. In reality, this is all that the ADD sufferers and their families are asking. We cannot legislate to change attitudes, but we can encourage and nurture an environment of social justice and tolerance towards all people, regardless of background, religion, impairment or any other, let us say, `feature', be it a physical, emotional or psychological difference, which sets one Australian apart from another.

As a nation we have many health issues to face, and face them we must. Health is not a domain of the privileged or of a chosen few. We must accept our responsibility for the accurate diagnosis and treatment of all health issues and concerns as part of the Australian way of life and not as an additional sideline or election gimmick.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you do not need me to tell you once again that the matter of attention deficit disorder is beyond being stamped urgent; it is now critical. We must now take immediate yet well planned action. As a nation we can no longer put the issue of ADD in the too hard basket, as we have with other issues in the past. My recommendations, I believe, are appropriate and workable. They tackle the issue head-on using pro-active strategies. By encompassing these in total we will not only achieve much for the sufferers but establish a sound blueprint for dealing with similar health issues in the future.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—It is a rare occasion in this House that the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and the member for Moreton would agree on a matter but on this occasion I absolutely agree with the member for Cowan in his motion. I come to this issue not through my political opportunities as a member but through friendship. One of my close friends has a child who suffers from a specific learning difficulty—not ADD but one of the specific learning difficulties associated with ADD in that they are classified as general learning difficulties that children have. On my desk I have piles of papers and reports from a great range of authoritative people in education who have all arrived at the same conclusions that the member for Cowan and I have—that this is a medical condition and not just a behaviour disorder. Behaviour disorders are a result of the medical condition that the children suffering from ADD and specific learning difficulties have.

PARA.TAB: There are a range of different learning difficulties that affect children that are not fully and properly recognised in the education system or properly diagnosed. These cause enormous problems for the children concerned and for their parents. The essential feature of attention deficit or hyperactivity disorder is a persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity, and impulsivity that is more frequent and severe than is typically observed in individuals at a comparable level of development. Some hyperactive or impulsive or inattentive symptoms that cause impairment must have been present before the age of seven years, although many individuals are diagnosed after the symptoms have been present for a number of years. One of the problems is that the children often are left too late before they are properly diagnosed with this problem and therefore have not received adequate attention.

Why are we concerned with this issue? Firstly, as the member for Cowan said, somewhere between five and 10 per cent of children have some specific learning difficulty and at least five per cent have attention deficit disorder. This means that five per cent of children in our schools are not able to receive an adequate education because the whole education system frustrates their everyday life and they are not able to gain from the education system what they could gain. It is important to understand that these children are not intellectually impaired. They cover the broad range of intellectual capacities that exist within our society.

Some of the brightest children in our schools suffer from attention deficit disorder or other learning difficulties and therefore their intellectual abilities are not being developed in the education system. Frustration at their inability to develop through the schooling system leads to a general frustration with society, which then has major costs on society. We are not developing these children to their full potential and therefore are not able to give them all the life opportunities they should be able to enjoy because we failed to diagnose the medical condition they had. Secondly, what has been proven through the court system is that a very high level of delinquent behaviour can be directly linked to attention deficit disorder or other specific learning difficulties.

These children take their frustrations out on society because society and the education system have failed them, so they engage in petty vandalism, in graffiti and, often, in violence because of their frustrations. They are too heavily represented in the court system. If you were able to track down all the kids going through the court system, I think you would find a great number of them have had attention deficit disorder or other learning difficulties. Also, ADD often leads to high levels of suicide or attempted suicide amongst young people because they can no longer tolerate the frustrations that their medical condition creates for them.

So it is absolutely urgent for state and federal governments to accept their responsibilities in this area and provide a much broader array of funds to the schooling system and to parents so that they can provide, firstly, the medical treatment that enables them to tackle this problem and, secondly, so that their schooling system is better provided with the skills and the resources to ensure that these children are able to receive an adequate education to fulfil the opportunities that their intellectual capacities will enable them to do. I fully support the motion, and I congratulate the member for Cowan on bringing it before the House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) on raising this subject today because it is thought that attention deficit disorder afflicts many Australian youngsters, up to five per cent of those under 18. Attention deficit disorder is also the subject of considerable controversy; and public policy, as it relates to ADD, must successfully navigate its way through these controversies if it is to be effective. There have always been difficult children but, generally, they have been treated as having behavioural problems rather than as patients. Most of the world still takes this view. England and France report one-tenth of the US rate of ADD, and in Japan the disorder has hardly been studied.

PARA.TAB: Researchers generally suspect a defect in the frontal lobes of the brain which regulate behaviour, but some psychologists question whether ADD is truly a disorder at all or merely a set of characteristics that tend to cluster together. Several studies have shown that people with ADD have depressed blood flow and lower levels of electrical activity in the frontal lobes than normal adults and children. What researchers do say with certainty is that the condition is inherited. Diagnosis is not always well handled. Many who treat ADD see recognition of the problem as a humane breakthrough but worry that the disorder, if embraced too enthusiastically, can be used to avoid taking responsibility.

In most cases, parents trying to explain away why their child is daydreaming in class, failing to complete assignments or driving everyone crazy with thoughtless behaviour stumble across a list of ADD symptoms in a book, on talk-back radio or during meetings of parents with children of similar problems, and so rush off to a doctor to get a prescription, says a Melbourne paediatrician, Dr Oberklaid. Dr Oberklaid argues for proper assessment. He says that the real problem may not be ADD at all, but something as simple as mild deafness or as serious as a psychiatric disease.

Diagnosing those who have attention deficit disorder without hyperactivity can be tricky. Such children are often described as daydreamers as they are not agitated or disruptive but, says Roseman, `They sit in front of a book for 45 minutes and nothing happens.' Many girls with ADD fit this model and are misunderstood or overlooked. Mark Stein, the director of a special ADD clinic at the University of Chicago concedes, `We need to find a more precise way of diagnosing it than just by saying that you have these symptoms.'

There are questions about the boundaries between personality and pathology, but it is agreed by researchers that when the traits are so extreme that they interfere with people's lives then the behaviour is a function of pathology. There is no doubt about the fact that lives can be affected. These young people often have few friends. Their parents may be blamed and ostracised by their neighbours, relatives and teachers for failing to have adequate influence over their children.

Parenting skills are called into question. School can be a shattering experience for these young people. Frequently reprimanded and turned out, they lose any sense of self worth and fall even further behind in their work. These children can be accident prone, but worse still are the psychological injuries that are caused. They can lie and steal and as adults will have problems with substance abuse, mostly with depressants like marijuana or alcohol. While early intervention is obviously highly desirable, researchers are still uncertain exactly what optimal intervention should be.

The best known therapy remains a stimulant drug such as ritalin. Some children have anti-depressants prescribed. Overprescription of ritalin has become a major issue in the US, but there are stories of how the lives of young people and their families have been improved and changed by use of the drug. There is consensus that, whether or not drugs are used, these disruptive young people should be taught behaviour modification, how to gain more control over their impulses and how to be better organised. This all takes considerable effort on the part of the children, parents, teachers and professionals giving assistance, with praise being an important ingredient.

It is argued that, whether ADD is a brain disorder or a personality type, the degree to which it is a handicap depends not only on the severity of the symptoms, but also on one's environment. The right job, the right school or home situation can make all the difference. All kids do not learn the same way and nor are all adults suitable for the same line of work. Unfortunately, modern society seems to have evolved into a one size fits all system. To acknowledge these problems is to acknowledge the need for changes in public policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too congratulate the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) for bringing this matter before the House as it focuses on children, who are the most undervalued group in our nation. Although I listened with interest to the previous speakers and although they have all raised some valid points in relation to the issue of attention deficit disorder, I happen to be in a minority in this debate and remain unconvinced that ADD is a medical condition.

PARA.TAB: Attention deficit disorder is not a disease. I am not attempting to argue that there is not a problem with children who suffer from what is described as ADD. But a question raised here today is whether it is a medical problem or a behavioural problem. I contend that it is most likely to be a genetic/environmental problem which flows on to behavioural problems in young children. I acknowledge that the member for Cowan mentioned that.

I believe that attention deficit disorder comes within the normal range of children's behaviour, albeit at the lower and upper limits. The issue is: where does normality stop and abnormality begin? As a teacher and a principal for some 25 years with the South Australian education department I saw at first hand children who fell into this so-called ADD group. I believe that even from birth children are able to work out parental behaviour; that is, what works and what does not. By this I mean that even a newborn baby appears to know that if he or she cries then he or she will be picked up, cuddled, fed and attended to in some form, be it changing a nappy or nurturing in some way.

Attention deficit disorder is just that; a disorder not a medical problem. Are we simply drugging children into passivity or submissiveness? Currently, Dr Florence Levy from the University of New South Wales is studying the disorder in 2,300 pairs of twins. She hopes her study will be able to separate which behaviours have a genetic basis and which may be due to environment. For example, the core problem may be that children are easily distracted and their aggressiveness may be a reaction to how parents and teachers handle them. It is generally known that attention and activity level vary across different environmental contexts and at different times during the day for most individuals, including children with attention deficit disorder.

It is my contention that all children need consistent caregivers, be they parents, grandparents or teachers. In my experience as an educator I found that in nearly every case children from homes where consistency in parenting was paramount on the whole performed a lot better than children from homes where parents were indecisive and continually changed their minds, attitudes and responses in similar situations. This also applied to the classroom. Children always responded better to teachers who were consistent and fair, and who treated them with respect. Are doctors overinterpreting the results of the test called neurometrics? The test has cost Medicare and parents large sums of money but it is unproven and may have overdiagnosed the number of children with ADD.

It is interesting to note that neurometrics testing is largely performed in New South Wales, which has 10,000 drug treated children. An important problem in assessing ADD is that evidence of pervasiveness is needed to show that inattention, impulsiveness and hyperactivity are not specific to certain situations. For example, it can be displayed in school but not at home, or only in some school and home situations.

As I briefly touched on a little earlier, a common finding on ADD is that children with this disorder tend to score below normal comparison levels on IQ and achievement tests but are frequently still within the normal range. Medication has not proven to be the answer. Some research indicates that approximately 50 per cent of children on medication improve. But the results all seem to indicate that those children not on any medication whatsoever also improve at the rate of approximately 50 per cent with behavioural control and, in some cases, food elimination diets.

These figures seem to demonstrate that approximately 50 per cent of children have no improvement even with the use of medication. Perhaps resources from state and federal governments should be directed to assisting parents and children develop a discipline system both at home and in schools. We should also ask ourselves who benefits when we come to the question of power and money. An analysis of the answer to that would prove very beneficial. Perhaps as politicians we should be a little more naturally suspicious and wary of tests costing Medicare $297 per time and $180 for a couple of times as a repeat dose, and drug costs for families of up to $50 per month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Attention deficit disorder, or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, is a condition that has always existed, but the term has only come into being over the last 15 years or so. It describes one of many symptoms, mainly in young boys. Five to 20 per cent of boys can exhibit some degree of it, and 80 to 90 per cent of all cases are in males. It is unlike other disadvantages in society, which often are visible, readily elicit sympathy from the rest of the community and encourage corrective measures to be put in place. In a sense, ADD is a hidden handicap. To that extent, it represents a potential loss to the community.

PARA.TAB: These children can go off the rails and go on to drugs, become liars and cheats and end up in gaol. They are often the brightest and potentially the most creative of all children. Leonardo da Vinci, Benjamin Franklin, Winston Churchill, Beethoven and Einstein were believed to have suffered from ADD in their early years.

The symptoms are many. One or more of these symptoms by themselves fall into the normal category. They take into account a brief attention span—hence the name—hyperactivity, distraction and restlessness. There can be a loss of concentration whereby you go into a daydreaming state. You get increased activity levels in many of these children. They exhibit impulsiveness and incoordination—they are clumsy—and they have a weak short-term memory. They are inflexible in their attitude; they are very dogmatic and they cannot adjust to changing situations. They fly into tempers, which distresses their parents. They have diminished self-esteem and peer relationship problems. They often exhibit sleep disturbances, appetite changes and speech disorders.

ADD is largely genetic. It is inherited mainly through the male parent. If one identical twin has it, there is a 90 to 100 per cent chance that the other child will have it. They think it is due to a lack of neurotransmitter fluid in the synapse between two neurones. This fluid is necessary to transmit the message from one neurone to another. If that fluid is in insufficient quantity or is destroyed in large amount by the enzymes that regulate any normal surplus in that area, you get a breakdown in the transmission of messages. This seems to peak in children of primary school age and usually, but not always, improves after they turn about 12 or 14.

There are many things to do for the treatment and management of this disease. Behavioural therapy is very necessary as it moves the child from negative to positive experiences and reinforces their good habits. Remedial teaching parental involvement is very important to identify and utilise the strengths to overcome the weaknesses the children show. Speech and language therapy is crucial, particularly at school. Occupational therapy is also important, especially with fine motor coordination such as tying shoe laces, et cetera. There is a high level of cross-dominance from left handed to right handed with eye, hand and feet, and this has to be recognised. Dietary control is important to identify noxious foodstuffs, such as chocolate and cola, and eliminate them from the diet.

Drug therapy is a very vexed question. Dexamphetamine is already approved but it does not work for some children. Ritalin is not approved yet for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, even though the advisory committee has recommended it be approved. The company that makes it has not been able to come to agreement with the government and it is costing many parents $70 to $80 every three or four weeks to treat their children, which is putting an excessive burden on those parents.

That situation is very distressing, and it is something I would urge the government to sort out as quickly as possible. The drug ritalin does have a very beneficial effect on a high number of these children, though I do stress we have to be very careful when diagnosing and administering these drugs to children because their long-term effects are not yet fully evaluated in society. (Extension of time granted)

It has often been queried as to why these drugs—dexamphetamine and ritalin, which are known as `speed'—have a hyperactivity effect on adults while they have the opposite effect on these children. This is what is known as the paradoxical effect, because it slows them down. It is thought to be due to the fact that these drugs increase the level of neurotransmitter fluid, which is deficient in these children. It may also decrease the level of uptake of the cells that put out these neurotransmitter fluids. It is also thought to improve the receptiveness of the level of the neurotransmitter that is released, and it inhibits the enzyme action on these neurotransmitter fluids.

Therefore, they lift a low level of neurotransmitter fluid to a normal level. If you give these drugs to an adult, they lift a normal level to an increased level and you get an undesirable effect. Therefore, if you are normal, you do not want to be using these drugs but if you have a low level these drugs can be very beneficial. We have to be wary of the side effects of the drugs because they can cause a loss of appetite, particularly when the drug is first taken by children. This can lead to weight loss. It can also lead to temporary insomnia. It can lead to early fatigue after the drug is first prescribed. It can lead to headaches, to dizziness, to blurring of vision in some children and also to temporary depression.

The last thing we want is doctors over-diagnosing this disease unnecessarily and using these drugs as diagnostic tools, or using them as `calmer' drugs, as they are called, in children who may have some other condition or who exhibit only a very low level of ADD. In these conditions, it would be irresponsible to be overprescribing this drug. We have already heard of instances where up to 20 to 30 per cent of children in some classes in America are on ritalin. Heaven forbid that we ever get to that state in Australia.

However, I would hope that, where the drug has a proper and beneficial therapeutic use, it would not be held back because of some reticence to use the drug. I do believe that the government should do everything it can in its negotiations with the company that makes ritalin, in particular, to get it onto the pharmaceutical lists so the parents will only have to pay something in the order of $12, $14 or $16 per prescription rather than the $70 or $80 they are paying now. If this continues to be the case, many children, particularly those from poor families, will be denied the use of this drug that they should otherwise be entitled to.

—The government is meeting this problem—to have the advantage of enterprise flexibility, that is, flexibility in any direction other than down—with a no disadvantage test. ANSWER.PARA: The prospect of going down in history as a person who consistently advocated wide ranging and substantive reforms of Australia's industrial relations system is one that fills me with pride.

—Order! The Prime Minister has the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it now the position of your government that foreign debt can rise to any level without having an impact on the interest rates paid for personal loans and mortgages by Australians?
—I saw a bit of comment in the paper today about these issues, but the table I mentioned earlier makes the point rather elegantly.
—You are not worried about it?

—With the stock of debt we have offshore we still have the seventh lowest short-term real interest rates in the industrialised world. I think that demonstrates the point. But there is another point about our debt. The opposition goes running around talking about the debt. Australia has always—when I say `always', for most of the postwar years bar maybe three or four years—run a current account deficit, mainly because we have a very large continent which will always require a lot of investment, and that investment, generally, will be more than the savings of a relatively small population of 18 million people.

PARA.TAB: Just a week ago a World Bank study said that Australians had the highest assets in the world because of the assets of the continent divided amongst 18 million people. The flip side of that is that there will always be a requirement on Australians to find more savings for the investments that can go into a continent of this size, be it in mining, agriculture, minerals processing, infrastructure or transport. We will always be requiring investment greater than our capacity to save.

Our savings declined in the 1970s and the 1980s principally from the household sector, largely because of the corrosive effect of high inflation. Double digit inflation removes the propensity of many Australians to save. The period through the 1970s to the mid-1980s of high inflation had a very corrosive impact on the propensity of Australians to save. At the same time, the public sector had bids for savings. In the year when this government was elected to office Commonwealth outlays were 30.5 per cent of GDP.

Now, on a trend basis, they are around 24 per cent to 25 per cent of GDP—they are down by about six percentage points of GDP. So, with that big call by the public sector in the days of the last coalition government and by the erosion of the propensity to save during the period of the last coalition government, this put Australia hostage to a bigger reliance on overseas savings to fund our investments.

Given the fact that we now have an open economy and a higher level of profitability which will actually underpin a higher investment performance, it really means we have needed more money for investment simply because we have had more investment than we had during the coalition years of office.

So there has been a requirement for more investment, hence more savings, yet there has been a falling away in household savings and there has been a bigger demand by the public sector. Both things this government has sought to correct with household savings through superannuation, by our measures to put a minimum of 15 per cent away for all Australians by the year 2002 and, in the public sector, by getting the budgets again back into surplus—bearing in mind that only a Labor government has ever had the Australian budget in the postwar years into surplus. We are back into surplus and we will be strongly in surplus for the balance of the 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have always made wild promises, Keating.
—The member for Hume is not required to comment.

—So the correction of the savings balance on the public sector account and also the other adjustments to which I have just referred mean that the government has put in place a long-term savings strategy to deal with the problem.

And that is why I think this campaign is going for them nowhere—nowhere!

TALK.START.PARA: —Call the election. Call the election.

—Timmy, old son, by the time the election is on, this issue will be nailed nicely into the ground. I always like to limber up on these things—a bit of limbering—I like to limber up on them. —I refer the Attorney-General to reports concerning the level of support available for young people in the legal system. I ask the Attorney-General: what is the government's response to those reports?

—About one quarter of the Australian population is aged 18 years or less. Obviously, the vast majority of those young Australians reside with their parents in Australian families. It is important that the vast balance of Australian government policy goes towards the strengthening of those families and the position of those young Australians. Indeed, I recall hearing over the weekend the minister for employment, Mr Crean, speaking about government programs in employment, education and training, which go very much to the support of young Australians. Our health policies are also directed largely to the health and welfare of those Australians and also our policies in relation to the operation of the Australian legal system.

PARA.TAB: A great deal of the laws which impact directly on young Australians rest at the state level. Nonetheless, there are important Commonwealth laws and important Commonwealth initiatives which impact directly on the position of young Australians in relation to the law. For instance, reforms which are currently before the Senate, having already passed through the House of Representatives, dealing with changes to the Family Law Act reinforce even more strongly that the position of children is to be the paramount consideration in any breakdown of marriage, that the welfare of children and parents' ongoing responsibility to their children is to be a primary concern of all those involved in that system.

Equally important—more important in my view—should be measures which prevent relationship breakdown and safeguard the position of children. That is why the government's Justice Statement has put so much focus on those areas of prevention, if you like. There has been a specific focus in the Justice Statement on young Australians. The statement supports the funding which already goes to a number of youth advocacy centres operating at the community level throughout Australia. In particular, I note that the statement supports the ongoing work of the national children's and youth law centre. This centre was under threat of closure, with its previous funding source coming to an end. The government has stepped into the breach and will allow that very valuable service to continue. In addition to funding that service, the government through the Justice Statement is also funding an additional placement in the range of community legal centres of specialist youth workers.

The government will also be working in my portfolio area in the next number of months to develop further responses in this area. The aim of this reference is to make sure that the inter-relationship between young Australians in the legal system is a responsive one, that young Australians do enjoy their full rights before the law, and that their parents are also fully equipped to deal with and protect them in relation to the law. Together with a range of other government policies, this proves the government's intention to make sure that Australian families are structured and supported in such a way that they are able to continue to progress, notwithstanding the obvious pressures of modern life.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: why does Australia have the highest prime bank interest rates in the industrialised world? —They were just under 16 per cent when the honourable gentleman left office, as I remember it. Today they are just under 11 per cent. He is the high interest rate, high inflation specialist. No-one will ever take his records.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer made the point the other day in the House that, as with rates in the banking system particularly, they respond to the demand in the economy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your memory is as good as Carmen's; selective memory.
—The member for Mackellar!

—the demand for money, the growth in the economy. The Australian economy has been growing somewhere between four and six per cent over the last couple of years and, as a consequence, Mr Speaker, there is more pressure for funds here than there is in other comparable economies. Japan has been growing at half a percentage point; western Europe has been growing at under two, at 1 1/2 or thereabouts; the United States has been growing at 2 1/2, and the Australian economy has been growing at least at twice the pace of the United States and at about three times the pace of western Europe. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. How does Australia's pension system compare with that in other countries? What effect does Australia's targeting have on the adequacy of pension payments?

—I thank the honourable member for his question because it gives me an opportunity to comment on a number of misleading reports making international comparisons of pension systems in Australia and in other countries. Such comparisons often fail to take into account the specific structural features of retirement income provision in this country, which is based essentially on three legs.

PARA.TAB: The first is a targeted public pension system delivered through the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The second leg is publicly mandated private savings through superannuation, which the government has given considerable emphasis to extending. The third leg is voluntary savings. In this country the main form that has taken is by people acquiring housing. Around 80 per cent of people going onto the old age pension own their own home outright, which is an extraordinarily high percentage by international standards; in fact, it is the highest.

There are three basic components to our retirement income system. Some have tried to compare one component of it—that is, the targeted pension system—with other systems in other countries which are based on a contributory arrangement. That is obviously an absurd comparison to make.

If you look at that component of the pension system which is directed at those in the greatest need and if you make adjustments for cost of living differences between countries, it turns out that we have one of the most generous pension systems in the world. The amount that is paid is 50 per cent higher than what is paid in Germany, 33 per cent higher than both the US and the UK, 17 per cent higher than Sweden and 12 per cent higher than France. This gives the lie to the claim that we have a peculiarly parsimonious age pension system or retirement income structure. We do not.

We have a system which is different. Unlike most developed countries, for a variety of reasons, we did not go down the route of a contributory system. When you look at the three components, there is no doubt that we have a retirement income system which is adequate in terms of providing a safety net. We have committed ourselves to maintaining it in real terms and improving it, unlike the coalition, which allowed it to erode both in real terms and as a proportion of average weekly earnings.

Importantly—the World Bank emphasised this point in a recent report on how different countries are coping with the old age crisis—we have a system which, because of its efficient targeting, will be sustainable in the long term in the context of a situation where we have a significantly ageing population. Within a few decades, we will have to deal with the situation where a significantly higher proportion of the population will be above pensionable age. On all those counts, there is no doubt that we are moving to a system which is both fiscally sustainable and provides a decent retirement income for Australian elderly people.

—I know that this is coffee shop conversation on a Saturday morning in Toorak. The honourable member is tuned right in on these things.

—They are down there wringing their hands and putting down their bags worrying about the fall in real wages in Western Sydney and the northern suburbs of Melbourne.

—Order! I warn the member for Hume!

—We have had a question of this nature before from the honourable member. Household disposable income per capita has risen by 21 per cent since 1983. It is that increase in household income plus the support which comes to Australians, particularly in the bottom deciles of income through the other transfer payments—10 per cent of the budget outlays we pay to Australian families—which go by way of additional family payment to the basic family payment. There is also the home child-care allowance, the generalised child-care rebate, fee relief and all the other elements, including Austudy.

PARA.TAB: These sorts of changes are the things which have made the difference in this country compared with some of the countries the honourable member mentions in his question—that is, in Australia, there has been a much greater level of support for those people on the bottom deciles of income.

I gave the points the American Labor secretary made recently when he said: `In the United States, we have had huge employment growth but we have had falling real incomes.' He said, `By contrast, in western Europe they have had rising real incomes but lousy rates of employment.' That is why they are still basically supporting obscurantist policies on industrial relations—not, as I said, that the profit share in the economy is not high enough. We now have a share of profits to GDP around a historic high. What do you want, something without any historic precedence? Why do you want to cut away at the incomes of working Australians? Why would you not want to see a no disadvantage test apply?

It is all a mystery to me, but it is always a mystery to me why you would support many of the policies you currently support. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. Can the minister inform the House what effect the rejection of the New Zealand case against France's nuclear testing program by the International Court of Justice will have on the protest action against the nuclear testing program? Can the minister advise the House whether any other legal avenue is available against the French decision to resume those tests?

—I thank the honourable member, the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, for his question. It is a matter of disappointment to the government that the International Court of Justice ruled against New Zealand in its attempt to revive its 1973 nuclear test case. I point out to the House that this decision was not a decision which ruled on the merits of the case. It was made entirely on procedural grounds because the 1973 case was concerned with nuclear testing by France in the atmosphere it could not apply to the kind of test which France is now conducting—that is, underground testing. It made no substantive decision on the legality of nuclear tests and therefore gives France no warrant for claiming that it is justified in legal terms to go ahead.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note that the court expressly stated that its decision about the obligation of the states to respect and protect the natural environment was without prejudice. It noted that both New Zealand and France had reiterated their obligations to that effect in the course of the proceedings.

It is true that both Australia and New Zealand acknowledged from the outset that these proceedings faced formidable procedural hurdles. As well as that, no new proceedings against France can be commenced because after the 1973 case it withdrew its recognition of the jurisdiction of the court so we could not raise any new cases. But by applying to intervene in support of the New Zealand case, during the proceedings Australia and four other Pacific countries—the Marshall Islands, the federated state of Micronesia, Samoa and the Solomon Islands—were able to demonstrate our commitment to opposing the resumption of nuclear tests in the region. We were able to put on the record our views on the important questions of international environmental responsibility which the New Zealand case raised.

Australia will, of course, continue to do whatever it can do to apply pressure on the French government to reverse its decision to resume nuclear testing. As for Australia's 1973 case, which as you would remember, Mr Speaker, was brought by the Labor government and was successful in driving the French underground, our legal advice has been that there is no real prospect of success for any attempt by Australia to re-open that case. The court's decision confirms the legal advice we have had to that effect.

To answer the second part of the honourable member's question, the government has also given careful consideration as to whether Australia could now commence new legal proceedings against France on any other basis, particularly, for example, under conventions which are aimed at the protection of the environment. Again, the clear legal advice we have had is that it is not possible to take action against France in the ICJ or before any other judicial or arbitral body without its consent.

From now on, our focus in the ICJ will be on mounting oral argument on another nuclear test issue which is forthcoming—that is, the hearing of the advisory opinions which are being sought by the WHO and the UN General Assembly on the legality of the use or threat of use of nuclear weapons. That is one of the things which will be preoccupying Senator Gareth Evans when he leaves for the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact the following changes:
1. That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

2. That The Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel, the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
3. That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
4. That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
5. That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
6. That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

7. That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
