Too little has been done so far by the Federal Government to implement the recommendations of that Report. In particular, we call attention to the following:

PETITION.PARA: financial resources have not followed the mentally ill in the shift from institutional to `community-based' care;

families are therefore increasingly left to provide so-called `community care' to relatives with mental illness, with inadequate professional support, while individuals without family carers suffer inadequate care;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to the standard of government administration and leadership and the public attitude to our democratic institutions. One can listen to the government's daily menu during question time in the House. I noted today that there were three typical questions supposedly without notice—but of course on notice—from government members to ministers. The three questions related to pensions, health and law. As I have said, this is part of the daily menu of government and part of what is really the government's administrative load.

PARA.TAB: I also notice the difference between that and the big picture: the question of what the government is doing overall, what its major policies are doing to Australia, and how those policies can enable it to carry out its administrative load. I have no doubt that, as far as the public are concerned, the government is not governing according to the expectations of the electors.

I noted the contradictions between ministers' statements and the response that they have received in the media. I read some references today in the amazing statement by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) last week concerning the non-connection—or lack of connection as he said then—between Australia's overseas debt, inflation growth and interest rates. In last week's Hansard the Treasurer said that the increases that occurred last year in interest rates had nothing whatever to do with foreign debt. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have, therefore, a level of mortgage rates which are set off official interest rates and have no connection whatever with the level of foreign debt.

I think most people on this side of the House shook their heads in amazement that the Treasurer could make such a definite statement when, of course, he is obviously wrong. The error of his pronouncement was illustrated in today's Australian under the heading `Adviser lashes Keating on debt'. The article refers to the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on this question. The commentator, Mr Alan Wood, wrote:

Drawing on work by two Reserve Bank researchers, Gregory delivers the unpalatable message that if the Government tries to push the economy along at the 3.5 to 4.0 per cent rate forecast in the Budget, it will face a falling exchange rate, rising inflation and rising foreign debt.

That is a view that is in direct contradiction to the official view now adopted by the government. There was a reference in the Australian to Mr Vince FitzGerald who, in his own article, answered the criticism of his view of the connection between the debt and economic factors within Australia. Mr FitzGerald wrote:
Government net debt to all other sectors, including amounts legally owing to its employees for past service, is well over $200 million.
He went on to say, however:
. . . Commonwealth debt accumulated over the past two decades, due to the Commonwealth consistently spending more on current consumption than it raised in revenues.
In other words, he quite clearly indicates that the Commonwealth's internal borrowing in Australia has a direct relationship to the overseas debt as we now know it.

PARA.TAB: There are further references in headlines such as `Deficit or jobs: It's our choice, says economist' and so on. This means that the government is in disarray. It could not be better illustrated than in an article in today's Australian which is headed `Innovate or Evaporate'. It refers to the industry policy for innovation of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). The article begins:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the planned cornerstones of the Keating Government's electoral recovery—its proposed innovations statements—has been savaged by the Labor Caucus as woefully inadequate, and its author, Industry Minister Peter Cook, told to go back and try again.

Clearly, the government is not governing in the accepted sense of the expectations of Australians. The roll-up of this is that the government is standing still and day by day justifies its record, instead of going out and telling Australia its plan for Australians in the future.

PARA.TAB: There is no point in the government continually saying to the opposition, `Bring out your policies.' The government has been in power for 12 years in Australia. It is Labor's record of government in Australia that I want to refer to now. I do so knowing that Australians generally have a very poor view of their politicians. There have been several polls of recent times and an article in the Bulletin which illustrate this point. An article in the Bulletin states:

SPEECH.PARA: A massive 95% of respondents—
referring to the Bulletin poll—
say that MPs should stop arguing with each other and concentrate more on running the country.
But, worse—this is according to the polls—it states:
According to voters, the quality of our federal MPs is much poorer today than two decades ago;
I do not agree with that poll. I believe that members of this parliament from both sides of this House are here with high motivations to serve Australians.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Labor in government across Australia has given a clear picture of its record in the last 12 years; that means that these disillusioned voters will make a decision for perhaps the first time in those 12 years knowing fully what they can expect from the result of that vote.

I look at Western Australia—a state government which blighted the future for years of that state with a patronage from government to selected individuals in industry and commerce, resulting in a fiasco, a loss of a great sum of money in petrochemicals and in the failed Rothwells bank.

In South Australia there was an enormous loss by South Australian standards, and by any government standards, of about $4 billion because of the defect of a Labor government's administration. In Victoria, there was a loss of similar dimensions—approximately $4 billion—through the failure of the Victorian State Bank.

Where were the regulators? Who was the chief regulator in Australia when these failures were occurring? It was, of course, the Treasurer of the federal government, now the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. He was the regulator of the financial institutions who could have and should have reined in those reckless state governments.

But, of course, the federal government was up to its ears too in the entrepreneurial spirit of the 1970s. I remember in this House the passage of an amendment to the Australian securities legislation to assist Mr Robert Holmes a Court to take over the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. It was a narrow run thing that that company was not acquired by Mr Holmes a Court, broken up into constituent parts and sold to owners around the world. If that had happened, this government in office would have been directly responsible for the bill that it passed in this House to assist a friend in the entrepreneurial area of Australian commerce and industry.

The picture is there for all Australians to see: three failed state Labor governments have been all replaced, a federal government which has run out of reform and a federal government, once we have got through the entrepreneurial activity in Australia which led directly into a recession, that has no further ideas to sustain the Australian economy. This government borrows heavily internally, affecting the overseas borrowing and reducing the initiatives that are available to any government to manipulate, for the benefit of Australia, the growth factors in this country: employment, interest rates and the value of our dollar on the world market.

These facts are clear for Australians to see. The dissatisfaction which the general public has with politicians in general will be transferred into a significant roll of the democratic wheel at the next federal election when this government will be soundly defeated. One can find the inevitability in the community and the atmospherics in the community—the forces which threw out the McMahon government will throw out the Keating government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this grievance debate I want to refer to the Working Nation program in two ways: firstly to commend and congratulate those firms, organisations and community groups that are participating in the Working Nation program and helping provide opportunities for unemployed Australians to re-enter the work force and, secondly, to encourage more businesses, local government organisations and community organisations to join the program and so further expand the range of opportunities for unemployed people to re-enter the work force.

PARA.TAB: With the Working Nation program what government is about is generating continued employment growth and seeking to involve all Australians in the economic recovery that is well under way. Where we have had growth in employment in the past, particularly back in the 1980s when the economy lifted and employment growth took place, most of that growth, most of those new jobs, went to new entrants to the work force. What we are trying to ensure through Working Nation is that those who have been unemployed are given priority in re-entering the work force. So those who have been unemployed 18 months or more are given special treatment to get them back into the work force, to give them current work experience and so enhance their chances of regaining an independent income and the dignity of having their own income.
When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) launched Working Nation on 4 May 1994 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Success depends on all Australians joining the effort to tackle unemployment—from business, trade unions and communities and all tiers of government.

So Working Nation does address all Australians. What we are saying to young Australians is: if you are inexperienced we will see that you get the training you need to get into the work force. To those who are unemployed we are saying: if you do not have the appropriate skills we will help you get those skills. To business, we are saying: we are aiming to supply you with the people and the skills that you need—people who are well trained and ready to enter or to re-enter the work force. The expenditure of public money will be on programs that will improve community amenities generally.

PARA.TAB: Under the heading of the Working Nation program there has been the introduction of a national training wage, there have been increased resources for work experience and training programs and there has been the introduction of the job compact. This is a compact between government and a person who has been unemployed 18 months or more that they will be given the opportunity to re-enter the work force, that a place will be found for them at least for six months and, one would hope, longer than that so they can rejoin the payroll and update their experience and skills, so enhancing their chances of securing long-term employment.

We have brought in new work opportunities, NWOs, and jobskills. Both of those programs are very active and are going well in my electorate. I will come to that later. One of the important aspects of Working Nation has been the introduction of case management so that the person who is seeking employment is able to deal with the same person. A manager is allocated to that unemployed person to assist and guide that person to regain employment. In the past, each time somebody went into the CES or went to make an inquiry the odds were that they would find a different person dealing with their problems. There was a lack of continuity and what came about was frustration and certainly a high degree of inefficiency.

There have been changes to Department of Social Security programs to assist people to get back into the work force and to support them whilst they are out of the work force. One might ask: how much is it all costing? The allocation over four years is $9,000 million. Of that, $2.2 billion is being spent in this financial year, 1995-96, and $2.3 billion in the following year, 1996-97. This is the largest amount of money and the strongest attack that has ever been made on unemployment in this country.
Let us look at the problems abroad. No Western economy has been able to address the question of unemployment, especially long-term unemployment, in the manner in which Australia is addressing it.

Some people here may make complaints. Some may say, `You should be doing more', but no country in the Western world is having the success in addressing the problems of the long-term unemployed that we are having. Others might say, `Well, you aren't doing enough.' Any person unemployed is one person too many unemployed. But there is a limit to how fast we can move through this program, and it is a limit that is in some ways decided by the level at which business, community groups and local government organisations are prepared to participate in the program. No other country provides a job for every person who has been unemployed for 18 months or more, and no other country in the Western world provides one-to-one case management as we in this nation are providing.

Since Working Nation began over a year ago, much progress has been made. The number of young people looking for work is down by 14 per cent; the total number of unemployed is down by 14 per cent. I do not mean that the rate is down by 14 per cent, but that the number of people who are unemployed is down by 14 per cent. The number of 15-year-old long-term unemployed people is down by more than 20 per cent. The number of 20- to 24-year-old people who have been long-term unemployed is down by over 30 per cent. In the last financial year over 400,000 unemployed persons entered case management. Of those, 110,000 obtained work, many in unsubsidised employment.

Overall, Working Nation is working. It is stimulating growth, it is raising the level of domestic savings, it is improving infrastructure and, most importantly of all, it is giving back to hundreds of thousands of Australians the dignity, independence and freedom that comes with being in employment, that comes with having a job and that comes with earning one's own income.

In my own electorate, the Working Nation programs have been very successful for the community, for the long-term unemployed and for local businesses, firms and community organisations. In the Toukley area, the Chamber of Commerce, in association with the CES, has developed a main street program. It is an excellent program, aimed at beautifying the main street and at providing skills in paving, planning and painting for the long-term unemployed. It is also aimed at strengthening that old type of local shopping centre, the main street, for people who have some difficulty coping with the big shopping centres. Here we have a wonderful combination of providing opportunities for unemployed persons to regain skills, to get them back into the work force, and also enhancing the environment of the local shopping centre, giving it and its business people a better chance of coping with the pressure that comes from the big shopping centres. It is helping to stimulate local business, and it will help put pride back into Toukley as a shopping area.

A little to the north, right on the coastline, on Birdie Beach there is a dune stabilisation program going on as a new work opportunity program. Under that project, the sand dunes are being shaped and re-stabilised, native vegetation is being preserved and the planting of trees is taking place. The dunes are being fenced, and the building of those fences is part of the program. Better community access and better national park qualities are being provided in that coastal area.

Moving to the northern part of my electorate, to the Lake Macquarie City Council area, a bicycle track is being built virtually right around the northern half of Lake Macquarie, running from Speers Point all the way around to Blacksmiths in the south. Last Friday morning we opened stage one of that project. Ten of 11 people there had been long-term unemployed, and they graduated with certificates. One could only be proud of the quality of work that they had completed on this cyclepath. One man I met there had been unemployed for four years, and one could see the difference it made for him to be back at work, even if it had been for only six months. For him to have a pay envelope for six months, to update his skills and to get his dignity and independence back, made it well worth doing.

Employment and training skills were provided for those people; the community has gained an excellent cyclepath; the participants have gained pathway construction and measuring skills, first aid skills, traffic control procedure skills and personal development. They have been provided with current experience, and we have enhanced their opportunities and prospects of gaining employment. So, overall, Working Nation is producing results in the electorate of Shortland. We want to see more participation from more business people and more community groups. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that home owners in the Geelong region know more about economics than the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other so-called experts do. While the Prime Minister is saying that things `are as good as they get', the World Bank is telling Australians they are the wealthiest people in the word. However, home owners in Geelong could be forgiven for not feeling particularly wealthy in the last few years. The seat of Corangamite has one of the highest proportions of home ownership in Australia: 77 per cent of dwellings are owned by the occupier, compared with the national average of 67 per cent. There is concern amongst these home owners that, while mortgage rates have risen in the last 12 months, the value of their homes has hardly risen at all.

PARA.TAB: The recent World Bank study which placed Australia at the top of the international wealth table is based on the value of unrealised assets, which are in the ground or exist in theory only. Much of that wealth is beneath Mount Isa or Olympic Dam, and is of no tangible benefit to individual Australians. Some of it is beneath North Ranger or in the south-east forests, which government laws prevent any Australians from realising. As anyone struggling with a family budget could tell you, these theoretical assets in the ground will not pay for the mortgage, food, gas or electricity. They know that their wealth can be judged only by real assets. The family home is the most obvious tangible piece of wealth for most Australians.

Clearly, the World Bank believes that the typical Australian lives in a cave of jewels, but the reality is that most Australians are not seeing their most fundamental asset rise in value. Owning the family home is the great Australian dream, something Australians have always strived to pay off and own outright after a lifetime of hard work.

Residents in Belmont, Highton, Grovedale and the Bellarine Peninsula have been paying more and more on that investment in monthly mortgage repayments in the last 12 months, while the value of this asset has remained static. They find it hard to believe the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Willis), who say that high mortgage rates in Australia have nothing to do with the $180 billion net foreign debt problem. If that is the case, why then are Australian home owners faced with higher mortgage rates than those in America, Britain, New Zealand, Canada, Germany, France and Japan? Even Dr Vince FitzGerald, who was the government's own adviser on national savings, is reported in this morning's Australian to have refuted this claim. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The level of our foreign debt, our current account deficit and the financial behaviour of domestic sectors contributing to it—especially government—are in turn key factors in the foreign lenders' calculus about the quality of Australian debt. The resulting risk premium they demand is priced into the whole structure of Australian interest rates.

Dr FitzGerald, an authority on national savings policy and the government's own savings expert, refutes the Treasurer's claim that foreign debt has nothing to do with interest rates in Australia. Under the current Labor government, net foreign debt has risen from $23 billion in 1983 to the current $180 billion. This year, Australia's record $27 billion current account deficit will simply add to this figure. This has put pressure on interest rates. Since August last year the Reserve Bank has raised official interest rates three times by a combined total of 2.75 per cent. This has fed through to housing interest rates, meaning home buyers in the Geelong area will pay more each month.

PARA.TAB: For example, at the National Australia Bank in High Street in Belmont, the flexible home rate now stands at 10.55 per cent with the alternative rate fixed at 7.9 per cent for one year or 8.95 for two years. At the ANZ Bank in Belmont, the variable rate is 10.5 per cent with fixed rates ranging from 8.95 for one year up to 9.9 for five years. However, while home buyers in Geelong have faced rising home loan rates, the value of their investment has not kept pace with inflation over the last three or four years. According to the Valuer-General, in Geelong in 1990 the median house prices in the city of South Barwon, incorporating Belmont, Highton and Grovedale, was $113,000. By 1992, the median price had fallen to $106,000. Similarly, in the Shire of Bellarine, including areas of Port Arlington and the new housing developments in Drysdale and Clifton Springs, the 1990 median price was $103,000. By 1992, it had fallen to $97,000.

Following the amalgamation of local governments in Victoria, the Valuer-General's figures are available only for the City of Greater Geelong as a whole. However, those figures show that right across the Geelong region the median house price remained stagnant at $94,500 between 1993 and 1994. Over the same period local house prices either fell or remained stagnant. The consumer price index rose by four per cent.

So while home owners are giving more and more of their pay packets to pay off their homes, their house values have not even kept pace with inflation. We are now faced with the very real prospect of negative equity where home owners owe more on their homes than the house is worth. This negative equity problem has been particularly acute in Britain where an estimated five per cent of houses are worth less than the combined mortgage repayment bill on them.

In the UK several families and young couples have sold their houses only to find that the sale price will not cover the outstanding debt to the bank on the property. The root of the problem in the UK has been the twin causes of rising interest rates and stagnant house prices. The result has been a series of stunning by-election defeats for the ruling British Conservative Party. Although this situation is yet to become widespread in Australia, it is something which could happen soon given the current conditions. The Australian Financial Review two months ago ran a story on the prospect of negative equity sweeping through parts of Australian suburbia. This is the situation in Geelong and the Bellarine Peninsula. Home rates have risen, house prices are stagnant, and young couples have the majority of their loan still to repay.

The situation is worsened because many home buyers start off at a lower interest rate fixed for a year or even up to five years. This makes sense for those who have a number of up-front costs such as furniture and other things associated with starting out in a new home in a new area. However, by the end of the period in which the concessional fixed rate applies, the home owners have paid off very little of the principal of their loan. They will have paid off some interest on their loan but the amount of debt they owe is often as high or higher after the initial period. They will face the prospect of higher home loan rates which could go even higher if the current account deficit and foreign debt continue to spiral out of control.

Home owners in Belmont, Highton, Grovedale and the townships of the Bellarine Peninsula can be forgiven for thinking that they are not as wealthy as the World Bank believes them to be. They should also take issue with the Prime Minister's notion that things `are as good as they get'. They might also wonder why they pay so much more than home owners in most other Western nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to discuss a recent visit I made to Lebanon around the time of the opening of the Australian Embassy in Beirut. Unlike some of my colleagues on both sides of the House I am not a prolific overseas traveller. In fact, it was my first trip out of the country at the ripe old age of 35 and after some 2 1/2 years in this place. I went to Lebanon with a number of other members of parliament, both state and federal and from Victoria and New South Wales, including from this place the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) and Senator Short, and at the invitation of the International Council of Lebanese Migrants in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank the council and its members, in particular its president, Ghassan Karaki, and its secretary, Mr Karl Saleh, for the assistance they gave on the trip. I would also like to thank the Lebanese government and Middle East Airlines for the assistance they gave in getting us to Lebanon and in assisting us in our travels around that troubled country.

As I said earlier, we were there for the opening of the Australian Embassy in Beirut. The Lebanese government had arranged for a week called Lebanon-Australia week to occur at that time. Honourable members may not be aware that Lebanon, as a country, has quite a small population—around 3 1/2 million people. But there may be as many as eight million to 10 million people of Lebanese descent living outside Lebanon. Although Australia is not the major place of residence for Lebanese who have emigrated, we are a major location for Lebanese migrants.

Lebanon-Australia week was designed to help foster good relations between our two countries and to help improve the understanding of the circumstances of Lebanon. It was a great success. Lebanon is a very small country geographically and a very interesting country in terms of its actual strategic position in the Middle East. It is an area that has gone through a severe civil war. Some 17 years of civil war occurred there. The fighting was widespread and quite vicious. It is now just a couple of years since that war officially ended.

One thing that I was particularly impressed by upon my arrival and travels in Lebanon is the relative safety that now exists within Lebanon. Sporadic acts of violence still occur, as they occur in all countries of the world, but members of the delegation were able to travel around at all times of the day or night feeling safe and were free to travel where they wished to go.

Another thing I was impressed by was the friendliness of the people. The Lebanese people were extremely friendly to the members of the delegation. We were treated extremely well throughout our time there. The development that is occurring in Lebanon also deserves comment. After so many years of war, the fact is that most of the basic infrastructure of the country has been destroyed. There was widespread devastation, particularly in central Beirut, which had to be acted upon by the Lebanese government and people.

They have embarked on an impressive program of development in order to correct those difficulties. We were able to tour the sites of some of the development, particularly in the central area of Beirut, undertaken through a consortium entitled Solidaire, which is looking to rebuild central Beirut. An interesting aside is that, when they were removing the remains of some of the devastation they found significant Venetian ruins under the main streets. They are now endeavouring to rehabilitate those ruins into a major tourist attraction as a result of what they have found.

Major development is occurring. Another comment about Lebanon concerns its traffic problems. As I said, Lebanon has a population of around 3 1/2 million people but over 1.25 million cars. Travelling around by car is seen in the current circumstances to be a sign of freedom. The fact is that you do not tend to travel very far very fast, because the traffic problems are quite horrific. But new works are going on into roads, electricity and telecommunications. The work is quite significant and important.

It brings me to the question of the potential of Lebanon as a country. Lebanon was known in the past before the civil war as the Switzerland of the Middle East. It was the commercial hub of the Middle East. Over 50 banks had their regional headquarters for the Middle East in Beirut. It was very much the commercial capital of the Middle East. Post war, attempts are being made to get that back on track. I wish the Lebanese people and the Lebanese government well in trying to deliver that. They have a major task ahead of them. Certainly on the evidence we saw while we were there, they are well on the way to rehabilitating the capital into a major commercial centre.

The history of that area is a history of great trouble. It is also a history of great accomplishment. In our time in Lebanon, we toured a number of historical areas in Baalbek and the Bekaa Valley. We viewed Roman ruins and Venetian ruins throughout the country. We certainly got a sense that many had travelled there before us. The ability of the people to rehabilitate themselves over time after the struggles they have seen historically is quite significant.

This brings me to another issue, which is something I brought back from the trip. It relates to the question of, in media terms, the stereotyping of Arabic people through the media. It is a problem that many in this House suffer. We get stereotyped for our behaviour. It is often unjust, but sometimes just. But the fact is that it does occur.

Any fair-minded observer, when examining both electronic and printed media reports in recent years, would certainly develop a very different view of the people of Arabic descent from those of us who deal with them. It has often been said to me when I have said I was going to Beirut that I should be careful and duck. I have been asked whether I am sure it is a wise thing to do. Others say things to the effect that there are a lot of terrorists there. Although, as I said earlier, there are problems in that part of the world, the fact is that the Arabic people we met there were very much cosmopolitan and modern in their outlook and ways. They were not riding camels and all wearing headdresses. We were not in situations, which you would see from the media, where there was a bomb behind every doorway or behind every cupboard.

On the weekend, I went to a seminar run by the South Eastern Arabic Community Association and the Australian Arabic Council, which is looking at the very issue of the stereotyping of Arabic peoples in the media. They raised some very pertinent examples of this occurring in the past. Members would remember the Oklahama bombing, which occurred not so long ago, and the initial stories that came out in the media at that time around the question of who may have been responsible. I know that the Melbourne Age, for example, did run in its stories—it was not alone—comments that the attack bore all the hallmarks of Middle East terrorism. Certainly a terrorist was one of the key prime suspects early on, but, when you went to the detail, there was no basis in fact for these allegations. As we all now know, it appears to have been done by an ex-marine all American boy. The matter is still before the courts.

Another example that is closer to home is the Russell Street bombing that occurred in Melbourne some time ago. At the time of the attack, the Age ran a story mentioning an Arab looking person being seen at the scene of the crime. Again, circumstances showed that it had nothing to do with anyone of Arabic descent. It had nothing to do with the Middle East or, for that matter, any organised group of terrorists.

The fact I would like to impress upon the House is that, as we all know, not all Arabs are Muslims. There are Christians and many different religious denominations in Arabic communities. Not all Arabs are Muslims, not all Muslims are fundamentalists and not all fundamentalists are terrorists. That is a fact. The circumstances are clear for people to see once we get past the initial media reports. That is something that people need to keep in mind when they read them. It is fair to say that it is a form of persecution which occurs against the Arabic community through the mainstream media in terms of perceptions.

I would like to thank a range of people associated with the trip. I mentioned before Ghasssan Karaki and Karl Saleh. There is also Hussein Al-Hage and Hayssam Joumaa, who is the director general of the Department of the Emigrants. The others include Ghassan Nasser, Eddie Abdullah and Nabil Seif. I am running out of time and I cannot go through the rest of the names. All those involved can be assured that they have my thanks and the thanks of other members of the parliamentary delegation who were there in an unofficial capacity for the work they did in ensuring that the trip was a success. There were problems. There will always be problems in organising a group and an itinerary of the size that they did. All in all, it was a great success.

—Today I want to talk about something that is relevant to my electorate: petrol prices. Regional Australians seem to suffer more than the rest of Australia over prices generally and petrol prices in particular. Mysterious extra costs seem to appear under the heading of freight charges—on everything from the local bowser to the corner store.

PARA.TAB: People in Cairns are quite justified in being flummoxed at the inexplicable and large differences between petrol prices in Cairns and Brisbane. If you travel outside Cairns, you will see that for some reason petrol prices are cheaper in places like Mossman, Port Douglas and Babinda than they are in Cairns. That is very hard to understand.

The Prices Surveillance Authority does not include freight charges in its setting of the wholesale price in places like Cairns because it has a sea port. There are no freight charges. Weipa has a similar problem. Prices are much higher there than in Cairns, even though the tanker stops at Weipa first before travelling to other centres.

The difference between Cairns and Brisbane is volume. There are fewer petrol stations in Brisbane for the number of users than there are in Cairns. Consequently, individual Brisbane retailers will pump a greater volume of petrol and can carry price cuts. Brisbane also has a very competitive market. As a retailer, you do not survive long in a place like Brisbane unless you run a very efficient business and are prepared to enter the local pricing wars.

In this type of atmosphere the large oil companies will support their retailers and the market by discounting and keeping their prices low. They do not have another option in the larger cities and do not have the competitive incentive in regional areas. Brisbane also has independent retailers that keep the major oil company run stations on their toes in terms of prices. In such a competitive market it is difficult for collusion between companies to occur on the whole.

In Cairns there have been reports of collusion between petrol stations for price setting, which is illegal. This is unfortunately difficult to prove. I would ask any member of the public who has information on collusion and can provide evidence and statutory declarations to please provide that information to me so I can turn it over to the Prices Surveillance Authority.

The large oil companies are unfortunately not willing to cut their costs in places like Cairns. They do not see any reason to. Retailers will set their prices as high as they can in these situations. They say that their margins are so small that they have to charge the maximum price the market will bear. There is no doubt that they do have a case. There has been considerable pressure put on petrol retailers in recent years. It is true to say that they have faced higher overheads and lesser margins. Although this may be true, I am sure that there are some retailers in Cairns who would not survive the competitive markets in the bigger cities because they are not running as efficiently as they perhaps could.

What can we do about prices in regional areas like Cairns? It is simply not fair and equitable to say to those who live in regional Australia that this is one of the consequences of living far away from the capital cities. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Ms Crawford), who is at the table, is responsible for the northern social justice strategy. A very important principle of that strategy is that people who live in remote areas should, if at all possible, have the same benefits as those people who live in the larger capital cities.

I have kept the Prices Surveillance Authority apprised of the situation throughout Leichhardt, particularly in Cairns and Weipa. The authority's view is that there is little scope for them to become involved in the issue. Their position is that they have no control over the retail price and the wholesale price is worked out using overseas averages. It is set quite fairly and gives retailers room to discount, but the problem is that discounting is not happening in Cairns.

The Prices Surveillance Authority can become involved where there is collusion between organisations on what price is set. Anecdotally, there is no doubt that collusion between petrol stations over the setting of prices is happening in some places in Cairns. However, getting hard evidence on this is difficult and anecdotal evidence is not good enough.

For example, my office recently had a call from a gentleman who spoke to someone behind a petrol station counter. He mentioned to the attendant that the price down the road was cheaper and the attendant remarked that this should not happen because the stations had an agreement. My office has tried to get a statutory declaration from the person outlining the full details, but so far has been unsuccessful.

Understandably people are reluctant to do what is seen as dobbing in a fellow member of the local community and innocent bystander, such as the station attendant. Unfortunately, the Prices Surveillance Authority cannot do its job without solid evidence. People with any evidence of collusion should contact the PSA or my office with that information. I am sure that would apply for other members in other regional centres. Another view often put is that there appears to be a lack of competition in Cairns simply because there are too many petrol stations for the market. I am not sure whether that is true but that is certainly a view that has been put.

It is interesting that in Mildura a successful scheme was set up to introduce competition into the market. The local RACV, with the help of the local paper, published daily the three cheapest petrol stations in town in a small box on the front page. This of course drew a lot of interest from the locals. People began buying the paper for the prices alone and were willing to switch their allegiances from station to station even for a small price difference. After a while, queues actually began to form at stations that had cheaper petrol. What began to happen was that there was a change in volume output of the stations pricing their petrol cheaper so they were able to carry the initial price drop and sustain further discounting.

The local paper had been publishing this price list consistently every day for a month when the petrol stations put up a concerted fight to stop the publication of prices. The stations were understandably worried but the paper continued this campaign for another month. After this time there was a permanent change in the market. Not only had competition been introduced and the opportunity for informal collusion broken but an independent station entered the market creating further competitive pressure. The oil companies were no longer able to be complacent about their pricing policies in regional Australia, and neither were the local operators.

I would like to do something similar in Cairns. There are some drawbacks. I would need the assistance of the local media. Prices would have to be listed daily for the idea to work. It will create quite a workload so I will also approach the RACQ for assistance. They have been publishing some petrol prices in their magazine, but it does not come out often enough to encourage a price drop.

The oil companies have to take a lion's share of the responsibility for this situation. I believe the oil companies need to be shaken out of their complacency in Cairns, and this may only happen if the market in Cairns becomes more competitive and an independent moves in. Creating competition can be quite a hard game, particularly in regional centres such as Cairns. It certainly does not happen by itself, but creating the right prod is also difficult. Oil companies have to play a part. They have to—to use a colloquialism—give those petrol operators who are operating efficiently a fair go. Hopefully, if resources allow, the regular publication, either through the paper or on radio, will give the impetus some retailers and their suppliers need to consider the margins again.

My constituents know that they will perhaps never get to the situation where they will pay the same prices as people in Brisbane pay. They want to be assured that the system is fair and equitable. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words in the time I have available on behalf of a constituent of mine, Mr Errol Holmes of Mermaid Waters. Mr Holmes is a marine engineer who was a member of the crew of the oil rig tender Lady Kathleen. On 21 July 1991, the Lady Kathleen was involved in an operation to prevent an oil tanker, Kirki, bound for Kwinana from the Arabian Gulf, from running aground on the Western Australian coast.

PARA.TAB: I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker Rocher, being a Western Australian, would have been aware of this event and the great service the crew of that boat provided not only to the people of Western Australia but also to the people of Australia. In fact, it was generally agreed that the action taken by Mr Holmes and his colleagues aboard the Lady Kathleen was directly responsible for preventing an environmental disaster occurring on the Western Australian coast which would also, incidentally, have severely affected Australia's cray fishing industry. Mr Holmes and his colleagues aboard the ship—there were 12 involved—received salvage awards for their efforts. My constituent received a gross award of $23,381 for the part he played in that rescue mission.

Honourable members will be aware, if they have followed this issue in the press, that the Australian Taxation Office held that these rewards or amounts were assessable income under section 26(e) of the legislation. I am aware that Mr Holmes—although I am not sure how far his colleagues took it—was successful in having this ruling overturned at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but that he subsequently lost an appeal by the Commissioner of Taxation in the Federal Court.

Mr Holmes and his 12 colleagues aboard the Lady Kathleen received a considerable amount of recognition for the action that they took that day. Part of that recognition was a citation for bravery by the Governor-General for the part that they played in the rescue mission. The group citation for bravery—a copy of which I have before me—says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ship's company of "Lady Kathleen" maintained a calm and purposeful dedication to the operation and performed their dangerous tasks with courage and enterprise.
It seems to me that, in effect, these people have now been treated very poorly by the Australian government.

PARA.TAB: I accept that Mr Holmes has certainly gone through the due process of the law, but it is now up to the Australian government to take action to make sure that the bravery these men exhibited is properly recognised. What the government is doing by failing to act to correct the situation is entirely penny pinching. When you compare the amount of tax that these people have been forced to pay with the millions and millions of dollars that they have saved Australian taxpayers, in part, and certainly Australian industry, it is penny pinching in the extreme.

The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was the Premier of Western Australia at the time that this incident occurred. She may not remember it, but if she were here I could remind her that she was very happy at the time to host a reception for the crew of the Lady Kathleen. There was a large number of people there. She was there to get patted on the back and to receive the accolades. But where has she been, as the member for Fremantle—where most of the crew of the Lady Kathleen at the time now reside? The answer I am informed is that she has been almost invisible in coming forward to help and assist in having the law rectified to overcome this problem. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), another Western Australian member, appeared on the Ray Martin show and told Mr Holmes and his colleagues to go to the AAT. They did and they won. They have since lost in the Federal Court, but Mr Gear has now apparently declined to appear again on the Ray Martin show and has had nothing further to say.

I have had a close look at the circumstances that existed at the time, and I believe there are certainly some extenuating ones which need to be taken into account. As the court has made a final determination on this matter, the government now has an opportunity to step in and rectify the situation in the favour of Mr Holmes and his colleagues. I observe, as I did earlier, that the amount of taxation involved is very small compared with the amount of money that the Commonwealth has saved as a result of these men's actions.

It is also important to point out that the crew involved had no knowledge of any salvage agreement having been signed between P&O and United Salvage. A technical question formed part of the final determination in the court—that was, under what circumstances they were acting. They did not attempt the rescue mission on the basis that they would receive a reward. I believe they were motivated purely by desire to prevent an environmental disaster. In any case, it is quite clear that the actions of those involved were carried out quite voluntarily. When you read the citation, when you hear first-hand accounts of what happened that day off the coast of Western Australia, those involved certainly risked their lives in the rescue attempt.

On behalf of Mr Holmes, I have written to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and have asked him to look at this matter. I hope that he will be motivated by the case that I put on behalf of my constituent and his colleagues to change the law—if that is what is required—to ensure these men receive the full reward to which they are entitled for the actions they took back in 1991.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion by Mr Sciacca:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Easson Mrs M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak to the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. This bill contains amendments necessary to implement some elements of the budget package for the veterans' affairs portfolio. Complementary to a comprehensive program of events commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, this budget package responds to the health and housing needs of the ageing veteran community.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends two acts administered by the veterans' affairs portfolio—namely, the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. For the most part, the amendments give legislative effect to the 1995-96 budget announcements. The major announcements were to extend defence service homes eligibility to full-time members of certain Second World War women's services; to allow the assignment of defence service homes eligibility to providers of retirement villages and granny flat accommodation; to set a minimum age requirement for the partner service pension; to extend income support supplement to war widows and widowers with pensioner partners; and to extend treatment eligibility for veterans suffering post-traumatic stress disorder.

As there is no central theme to the bill, I would like to provide a brief background on each of the major amendments. The main amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 are as follows. Housing assistance has been available under the provisions of the act to certain men and women who have served Australia since 1918. As at June 1994, there were 107,124 persons in receipt of defence service homes assistance. Assistance includes housing loan interest subsidies, comprehensive home owner insurance cover and home contents insurance. The maximum loan available is $25,000, repayable over 25 years. Under an arrangement between the Commonwealth and Westpac Banking Corporation, the Commonwealth subsidises Westpac for low interest loans that it gives to eligible persons.

The main effect of this amendment is to extend defence service homes eligibility for women who during the Second World War were members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service or the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force; a member of the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, other than a member of the Australian Imperial Force; or a full-time paid member of the Voluntary Aid Detachment.

As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) said in his speech, for 50 years now former members of the World War II women's services who did not actually serve overseas during war time have been excluded from home services benefits, in contrast with many of the male volunteers. This initiative redresses that situation and recognises the major contribution to the war effort made by thousands of female volunteers who joined the services on the same basis as their male counterparts.

Furthermore, a conciliation conference was held before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission as a result of a complaint from a World War II ex-servicewoman representative. The parties agreed that the present position is an issue of indirect discrimination and should be resolved. This proposal redresses that situation and recognises the major contribution to the war effort made by thousands of female volunteers who served the services during World War II.

The majority of the proposed amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 deal with the assignment of the DSH eligibility to provide retirement village accommodation and granny flat accommodation. The key amendments proposed give the secretary to the department power to give permission to eligible persons to give their DSH eligibility to another person. Permission which takes the form of the issue of a certificate of assignment will be given only where certain conditions are met.

Schedule 1 extends the proposed amendment right to widows and widowers. It also extends the proposed assignment right to loans for essential repairs. The rationale behind the amendment is that, as the veteran population ages, their housing needs change and retirement village or granny flat accommodation are appropriate for many who have difficulty living alone independently.

These arrangements will increase appropriate housing options and assist elderly clients to remain independently housed while encouraging them to move to accommodation more appropriate to their needs. As veterans age, existing accommodation may become inappropriate, and where this occurs, and particularly where social isolation is also a factor, there is often increased demand for nursing and caring services that might be more effectively met in terms of cost and health outcomes in more appropriate accommodation.

The main amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 are as follows. Firstly, there is an extension of pension eligibility to persons who performed continuous full-time service in Japan between 28 April 1952 and 19 April 1956. The government's intention with this amendment is to make eligible for a pension persons who were allotted for duty in Korea during the Korean war but who served only in Japan.

Secondly, there will be a minimum age for partner service pension. The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 allows a partner of a veteran to receive a partner service pension where they are married to or in a marriage-like relationship with a veteran receiving an age or invalidity service pension. The main effect is to provide that a person is not eligible for partner service pension unless they have reached 50 years of age or have a dependent child when they make a claim for the pension. This exclusion will not apply in two circumstances, namely, to a claim made before 1 October 1995 by a person eligible for a partner service pension or to a claim by a person determined by the Repatriation Commission before 1 October 1995 to be eligible for a partner service pension.

The rationale given for the proposed extension is that it is generally accepted that people under 50 years of age should not be expected or encouraged to retire. Payment of partner service pension to younger partners does not encourage those people to seek work in their own right, and for many it is irrelevant as most partners today tend to be in the work force. Future non-veteran partners under 50 who are not looking after a dependent child or severely handicapped veteran and are unable to obtain work may be eligible for partner allowance, sickness allowance or disability support pension from the Department of Social Security.

The next amendment is the extension of eligibility for partner service pension to certain non-veterans and widows and widowers. Eligibility for partner service pension will apply to those persons who are a member of a couple, whose partner is a veteran and who qualify for an age pension under the Social Security Act or who are a widow or widower of a veteran who has rendered qualifying service and who qualify for an age pension under the Social Security Act.

Currently a partner of a veteran cannot apply for a partner service pension unless the veteran is receiving a service pension. Therefore, a partner who is of pension age and married to a veteran below pension age has to apply for a DSS pension and then transfer to a service pension later when the veteran becomes eligible. This initiative enables the Department of Veterans' Affairs to support a veteran's dependants even though the veteran does not receive a service pension or did not receive a service pension prior to his or her death. In addition, partners, widows and widowers may be entitled to receive a greater amount of pension than they would be entitled to from DSS because the DVA does not assess disability pension as income.

Fourthly, there is extension of income support supplement to war widows and widowers with pensioner partners. Basically, income support supplement is a payment in lieu of a social security payment, and to qualify a person must be a war widow or widower, an Australian resident and have reached retiring age, have a dependent child or be permanently incapacitated for work.

This amendment extends eligibility for income support to war widows and widowers who have a partner getting a pension. The rationale for the extension of income support supplement is that the original intention of the income support supplement was to give all war widows and widowers receiving a social security income support pension the option of receiving their income support payment under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. However, not all social security pensioners fall within the existing eligibility criteria for the income support supplement. War widow and widower spouses of disability support pensioners and age pensioners are excluded. These amendments rectify this oversight. On equity grounds, war widow and widower spouses of service pensioners are also given eligibility for the supplement.

The final amendment is extension of treatment eligibility for veterans suffering post-traumatic stress disorder. Basically, to be eligible for treatment there has to be a determination in force providing that an injury suffered by a veteran is a war caused injury or that a disease contracted by a veteran is a war caused disease. Entitlement to treatment commences from the date the pension or increased pension is granted to a veteran for the injury or disease or, if the injury or disease is insufficient to grant eligibility for a pension or pension increase, the date the pension or pension increase would have been granted if the injury or disease was sufficient.

The essential features of post-traumatic stress disorder include rage, feelings of betrayal and guilt over having survived, confusion and memory problems, apathy, depression, anxiety, obsessive memories of combat experience, nightmares, insomnia, irritability and psychosomatic manifestations such as headaches, dizziness, stomach complaints, startle reactions, fear of losing control, panic attacks, emotional numbing and frequent denials of any problems.

Last year the government initiated major extensions of treatment and support services for veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder around Australia. Many veterans have directly benefited from specialised in-patient services.

This proposal will assure the provision of appropriate early treatment to veterans for psychiatric problems brought on by post-traumatic stress disorder. Such early intervention in post-traumatic stress disorder cases greatly increases the likelihood of successful treatment outcome.

Whilst talking on the topic of veterans' affairs I thought it might be appropriate to take a moment to mention the importance of the Australia Remembers year and the way in which this has impacted upon my electorate of Lowe. `Australia Remembers 1945-1995' is the title of a year of commemorations which seeks to honour those Australian service men and women who died both during the war and in the intervening years, to thank those remaining service men and women for their efforts, to appreciate the sorrows and the difficulties of those who lost a loved one and to acknowledge the role played by those who worked on the home front in Australia during the war years.

I know that in my electorate of Lowe the Australia Remembers committee has played a key role in putting together and orchestrating a great program of events for the people of my area. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my fellow Australia Remembers committee members for their fine effort. The committee consists of Mr John Lutman, the chairman; Mr John Murray MP; Mr Paul Zammit MP; Stephen Lesley; Alan Kinkade; Debbie Picone; Maurie Goldberg; Jack Hayes; Ross Brown; Bernard Falk; Frank Hayes; Karen Meadth; Ben Woolden; Ron Peak; and Russ Kenny.

I would also like to mention the funding which was allocated by the Australia Remembers program to the following: World War II Veterans' Association launch; Concord Repatriation Hospital ball; Concord RSL fundraising ball; book of prose, poetry and performance program organised by Ms Joy Dempsey; Strathfield Municipal Council historical program; Burwood Oral Historical Group; Tarakan Memorial; Australia Remembers badges; Drummoyne RSL memorial refurbishment; school essay competitions; and Massey Park Ex-serviceman's Club.

I take this opportunity to especially mention an excellent book by Ms Olwyn Green of Drummoyne entitled The Name's Still Charlie. This is a book about her husband. It has been a highly acclaimed book. I would highly recommend it to anyone who would like to relive those years; it certainly brings those war years alive.

I want to refer in particular to the amounts given to the Concord Repatriation Hospital ball and also to the Concord RSL fundraising ball. The profits from those two balls went to the Anzac Health and Medical Research Foundation. I am very pleased to say that a grant has been given for a research institute in my electorate. I will just read part of this article:

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Con Sciacca, visited the Electorate recently to launch the capital appeal for the ANZAC Health & Medical Research Foundation to be based at Concord Repatriation General Hospital.

The Federal Government will contribute $3 million over the next three years on a matching dollar for dollar basis with the State Government in order to build a state of the art Research Institute to carry out the work of the Foundation.

The Institute will be dedicated to the study of the disorders of lifestyle and ageing, with an important aspect of its work being to undertake studies to improve health care delivery and outcomes to the veterans community.
In the Foundation, we have a lasting memorial to the Anzac tradition here in the Electorate—

SPEECH.PARA: of Lowe—
which will perpetrate the Australia Remembers Program and provide a tangible commitment to improving the community's health standards for the future.

PARA.TAB: The Foundation will also have many benefits for Concord Hospital. Over the years, as a Repatriation Hospital, Concord Hospital's focus has been on service provision to the veteran community.

Unlike other major teaching hospitals Concord has not had a Research Institute. While valuable research has occurred at Concord in the past the strategic advantages of the hospital hosting a stand alone Research Centre are enormous.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to make a few reflections on VP Day. I had the pleasure of attending a memorial service at Concord Hospital and later went to the wards and distributed the Australia Remembers certificates of appreciation. It stands out in my mind as one of the most moving days in public office. There were people who said to me that, for the first time in 50 years, they had actually begun to cry. It certainly was an opportunity for people to let out emotions that they had hitherto kept inside. When you asked where they served, the stories came tumbling out. You realise that these were ordinary Australians caught up in extraordinary times. I guess it is always ordinary Australians who are there to fight wars.

PARA.TAB: At the launching of a school kit at MLC we had the recollection of the diggers. One of them was talking about the night before they went into battle and saying that they were praying and that they were scared. As he described it, they were scared as hell that when the moment came they would not let their mates down.

One of the beautiful things that I have been involved with on the Lowe Electorate Australia Remembers Committee has been the essay competitions where we have seen young people, who really did not have experiences of this war, all of a sudden building bridges with an older generation and asking people for the stories of what their experiences were like. They certainly appreciated that the freedom that they now have is a result of the sacrifice that other people made. It is certainly very important to building those bridges between our generations.

Those veterans did not let us down. I often wonder, as a young person of my generation, whether we would be prepared to pay such a price. I remember saying this at a function of the veteran community in Drummoyne and some veterans called out from the hall, `Yes—yes, you would pay the price just as we did because you are Australians, just as we are.' There is always the belief that as Australians we are prepared to do the right thing.

I have shed many a tear at many of the commemorative events but I also have a new-found and deeper admiration for many of the older Australians, especially our veterans. They fought to protect us not only for democracy—these are not just words—but also for a way of life. I express the gratitude of a whole nation for remembering the end of the Second World War.

—The member in her remarks—having been kind, perhaps I could be slightly unkind—read a speech. I am not quite sure where she was given it to read from; I assume from the minister's office.
