PARA.TAB: The member for Lowe talked about initiatives and extensions in the context of a bill dealing with veterans' affairs. That may be the rhetoric, but in practice that is not actually what we are talking about here. Taking the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill in its entirety, we are not talking about the extension of benefits to veterans; we are actually talking about a reduction of benefits to veterans.

You do not have to look past the financial impact of this legislation to see that that is the case. In total, there are 14 items listed in the financial impact statement accompanying this legislation. Of these, four have no financial impact, five will cost additional money and five will result in savings. Overall, the measures result in the following savings: in 1995-96, $3.4 million; in 1996-97, virtually $6 million; in 1997-98, $7.4 million; and in 1998-99, $8.7 million.

The net effect of this legislation is that it takes away benefits from veterans; it reduces their current entitlements—you cannot obfuscate that. Even if you do want to trot out the government propaganda on this legislation and talk about initiatives and extensions, that is not the case. Those savings mostly come from the one element which the member referred to—where she again used the phrase `an extension of benefits'—and that is the changing of the minimum age for non-veteran partner service pensions. I regard that change as a direct attack on the veteran community. It is penny-pinching in the extreme. The reason it was introduced was to stop World War II veterans taking young Asian brides. There is nothing racist intended in that comment, as people who are aware of the situation would understand, but that was the point of that change, as I understand it.

The minister is not in the House today. He very often is in the House when veterans' affairs matters are debated. I do not question his whereabouts. I only make the observation that he normally comes in. I assume that he is otherwise engaged, which I perfectly understand, but I hope that somebody from the government side, and hopefully the minister when he sums up, will refute that suggestion in this debate.

I want to hear an argument—not a trotting out of the propaganda or a talk about other issues—that this has not been introduced for that reason. If that is the reason the government is supporting this legislation, as I suspect it is, then I want to ask the parliament and the minister whether they have questioned the effect this will have on the vast majority of veterans who will be adversely affected by this legislation.

Setting at 50 years the minimum age requirement for partner service pensions for partners without dependent children saves the government a few million dollars, but it impacts severely on those many veterans with younger wives. Most of those—almost by definition—are not aged World War II veterans. You could count on a couple of hands those who do marry younger brides for one reason or another. Affected by this will be mostly Vietnam veterans, particularly the Vietnam veterans who have emotional or cardiorespiratory impairments where it is desirable—as it probably will be in every case—to have a wife acting as a carer at home.

So this bill not only represents an attack on veterans, and Vietnam veterans in particular, but also represents an attack on those who care for them and need to care for them. Caring is a very emotive situation. The member for Lowe and the government have made the point that this initiative is to encourage those younger women to get back into the work force. Of course, many of them can choose, and they do choose, to do that—that is their right, and that can be encouraged—but this proposal will deny those veterans not on the special rate the care they need.

I accept that the government under pressure backed down in respect of some veterans—the member in her speech alluded to some of those areas—and certainly in respect of those on the special rate. But what about those, I ask the minister, on the 100 per cent rate who are unemployable and others who need to have a carer at home? Their interests are being severely downgraded. I am assured, from talking to some of my friends in the Vietnam veteran community, that they regard this also as an attack on their existing entitlements. There can be no argument that it is other than that, because of the savings that are going to result for the government from this initiative.

The argument may well be—let me anticipate government members who may come in here to argue the pros of this bill; perhaps the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) will—that this will more or less bring Vietnam veterans into line with social security beneficiaries. That also is objectionable in principle to the veteran community. Veterans deserve special treatment, not for any other reason than that they have earned that special treatment. It is something they are entitled to. Any attempt to downgrade the special treatment of Vietnam veterans, take it away from them, diminish it and put them in the same category as all other people is to downgrade their entitlements, which they have earned.

These sorts of entitlements to veterans or their carers are not handouts but things they have earned. The wives who are involved, particularly if they are taking care of a veteran, are also entitled to have that opportunity. It is a shared responsibility that they have. The veteran lives through the effects, but so do the carers and spouses.

I am very disappointed that the government has taken this action at this particular time. The member for Lowe who spoke before me mentioned Australia Remembers. It has been a great year. We have all talked about the many wonderful things that have happened. It is unfortunate that this measure should be enacted in this year of Australia Remembers.

In the context of this bill, let me place on notice for the minister some concerns that are being expressed in the veteran community about the 1994 changes to the act. There is an increasing concern that veterans' conditions have in practice been considerably diminished by virtue of that legislation. The legislation established the Repatriation Medical Authority, and we debated that at length at that time. It was the government's response, on second or third try, as I recall, to the Bushell decision, which was at the time very generous to veterans. There was concern—misplaced as it turned out to be—that this was going to cost billions of dollars. It was accepted by the RSL at that time, but I do not know exactly why. I have heard some suggestions as to why that might have been.

Veterans, the system having been put in place, are now coming to realise the full implications of this change. I want to ask the minister—he has responded frequently to the remarks I have made in the House by writing to me, and I respect him for the way that he does his job—when the promised review of the working of the new RMA is to happen. Veterans are starting to ask that. A review is part of the process. We are not sure whether that review is to take place on the anniversary of the passing of the legislation or at what point that review will take place, but veterans are certainly looking forward to it.

It seems that the benefit of doubt which had been enjoyed by the veteran community has, in practice, now been undermined to some extent. The RMA is effectively now judge and jury, and it seems to many veterans that the weight of medical and scientific evidence is now the standard of proof.

There is concern amongst veterans over the effective treatment of those with motor neuron disease. I bring this issue to the minister's attention. Motor neuron disease is a name given to a group of diseases, each sharing several commonalities. Statistically, MND affects about one person in every 100,000. It generally occurs in those people over the age of 50. The most preponderant form of MND witnesses a slow degeneration in muscles, with an average of about eight to 10 years from diagnosis to death.

Out of the approximately 50,000 Vietnam veterans, one would statistically expect only one case of MND. Statistically, any more than two cases of MND in the entire Vietnam veteran population is beyond a chance event and points to a threat to the popularly held genetic hypothesis. More than three cases being found would also allow scientists to link the disease to a special causative agent, so reinforcing the weight of environmental hypotheses.

To date, nine Vietnam veterans have been diagnosed with MND. Clearly, the fact that nine cases of MND have been diagnosed upsets the relevance of the currently popular genetic hypothesis. It also warrants a major investigation. The fact that so many Vietnam veterans have MND, and the SOP shows no linkage to service, undermines the validity of the current process. I make those remarks because in the context of this debate—and bearing in mind your earlier admonition, Mr Deputy Speaker—I want to take the opportunity to ask the minister specifically about that issue. A number of veterans have put to me a concern about how the current system treats motor neuron disease.

I do not say this lightly, but I am concerned that the last couple of years have seen consistent downgrading of benefits to veterans. That is the debit side. In fact, I do not think there is any real evidence that there is a great credit side, but perhaps we will hear some cogent arguments from government members when they get up to speak on this issue. I hope that a coalition government, elected shortly, will reverse this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha! Keep dreaming.

—Unfortunately, the member for Moreton will not be here when that happens. But I believe you have done a fair job while you have been here. A coalition government, of which I will be a member, will reverse this trend and take a position where legislation is not introduced. I would like to see legislation introduced which will reverse some of the decisions that have already been taken. In fact, I am disappointed that we will not vote against the changes to the pensioner arrangements.

—There is one thing upon which I will agree with the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) and that is that veterans in our community are entitled to extra benefits and extra consideration because of the service that they have performed for their country. As the child, grandchild and son-in-law of veterans who served in the Second World War—and many other of my relatives served in the Second World War, the Korean War and a couple in the Vietnam War—I believe that it is the government's policy and philosophy to provide as many benefits as possible to the veteran community in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Where I disagree most strongly with the member for McPherson is in his assertion that we are continually diminishing the benefits that we provide to veterans. I believe that that can be very strongly contested. As the member for McPherson has recognised, our current Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) has been doing an outstanding job in his portfolio, and that has been recognised across the community. I understand that in very recent days he has been recognised for his contribution by the RSL organisation nationally which has granted him the distinctive honour of life membership. I do not think that organisation has ever previously given that honour to a minister—particularly a Labor Minister for Veterans' Affairs. That speaks volumes for the contribution that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has made to the welfare of veterans throughout Australia.

In 1995—the 50th anniversary of the ending of the Second World War and the year of Australia Remembers—I believe that we are honouring that memory with additional benefits to veterans. There is one very important part of the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 that the member for McPherson failed to recognise as a positive benefit. I refer to the amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act. I will deal with that matter shortly.

There are many other things that the minister has done this year which give due recognition to the important place that veterans have in our society and the honour that they deserve for the work that they have done for our community. One of those has been in the area of the aged care policy. The minister outlined previously in the House the policy that he had earlier announced called As time goes by: Continuing the commitment. That was the policy statement on aged care which sets out future directions for care of the veteran community in the next five to 10 years. That policy has been drawn up in consultation with the veteran community across Australia.

Through that policy program the government is introducing a five-year program to assist ex-service organisations to upgrade, replace or relocate their aged care facilities. It will be complemented by a four-year community care seeding grants program to improve the range and availability of community services in areas of demonstrated need where there is a high veteran population. That is just one initiative that the minister has taken which is a positive improvement in services.

Another major initiative increases funding for research targeted to the health needs of the veteran community. A number of priority research areas will be identified each year to maintain the focus on veteran related issues. These arrangements will ensure that the health areas of most concern to veterans can be researched by the best scientists. That is a very important initiative because our veteran community has a number of specific health needs that require intensive research and analysis. This government is demonstrating its commitment to fulfilling that need by this program.

Another very important initiative which the government recently announced is the improvement in the payment of nursing home costs for former Australian prisoners of war; improved access to chiropractic and osteopathic services for entitled veterans, war widows and war widowers; and simplification of the delivery of health care by halving the different types of treatment entitlement cards. I would like to particularly comment on the expansion of the nursing home costs for former Australian prisoners of war because that is a very important additional initiative.

I was impressed by the arguments of a former member of this place, Mr Tom Uren, when he sought to have some improvements made to and recognition of the particular circumstances that prisoners of war had suffered in the war years. He pointed out that they were entitled to some additional benefits. I commend the government on this initiative of covering all the nursing home costs of Australian former prisoners of war. I am the grandchild of a former prisoner of war. My grandfather spent 3 1/2 years in Changi and on the Burma railway and suffered enormously as a result of this treatment. He is no longer with us. He certainly gave a great deal for his country. I believe that prisoners of war deserve special recognition and special consideration. They are getting it from this government.

It is important to note that this government recognises the important place that veterans have in our society and that they get extra special treatment. It is something to which they are fully entitled.

I wish to comment on one of the very important initiatives in this legislation that the House is debating today, and that is the extension of the defence service homes eligibility to full-time members of certain Second World War women's services. For 50 years former members of the World War II women's services who did not actually serve overseas during wartime have been excluded from the defence service homes benefits in contrast to many of the male volunteers. This amendment redresses that situation and recognises the major contribution to the war effort that was made by thousands of female volunteers who joined the services on the same basis as their male counterparts.

A lot of these female volunteers worked in circumstances which were in forces that acted in a military-like way and they were required to undertake certain duties that were similar to military type duties without, of course, facing direct threats in service. They provided an enormous array of services for Australia's war effort. This extension of the defence service homes eligibility will be an important additional benefit for them in recognition, in 1995, of the contribution that they have made.

Another important change that has occurred is that we have extended the eligibility of defence service homes to providers of retirement village and granny flat accommodation. This will mean a major improvement for former veterans who are living in those forms of accommodation. As the Department of Veterans' Affairs review outlines, as the veteran population ages their housing needs change and retirement village and granny flat accommodation is now more appropriate for many who have difficulty in living alone independently.

This legislation will increase appropriate housing options and assist elderly clients to remain independently housed by encouraging them to move to accommodation more appropriate to their needs. As veterans age, existing accommodation may become inappropriate. Where this occurs, and particularly where social isolation is also a factor, there is often an increased demand for nursing care and services that might be more effectively met in terms of costs and health outcomes in more appropriate accommodation.

It is the desire of the government to keep people independently housed for as long as possible. If that means that we need to provide additional financial assistance so that people can utilise other forms of accommodation such as granny flats, where they are living under or next to their families but still independent of their families—still having close access to their families—or if they are living in retirement village situations and are able to work in a group and have the comfort of knowing that they are in a group housing situation for their own support needs, we believe that should be encouraged. It is preferable to people being forced, because of their needs, to move into some form of institutional care such as a nursing home or hostel.

So this amendment to the legislation will facilitate greater independent living by those veterans who are in need of nursing care or support services but who do not wish to be institutionalised in a nursing home. So I commend those amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act to the House.

Tonight we are considering a number of other amendments in the legislation, one of which extends income support supplement to war widows and widowers with pensioner partners. This, again, is a positive benefit which is not a reduction in the conditions applying to veterans, as the member for McPherson would have us believe. It is an improvement to the benefits available.

I believe that all of these amendments are worthy of support. They are not amendments that will in any way diminish the quality of care that this government provides to the veteran community. It is a reflection of the fact that this minister does have a strong commitment to the veteran community. That has been demonstrated throughout this year through the commemorations and celebrations that we have had all over Australia with the Australia Remembers program. It is to his credit that the minister continues to be an active voice in the government and in the cabinet on behalf of veterans.

I might also make a couple of comments about the success of the Australia Remembers program, because it has been a very vital program for the whole of Australian society. Within my electorate, I had great pleasure in being engaged in a range of activities for the Australia Remembers program, encompassing young school children attending primary schools, through to some of our most senior members of our community being involved in some wonderful celebrations and commemorations.

I would like to single out two particular events. The first one was a musical event that we staged in Brisbane at the Southbank piazza which was called `Bridging the Generations'. This Australia Remembers celebration was designed, as the title says, to bridge the generations between those young people from the 1930s and 1940s to the young people of the 1990s, so that the young people of today could understand some of the joy and happiness and some of the songs and dances that the young people of the 1930s and 1940s enjoyed, so that it was not all a sombre reflection on the sorrows and tragedies of war, but a part of our celebration of life and the good times that people had.

The `Bridging the Generations' concert involved some 200 young people from primary and secondary schools around my electorate who joined together with some older singers who sang a number of the songs of the war years and massed choirs. We also had a couple of school bands playing some of the big brassy sounds of the 1940s. And we had a `Bridging the Generations' dance group which was made up mainly of 70- to 80-year-old ballroom dancers who did a medley of about six different dances from the 1940s, which was greatly enjoyed by the audience.

Throughout the evening, we took the opportunity to remember some of the particular important points during the war years. The Mount Gravatt High School put on a short play which emphasised some of the personal recollections that people had from our local area about their time in the war years, some of the things that they saw and some of the things that they suffered.

All in all it was a wonderful evening. My congratulations go to all of the people who helped pull it together. It was staged by the Moreton commemorative committee for Australia Remembers, but it was particularly pulled together by a small subcommittee which organised the `Bridging the Generations' concert, led most ably by the principal of Greenslopes State School, Mr Geoff Mill, who did an outstanding job in bringing together all of the different primary school bands. He was helped by Mr Graham Mellor from the Catholic Education Office who assisted in bringing together some of the Catholic schools involved, particularly the band from St Laurence's college, to perform at the concert.

The second event, which was a very important and a more sombre occasion, was the opening of Australia Remembers Place, which is now established in Stimson Park on the corner of Ipswich Road and Beaudesert Road in Moorooka. This is now a permanent memento to Australia Remembers and to the 50th anniversary of the ending of the Second World War. It has been put in there by very generous support from the Brisbane City Council which, firstly, allowed us to establish this place in Stimson Park and, secondly, spent the money to build the pathways, build the gardens and plant the trees and flowers in Australia Remembers Place.

My thanks go to Jim Soorley, the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, who has been a very strong backer of the Australia Remembers program throughout Brisbane, but particularly was very supportive of the establishment of Australia Remembers Place. It is the only specific memorial to the Second World War in my electorate and one of the few that exists in Brisbane.

We have throughout Australia many fine memorials to the First World War, and the names of veterans who gave their lives in the Second World War have often been added to these First World War memorials. But there are very few Second World War memorials only, and this Australia Remembers Place in Stimson Park in my electorate will be a very important reminder of the unique contribution that many people made in the Second World War.

The place is designed to have two main arcs that your eye immediately goes to. One represents the African and European conflict and it has a number of plaques to specific conflicts within that theatre of war. The second arc goes to the Asia-Pacific conflict and it has a number of plaques that commemorate particular campaigns in that theatre of war.

The plants in the African and European garden are flowering shrubs and trees from Africa and Europe and the plants in arc of the Asia-Pacific garden are from the Asia-Pacific region. The flowering plants in the African and European garden will flower around early May, which is the time of the ending of the Second World War in Europe. The flowering plants in the Asia-Pacific garden will flower at around mid-August, at the time of the achievement of victory in the Pacific.

A large plaque in one garden commemorates Australia Remembers Place and that garden is full of the peace rose to commemorate what that sacrifice by all of those people who fought in all of those campaigns was all about, namely, the achievement of peace and freedom for all the peoples of the world and particularly for Australians.

The minister has much to be thanked for—it has been his initiative and his drive that has kept the Australia Remembers program going throughout 1995. He has done an outstanding job and the people of Moreton, the people of Queensland and the people of Australia are very grateful to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for all the good work he has done on that.

The House should also be supportive of this legislation, because although a couple of clauses here will make some changes to benefits, by far and away the vast bulk of this legislation is positive and built upon many other positive achievements that this minister has made throughout his period as Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Fisher, and not wanting in any way to dampen the enthusiasm for the Australia Remembers program, I think it worth while pointing out that the question of relevancy is important here. We do have a veterans affairs amendment bill before us and we do have on the Notice Paper a ministerial statement and a debate on the Australia Remembers program, 1945 to 1995. So we should confine ourselves to the motion before the House rather than stray down alleys which resurrect the Australia Remembers program.
