TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, there is no doubt that the ruling you have just given is technically very accurate, but having allowed the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) to stray down those alleyways one would imagine you would be similarly generous to subsequent speakers.
—I thought you might say that. We will allow it to be a rather widespread debate.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are debating the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, which amends two bills. As seems to be the practice in this place, a bill will often be brought into the parliament making a large number of changes which never seem to share any common thread. This bill amends the Defence Service Homes Act of 1918 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986. There are 14 changes made pursuant to the budget delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) some months ago. Four of these have no financial impact; five will cost the Australian taxpayer money, and five will save money.

PARA.TAB: The total budgetary impact will not be large when one looks at the overall level of Commonwealth expenditure today. Indeed, one ought to appreciate that the net result will be that the veteran community will be worse off financially. The honourable member for Moreton told us that the vast bulk of the amendments improved the situation for veterans. There are some of those but one must realise that the government is taking away benefits from other veterans.

There are major amendments in relation to both acts. There is a most important amendment to extend the defence service homes eligibility to full-time members of certain World War II women's services. The legislation also seeks to allow the assignment of defence service homes eligibility to providers of retirement village and granny flat accommodation. The legislation seeks to set a minimum age requirement for the partner service pension. It also seeks to extend the income support supplement to war widows and widowers with pensioner partners and seeks to extend the treatment eligibility for veterans suffering post-traumatic stress disorder.

Firstly, in regard to the changes made to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918, this act provided housing assistance for certain men and women who have served our nation in various spheres of conflict since 1918. The 1993-94 annual report of the Repatriation Commission and Department of Veterans' Affairs states that as at June 1994 there were 107,124 persons in receipt of defence service homes assistance. As a person who formerly practised law, we had many clients who sought loans under the defence service homes arrangements. From time to time government policy has varied and at times people were disadvantaged by changes in government rules and regulations. Up until the present time the loans were available only to certain persons. The amendment before the House seeks to extend the eligibility to former members of World War II women's services who did not actually serve overseas during wartime.

One might say that the government is seeking to remove some discrimination but the government cannot strut about or be too proud of this change because this amendment results from a complaint made at the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and actually follows a conciliation conference. It was not that the minister got up one morning and said: `This is an injustice that must be rectified.' A conciliation conference drew this to the government's attention and, in effect, the government has been dragged kicking and screaming into the House to propose this amendment.

As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, many women were not given the opportunity to serve overseas. The general belief at the time, 50-odd years ago, was that it would be better to fill the jobs and positions of men at home with women so that men would then be free to serve overseas in the war zones. Women who were members of a number of services up until now have not been eligible to receive defence service home loans. That was an obvious discrimination and completely unfair. I am pleased that the government, however reluctantly, is seeking to change the provisions to permit members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service and the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force to receive the benefits they should have received many years ago.

Also to benefit from the amendments are some former members of the Australian Army Medical Women's Service. Also, full-time paid members of the voluntary aid attachment during the war will receive the benefit of the amendment we are currently debating.

In the past it was considered that the services in which these women who will now benefit worked were, in effect, raised merely for home service and that the very important contribution they made to the war effort was not sufficient to make them eligible to apply for a defence service home loan. It should be noted that male volunteers who did not serve outside Australia have been eligible for defence service homes assistance for a very considerable time.

Another major development included in the legislation is the assignment of defence service homes eligibility to providers of retirement village and granny flat accommodation. In effect, this keeps before veterans a wider range of housing options. As many of our veterans are not as fit and able as they used to be, they are clearly at this time of their lives looking at housing options. I am pleased to see that the government is bringing this amendment in, which will provide a wider range of options to veterans so that they will not be disadvantaged. The legislation allows for the assignment to providers of a granny flat despite the fact that the particular property might not be owned by the veteran or the veteran's spouse. This would benefit many veterans who might well make an addition to a home owned by their child. So they have this sense of independence while still being close to family.

Also, the amendment allows for the assignment to a retirement village that provides accommodation mainly to veterans or their widows. The legislation encourages independence and freedom of choice. In the electorate of Fisher, a very fine electorate, we have two war veterans' homes. One is at Caboolture, which is going to the new seat of Longman, which will be represented by Malcolm Brough for the Liberal Party after the next election. But I am retaining the establishment in Caloundra, known as the Centaur home. Both the home at Caboolture and the home at Caloundra are very well run. Matron Gwenda Shaw at Caboolture does a fine job and, along with her staff, has gone out of her way to make sure that the veterans living in the war veterans home have a very caring environment. It is a desirable place in which to live. Garry Dukeson, the director of nursing at the Caloundra Centaur home, has been able to create a similar environment there. It is important that as a nation we seek to care for our veterans at a time in their lives when they need this kind of assistance.

There are changes to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and earlier speakers in the House have outlined what these changes entail. Basically it will mean that partners of veterans who are currently allowed to receive a partner service pension where they are married or in a marriage-like relationship with a veteran receiving an age or invalidity benefit will not necessarily have this benefit extended. The amendment provides that a person is not eligible for a partner service pension unless he or she has reached the age of 50 or unless he or she has a dependent child at the time an application is made for the pension. It ought to be noted that this provision is not retrospective and will not affect those receiving or those who have been determined to be eligible for a partner service pension prior to 1 October 1995. The Department of Veterans' Affairs budget review 1995-96 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally accepted that people under 50 years of age should not be expected or encouraged to retire. Payment of partner service pension to younger partners does not encourage those people to seek work in their own right. Future non-veteran partners under 50 who are not looking after a dependent child or severely handicapped veteran and are unable to obtain work may be eligible for partner allowance, sickness allowance or disability support allowance from the Department of Social Security.
So, even though these changes are coming in, there will be a safety net there for those who need it.

PARA.TAB: The coalition, as has been indicated by the shadow minister, is not opposing this amendment, but we do have some reservations, particularly regarding Vietnam veterans. It is fairly obvious that many Vietnam veterans now aged about 50 could well have spouses somewhat younger, five or 10 years younger, and it seems that the government is going to disadvantage those families. This is a matter the government really ought to look at very closely. The Vietnam veterans are not happy about this particular amendment as they feel that it does not adequately recognise their age group and that indeed it is an unjust imposition on them.

Some Vietnam veterans are already eligible for various entitlements but, due to the simple fact some spouses are not 50 years of age, they may get nothing. It would not take too much for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) to take this matter back on board and to once again try to make sure that the justice which everyone wants to see extended to veterans is indeed extended to veterans of the Vietnam War. I was very pleased to hear that the shadow minister, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), will be continuing to look at this matter because it is very important that Vietnam veterans be given the same consideration as other veterans who have served their nation in the way Vietnam veterans have.

The coalition supports the amendments before the House. We have a number of reservations, particularly relating to Vietnam veterans, but I do not believe that it is too late for the minister to look at this again. With a couple of nips and tucks in the legislation, I think the minister could rectify what is probably an unintended consequence.

A moment ago we heard the honourable member for Moreton say that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has driven the Australia Remembers program. The honourable member for Moreton seemed to indicate that had it not been for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs we would not have had an Australia Remembers program—a program which has been patently successful, as everyone in the nation would accept. I think we really ought to pause for a moment and recognise that the success of the Australia Remembers 1945-95 program has not been due solely to the minister; it has been due to the bipartisan approach that both sides of politics have taken to the Australia Remembers program.

More importantly, the Australia Remembers program is bigger than politicians; the Australian community has fully embraced the Australia Remembers program. Right across every electorate in the nation committees were set up, and those committees worked very hard. They called for submissions, and projects were submitted to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Right across the 147 House of Representatives electorates there are very many worthwhile projects which will see bricks and mortar monuments to the Australia Remembers program in place for many years to come.

You will not be surprised to hear, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the electorate of Fisher has fully participated in the Australia Remembers program. When the minister announced that seeding funding of $20,000 was going to be provided for every federal electorate throughout the nation I called a public meeting at the Caloundra RSL. A wide representation of RSL members from throughout the old electorate of Fisher attended. We tried to get some extra money for the electorate of Longman. I think the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) was also very keen for money to be provided separately for the electorate of Longman because that would have left more for his electorate of Dickson. Indeed, had we been able to get money for Longman there would have been more for the redistributed electorate of Fisher. The minister said, though, that only existing and not new electorates would be funded.

The chairman of the committee we set up was Mr Gordon Caldwell of Blackbutt; the secretary was Dick Alchin of Caloundra; the treasurer was Bill Platten of Caloundra, and the committee members were Jim Courtney from Bribie Island, Bernie Barton from Glasshouse, Bob Russell, Gordon Granzien from Toogoolawah, and John Hodgkinson. This committee worked together and called for applications from throughout the electorate, recommending funding for some 19 projects.

Of course, when one is a representative of a geographic area considering applications for funding from that geographic area there would be every opportunity for a bunfight, but I must say that this committee worked very well. Whenever a local project was being considered the representative from that area on the committee did not take part in the discussions, with the result that the 19 projects which were recommended from the electorate of Fisher were indeed 19 very worthwhile projects. I am very proud to have been part of this particular program.

I must also say that there were contributions made by people who did not receive seeding funding. For instance, the Buddina State School opened a cenotaph and memorial garden. The way the entire school community contributed was tremendous. The principal, John Brooker, and the school community got behind this project, and the fact that it was such an outstanding success—involving also the local Kawana Waters RSL—was a credit not only to John Brooker but also to all the staff, students and parents of the Buddina State School. Peter Koster from the Bokarina State School got into the action too. They also opened a memorial garden in conjunction with the Kawana Waters RSL. I was privileged and proud to have been part of both of those ceremonies. What continues to happen in the electorate of Fisher with respect to the Australia Remembers program is indicative of what is continuing to happen throughout the nation in this particular year.

In his speech on this bill the shadow minister once again drew to the attention of the House the fact that the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan), on the back of his application form, had a lot of party political information regarding the Australia Remembers certificates. I think all of us on both sides would condemn the honourable member for Lilley for doing this because he is politicising what is really a non-political issue. I now announce to the House that it seems he has withdrawn the side of his application which is critical of our side of politics. Indeed, he now has a document which on one side has an application for a certificate of appreciation in recognition of wartime service to Australia, and on the other side we find he is announcing Wayne Swan's community information kits and sheets.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the name again?

—The member for Lilley is inviting people to apply for a broad range of kits and sheets in respect of matters not concerning the Australia Remembers program. The member for Lilley is running scared because he knows that Elizabeth Grace will be the Liberal member for Lilley after the next election, and that will be a matter of very great advantage to the people of the electorate of Lilley.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the Second World War, Prime Minister Chifley said:

SPEECH.PARA: The careers of hundreds and thousands of young men have been interrupted and in some cases partially ruined. There is a break of education, training and opportunity which cannot be repaired. It is perfectly true that experience is gained, but that is not material to an ordinary civil vocation. On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.
A coalition Prime Minister of the day, Sir Arthur Fadden, said:

A grateful nation must see that those who are privileged to return from battle areas shall be properly cared for, and that their reinstatement in civil life shall be wisely and expeditiously carried out.

So we had two sentiments expressed by two great Australian Prime Ministers. As a coalition member, I must say that I agree with the comments made by both Prime Minister Chifley and Prime Minister Fadden. It is very important that, as members of parliament dealing with veterans' affairs through the bill we are discussing today, wherever possible we are bipartisan, that wherever possible we endeavour to make sure that we do not play party politics with the lives of ex-service men and women who went overseas to make sure that succeeding generations are able to enjoy the freedom, stability and way of life that we have today in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the Australia Remembers program has been such a success is a credit to everyone in this place and a credit to the entire Australian community. I am pleased to see, in the area of veterans' affairs, that we have adopted these sentiments of Chifley and Fadden but, with respect to the legislation that we are debating, I would ask the government once again to look at the case of Vietnam veterans because Vietnam veterans are going to be disadvantaged by the amendment I referred to earlier. It is important to be fair, reasonable and just. We do not oppose the legislation before the House, but we ask the government to reconsider that particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start my speech on the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill, let me just say that I find it somewhat ironic that members of the opposition lecture this side on social security, family support and a safety net that is available to all Australians. If there is any government in the history of Australia that has ensured that all the needy people in Australia have a safety net, it is this government.

PARA.TAB: Australia remembers and this government remembers. I am proud to say that veterans' affairs are of great concern to this government. They always have been and, while we continue on the government benches, they always will be. This has not always been so. There have been governments in Australia's history that have tended to ignore the needs of the men and women who fought for the freedom of our nation and our way of life. But the time has arrived where changes need to be made to the bill.

These amendments comprise 14 key points which will provide greater services and benefits to veterans. Indeed, these amendments are about increasing flexibility and making the veterans' affairs support system more user friendly in areas such as housing, health, treatment and provision, and insurance. The amendments will also reduce areas of waste, inequality and, particularly, bureaucratic delays. Everyone in this House knows how many representations they make to Veterans' Affairs to support the veterans in their electorate when bureaucracy, unnecessarily in many situations, delays the assistance that is sorely needed.

I am pleased to see that the opposition is supporting these amendments. They have made some political capital of the fact that veterans' spouses under the age of 50 may be removed from the safety net of Veterans' Affairs. While I understand that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) later this evening will address this issue, no-one from this side is suggesting that they would be removed altogether from the safety net of social security. That has never been the intention of the government. It is not our intention to remove any needy Australian from any safety net. The opposition should keep that well in mind when they are talking about budgetary cuts and about how they might do things, if they get the opportunity to cut spending. I am sure they are looking at cuts to the social security system.

The first amendment under this legislation is to provide assistance under the Defence Service Homes Act where title is to be held as tenants-in-common. As I said, there is flexibility and it is user friendly, allowing the beneficiary the maximum flexibility of the system. It will assist clients who are wishing to hold title as tenants in common, allowing clients who have pooled loans recognition of title. These changes are in keeping with current commercial practices and they will not affect a great number of clients. But the ones they do affect will receive the benefit they wish. That, of course, is the wish of the government—that where people require this form of assistance, it be available. So the fact that the amendment may affect only a few is really irrelevant. The ones who need it are the ones who ask for it, and they will get that form of assistance.

The second amendment will provide defence service homes benefit to full-time members of the World War II Women's Service. It is not to any previous government's credit that this group of Australians have not received this benefit until now—after 50 years. Until now the Defence Service Homes Act of 1918 discriminated against women by not entitling them to the full defence service homes benefit if they had not served outside Australia, regardless of their Australian service. For 50 years, women in the Australian armed forces have received little or no recognition of their commitment and loyalty to Australia. Men have always had access, even if they served only on Australian soil. This change will improve the position of over 200 women in the first year. While government outlays may be relatively minimal, to the people who receive the benefit it is something that is not only needed, it says that Australia as a nation thanks those volunteer women who served Australia so well.

This is important to me as a representative because I am aware of several ladies who served as nurses in France before the German invasion and following D-Day. These ladies faced risks as great as soldiers did, if not greater, because they were unable to defend themselves. I have also met ladies who were seeking to move closer to their families and friends, and required a loan to purchase smaller apartment style accommodation. I think it is great that there is flexibility in aged housing these days. This government certainly has a commitment to hostel accommodation and to nursing homes—but they do not suit everyone.

Families today tend to be diversified. They do not stay in one locality or community. Many people, as they age, want to get closer to the family support system but that has been denied to many of the elderly, particularly widows, because they did not have the mobility or capacity to get rid of their home and purchase another one. To those ladies who were previously refused access to defence service home loans, I say that this injustice has been rectified.

The third amendment allows the assignment of a defence service home loan entitlement to certain providers of accommodation. At present the current loan conditions for defence service home loans do not accept the properties in question as collateral if the home or unit is within a retirement village. You and I both know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in the Hunter region there are some magnificent retirement villages that provide first class accommodation and are there purely because of grants from this government, something that this side of politics is extremely proud of.

Often, retirement villages offer only a leasehold agreement and, therefore, provide less security for the loan provider. The current act does not allow loans to be used for this purpose and the legislation will see this revoked. Again, it is all about flexibility and being user friendly. Not only will this provide veterans with a wider choice of accommodation facilities, it will allow them to retain their independence, freedom and privacy—the things they fought for so long ago.

Veterans can live in a retirement community with a body corporate able to provide essential services and care usually found only in nursing homes. The extension of the loans criteria is a recognition of the value that the community places on these Australians. The take-up rate will be approximately 70 in the first year. Again, it is not a major cost item to the government, but it is of major value to those people who require it. I am sure that it will be welcomed.

The fourth amendment provides assistance under the DSH Act for a company title or leasehold title. The current act does not provide conditions under which a property may be purchased under company titles. While this has not affected many people, especially following the spread of strata title units, there is still a number of people who wish to take on loans under these conditions. This is simply a procedural matter to assist in the processing of requests.

The fifth amendment cancels the subsidy in relation to deceased estates where there is no surviving spouse. This will prevent subsidy conditions being continued to an estate after a veteran and their partner have died and there are no more dependants. There is a three-month period following the death of a veteran and partner without dependants before the cancellation of the subsidy, allowing time for the executors of the estate to make all the necessary arrangements.

The sixth amendment will allow greater flexibility to clients by allowing subsidised advances to be used for housing purchases different from the initial house if that is no longer available or suitable. The existing certificates only last three months, which requires clients to apply for new certificates for each new project. The changes will see this time period extended. This will represent a saving to the government. Again, it is not a lot, but it will benefit in the order of 100 people per annum.

The seventh amendment will extend the pool of persons eligible to insure dwellings under the Defence Service Housing Act. At present, the current legislation does not allow a DSH client to be eligible for DSH insurance without undertaking a defence service housing loan. The amendment will allow veterans who may own their own home outright to take out defence service housing insurance. This insurance offers a broader cover than most insurance packages. Its structure shows an understanding of the requirement of veterans in the community. Defence service housing insurance covers flood damage, which is rarely covered by private institutions without high premiums. While it may seem far away, Mr Deputy Speaker, flood damage in your electorate and mine is of major importance. With the way it was raining when I left home this afternoon, perhaps we should take out some.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—We need it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current legislation does not allow portability of the loan if the client decides to move. We are talking about people of advancing years. These people may require movement, as I have already indicated, to be near their family, but they cannot move because of financial arrangements. If they have an existing loan and the loan is not portable, they will stay there. They will put up with the hardship that is incurred by that. Under this legislation, the loan will become portable. That in itself is a major benefit to those people who need it.

PARA.TAB: It is very important for the entire community, not just the veterans. It allows veterans to remain in their own area as they grow older, even if their housing needs change. An example of such a situation would be a veteran couple who sell the family home and move closer to their children in perhaps smaller unit style accommodation. The portability of the loan would allow the couple to take their existing borrowings and transfer them to the new property, thus allowing the veterans to move freely, to live closer to their family and friends and to have greater access to health and community services and, of course, the family network that is so important to the elderly.

The community of today owes a debt to those who fought for our nation in the past. We can repay this debt through allowing them to remain an active part of the community, as most of them wish to be. I am sure all members know that these people are fiercely independent. They gave something to Australia that no other generation has. They want to be independent. These amendments are about assisting that. Finally, the changes will repeal the insurer of last resort, which has often seen the DSH liable for substandard physical or moral risks. This will benefit the community as a whole and reduce the financial burden on the government, as it has been previously placed in a position that private insurers would not accept.

The eighth amendment redefines the terms and stabilises interest rates for further advances under the Defence Service Housing Act. The variation to the terms of the loans will see loans become more portable and reduce the pressure on those who choose to move. At present, if a recipient chooses to move and take the loan with them, their interest rate will increase, changing what would have normally been, for example, a $63 per month loan repayment to a $237 per month repayment. This current system discourages the elderly from moving closer to family, friends and medical and community support.

The ninth amendment is designed to amend eligibility for income support and compensation payments. The amendment to this act will simply redefine the qualifying characteristic for eligibility to service or disability pensions. The act of 1920 set out the criteria for eligibility for age or disability pensions. The current amendments only seek to explain this more clearly.

The clarification is designed to reduce the number of veterans pensions being paid to people who are not eligible for a pension. There have been several cases where people who were not in operational areas have received pensions to which they were not entitled. The amendment also makes special provision for the payment of pensions to people who were ordered to serve in Korea but who served only in Japan. Until now, these people were not recognised as being in an operational area. The amendment seeks to redress this problem and recognise the contribution made by these people to the defence of the Pacific.

The 10th amendment is to adjust disability pension lump sum arrears where the social security pension or income support supplement has been paid to the veteran's partner during the arrears period. At present, the current act has a provision allowing for excess income support payments to veterans to be deducted from their veterans pension arrears. However, this provision does not allow for the deduction of any amount of an existing pension benefit or allowance that would not have been paid to the partner if a new pension or allowance had been paid. This amendment will establish a new methodology for the calculation of the lump sum arrears.

The 11th amendment will set a minimum age of 50 years for partner service pensions. As I have already indicated, I understand that this amendment is to be addressed by the minister later this evening. As I also pointed out, it does not mean that that partner of less than 50 years of age would be denied access to the government safety net. They certainly will continue to be the recipients of benefits. I look forward to what the minister has to say later today.

The act will allow the retention of eligibility in certain circumstances when the veteran ceases to be paid. This could be due to receipt by the veteran of a special compensation lump sum payment or similar payment. The act will also limit the rate of service pension to the married rate in any circumstances where the other member of a couple is not receiving a pension or benefit. These last two measures will allow partners and dependants to continue to receive pensions even if their veteran partner or provider no longer receives payment.

The 12th amendment will disregard war widow or widower pension as income in the calculation of bereavement payments. This will bring together pension payments to war widows and widowers of disability and age pensions under the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Previously, they had been under the control of the Department of Social Security. This act will see war widow or widower pensions not included as income in determining bereavement payments but will see them included in determining income support supplement payments in general. This will see the government aid war widows and widowers as a total by $67,000 in 1995-96.
The 13th amendment is designed to provide automatic treatment and entitlements for veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and related co-morbidities. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the member for Paterson (Mr Horne), I think it is a shame that we were unable to hear the rest of his speech. He certainly went into full detail on each of the amendments in this legislation. I rise today to speak in support of the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. This bill puts forward a number of proposals. I urge all members to consider them very carefully not the least because of the significance of this year to veterans, to the veterans of the Second World War, and naturally, in retrospect, to all Australians.

PARA.TAB: In my electorate of Bass, the most outstanding thing about this year has been the enormous success of the Australia Remembers campaign. I note the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) is in the House at this time. He, his staff and his department are also to be commended for that particular campaign. It has been very successful. I am sure that is an observation that would be shared in all electorate offices all over this country.

Many hundreds of constituents have contacted my office seeking information and material relating to that campaign. They have been, without exception, positive and favourable in their response to it. Seeing the real joy many are deriving from the campaign has been a highlight for me personally.

Australia Remembers has more than a symbolic relevance, however. Indeed, witnessing the strength of community support for Australia Remembers prompts an important realisation. It is about more than just remembering. It is about doing. It is about paying real respect to those who defended our country during the Second World War. That means ensuring our servicemen and women continue to receive an appropriate and benefiting level of care, even as we move away from the war era and into the future.

The bill that we are speaking on here today, which has been put forward, takes several positive steps towards achieving this objective. It demonstrates that this government is committed and willing to put its money where its mouth is when it comes to recognising the particular needs of servicemen and women—needs which, while remaining essentially the same, will inevitably change as the service population ages and society in general changes.

One of the changes that I am most pleased with is that women are finally achieving equality of recognition and entitlement with their male counterparts. Such a development should not be taken at all lightly. Australia Remembers has inadvertently highlighted the importance of women's contribution to the war effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not inadvertently.

—Thank you, Minister. It has highlighted the importance of women's contribution to the war effort through, in particular, the issuing of certificates of merit. Out of the woodwork have come people from a very broad cross-section, men and women whose combined contribution to the war effort is absolutely staggering. It never ceases to amaze me from day to day.

PARA.TAB: But most interesting is the number of women coming forward for recognition. Again, I think most electorates would share this observation. These women are asking to be recognised for a great range of active duties associated with fighting the war—whether it be manning watches over the air and sea, producing armaments or uniforms, organising food parcels or even knitting socks. There are many women who served at home in military or naval corps who until now have not been acknowledged properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you. Arising from the 1995-96 budget, the bill before us puts in place measures which will provide such women—servicewomen, partners of veterans and war widows—with the entitlements and benefits they deserve. Item 12 of schedule 1 will extend eligibility for defence service homes benefits to full-time members of the World War II Women's Service, including the Women's Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Army Medical Women's Service and the voluntary aid detachment.

PARA.TAB: This is significant because for 50 years these women have been denied defence service homes benefits unless they served overseas during the war—in contrast to their male counterparts who, by and large, automatically qualified. Representatives of the World War II Women's Service have long campaigned for this recognition and there is no question that they definitely deserve it.

Furthermore, the suggestion of indirect discrimination arising from the current legislation has been acknowledged by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I understand this was their finding early in 1994. Currently, subsection 4(2A) of the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 is almost certainly in breach of both sections 5 and 26 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, and the Department of Veterans' Affairs has no choice but to redress that situation.

To my mind, there remains no valid reason to delay this measure any longer. It should come as no surprise, by the way, that the estimated take-up rate for loans under this measure is around 200 per year in the first five years. The increase in options for housing, independence and comfort in retirement for eligible women will certainly make an impact here.

There are other areas of veterans needs which have come under a degree of scrutiny in my electorate of Bass, as has been the case, I do not doubt, in many other electorates. Recently I attended a meeting of the Launceston RSL sub-branch at which specific matters relating to housing were raised. I have been looking into this area with a great deal of interest partly because I see it as an area which is constantly being improved and extended.

But, of course, as with everything that is put into place, there is almost certainly always room for more flexibility in terms of providing accommodation. In this instance, it is in providing accommodation for war veterans and pensioners. The amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 are responsive to the reality of changing needs, and they certainly provide the flexibility that we have been looking for.

Item 35 of schedule 1, for instance, allows for the assignment of a defence service home loan entitlement to certain providers of accommodation—those who can provide retirement village or granny flat accommodation. Other items extend this measure to benefit widows and widowers and to help provide loans for essential repairs. The area of loans for essential repairs has long been an argument with regard to housing for the elderly, and I am pleased to see that this is a measure we are looking at. There is a measure included in the bill to extend eligibility also for home insurance. We heard the previous speaker, the member for Paterson, expound on that particular area at great length.

Another important measure is to redefine the terms of and stabilise interest rates for housing advances. These seem like simple and obvious solutions to a range of problems and I think that they have come none too soon. Difficulties encountered by those wishing to use their service home loans to help them into retirement villages and other forms of accommodation should be adequately addressed by the proposed measures. Under existing arrangements, although a service housing loan can be used to buy a spot in a retirement village, in reality very few loans are made for this purpose. The main reason for this is that the form of tenure in most retirement villages does not satisfy the lender, Westpac, in terms of security. The amendment put in place in this bill gets around this problem by assigning the loan to the organisation, which is better able to satisfy security requirements.

Obviously, the war veterans pensioner population is ageing. We hear this on a daily basis. This goes hand in hand with changing needs. The one thing which should be kept in mind is that freedom of choice, the ability to live as independently as possible, is a common desire and ought to be respected.

The amendments before us not only help to fulfil individual needs for housing but also, in doing so, will have significant benefits further down the track. By helping a pensioner to live in a granny flat, for instance, where family care or alternative carer support may be readily available—many older citizens of our community do not wish to go into nursing homes; the option of getting a loan for a granny flat is going to be optimal for them—we will be able to alleviate some of the need for health and home care services. There could be significant downstream savings to health program expenditure as a result. We are always looking for some ways to make savings in the budget.

I am also pleased to see the bill includes amendments which extend pension eligibility and clarify previous fairly grey areas in the legislation. Those people, as we heard the member for Paterson remark, who were members of units which were allotted for duty in Korea but who served only in Japan will now be eligible for this pension under part II. This is a measure which will no doubt be made very welcome by that particular group of war veterans.

I have also had a lot of contact with representatives of our younger veteran group. I am talking in particular about the Vietnam veteran associations. They have been concerned about various aspects of their entitlements to pensions and so on. They are the next generation, so to speak, of pensioners. They are looking towards their future and questioning their entitlements at this stage.

Section 85 of the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 deals with eligibility for medical and other treatment which basically relies on there being a war caused injury. Item 1 of schedule 6 of the bill extends such eligibility to veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder—we have heard a lot about it in recent times and will continue to hear a lot about it as our Vietnam veterans are ageing—a condition which is characterised by symptoms such as anger, confusion and memory problems, apathy, depression, panic attacks and so on. I am sure most members of this place have been in contact with Vietnam veterans who are suffering those particular symptoms. It is not only stressful to the veterans and their families but also stressful to their friends. It is particularly prevalent in Vietnam veterans. The amendment will go a long way towards redressing what have been perceived as longstanding inadequacies in benefits available to Vietnam veterans.

I thoroughly approve of the amendments which extend the eligibility for the seniors health care card. Again, from an electorate perspective, I can see a need for this card to be made more widely available—if only to help fill in some gaps in benefits available from one class of pensioner or veteran to another.

Before I complete my remarks on this bill, I would like to spend some time talking briefly about the Australia Remembers program. Many people actually consider, now that VP Day—August 15—and the major celebrations are over, it is all over and done with. I guess most members of this place would agree with me that in their electorates it is generally alive and well. In my electorate of Bass I am fortunate that in November the minister will come to my electorate and present certificates of appreciation. I have been amazed at the number of people who are still contacting my office and asking whether they are eligible for these certificates.

I think this has been very significant for veterans, particularly the World War II veterans. It has also allowed the electorate—young, middle aged and older people—to remember what the World War II veterans did for us and to reflect on all other conflicts. One of the special things is that it has made all of us aware of the veterans.

It has also encouraged young people to learn about what happened. They were not alive in those years and they do not know much about what happened. Perhaps we have been a bit remiss in our schools over the past 50 years for not teaching our school children what has happened to the extent we should have. We have made our veterans proud of what they have done for us in all arenas of war. We have also put our thanks for what they did on the record. I take this opportunity to commend the minister, his department and his staff for all the hard work that they have put in on the Australia Remembers program and continue to put in on that program.

Finally, this bill represents a very sound and equitable response to the evolving conditions faced by our war veterans and pensioners. It can only result in immediate and measurable improvements in the prospect of our veterans overall and, in particular, those who have until now been excluded from receiving certain benefits because of obscure and sometimes discriminatory rationale. I give this bill my full approval in commending it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—First of all, I thank the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) for her kind and generous remarks and also thank all other speakers in this debate. It is quite poignant that we are discussing the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill in this House on the very day that the national executive of the Returned Services League bestowed on me honorary life membership. I am very touched and satisfied with that. I probably do not deserve it, but in their wisdom they thought I did. I thank them very much for that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member. I understand this is the first time they have bestowed this highest of honours to a politician—certainly to a serving one anyway. That said, I would like to make a couple of points.

PARA.TAB: I listened to the comments of the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). In all my dealings with the member in his capacity as the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, he has always taken a very positive and very constructive role. He sees his role—and I commend him for it—as an advocate for the ex-service community. Again on this occasion with this particular bill he has taken the same approach. I know that he had some objections with respect to one of the measures being introduced in this bill—a measure which will hopefully be passed today. He has made it very clear that he will be monitoring the situation to ensure that nothing happens which will in any way impinge on the rights of veterans, particularly younger veterans such as those that served in Vietnam. I respect his views on that.

The government did not take lightly its introduction of the 50-year age limit for partners of service pensioners who do not have dependent children. We need to be make it clear that the only people who may be affected by these initiatives are those who on and from 1 October 1995 are less than 50 years old, those who are not receiving service pension and those who do not have dependent children or do not have a partner who is receiving the special totally and permanently incapacitated—TPI—rate of disability pension. With respect to the last condition, I will shortly be moving some amendments that will ensure that is the case.

There are three important principles which stand behind this initiative. Firstly, younger partners who do not need to stay at home in a carer role should be encouraged to contribute to their family's support and maximise their family's total income by continuing to participate in the work force. They should not expect to be able to stop working earlier than they would otherwise just because their partner is a service pensioner. Secondly, younger partners who are encouraged to participate or continue to participate in the work force as a result of this initiative are contributing to their own support in their eventual retirement through ongoing contributions. Thirdly, due to the changing gender roles in society and the significant changes in women's labour force participation in recent decades, over half of all women of work force age now participate in the labour force. On the basis of this statistic, it is no longer appropriate for the government to make income support payments to younger women on the assumption that they are dependent on a male partner.

The government is committed to providing assistance to those who genuinely need it. Younger partners who are unable to find employment will still have access to assistance from the Department of Social Security in the form of partner allowance, newstart allowance, sickness allowance or disability support pension. This range of safety nets is also available to any other member of the community who is seeking work or support from the government.

The carer service pension will still be available from the Department of Veterans' Affairs to those whose veteran partners require a significant level of care in the home. This government has developed a budget that saves money, and this initiative is one of the means of achieving those savings. However—and this needs to be made very clear—the additional resources that will become available enable the government to extend benefits in areas of identified need. For example, over $20 million has been provided to help meet the needs of veterans and war widows and widowers in age accommodation and in their own homes. The health care entitlements of over 140,000 veterans and their dependants will be expanded at an additional cost of over $20 million over a forward estimates period.

The sum of $5 million has been allocated to medical research, of which $3 million will be given to the Anzac Health and Medical Research Foundation, which will be attached to the Concord hospital in Sydney when it can get matching funds from the New South Wales state government. That is a project which I personally am very glad to support strongly, and I have indicated that support. We need to ensure that we research diseases of the ageing lifestyle. We are all getting older. The veteran community is ageing at something like 2 1/2 times the rate of the general community. The fact is that they are the ones that are feeling problems such as dementia and so on. I think we need a research facility. The moneys that I and the government are able to save in one area without any harm to existing pensioners can be used in those other areas.

In addition, the rules for carer service pension will be relaxed and a range of additional benefits will be available for those caring for a severely handicapped person. Eligibility for income support will be extended to the older partner of veterans who are not yet eligible to claim service pension and to the widows and widowers of former veterans who did not claim service pension before their death.

The honourable member for O'Connor commented that the initiatives in this bill result in overall savings to government. As I have pointed out previously and in my second reading speech, this bill is only part of a package of measures announced in the context of the 1995-96 budget. Next month I will be introducing a second budget measures bill with the remainder of the changes required to legislation. More importantly, from the point of view of overall expenditure, many of the initiatives in my budget package do not require any legislative change. I have mentioned some of those. These amounts that I have mentioned previously dwarf the savings mentioned by the honourable member for O'Connor.

I now turn to the contribution of my friend—and I say that quite sincerely—the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). I do not think it would matter if the government and I gave away $100 billion tomorrow to the veterans' affairs portfolio. There is no doubt in my mind that my friend and colleague would find something wrong with it. I do not think there has ever been anything that I have ever done in this House regarding the veterans' affairs portfolio that he has not found something wrong with. I do not say that to be in any way critical, because I know of his own interest in this. For instance, he has been one of the biggest supporters of the Australia Remembers program, and for that I thank him. In fact, I have been in his electorate and have officially opened a memorial garden at Allambie Gardens for him. I am quite happy to go back again.

The honourable member for McPherson for some reason always tries to find some negatives. Even if there is nothing there, he will still try to find it. I say to the member, `Do not think simply because we are on opposite sides and because I represent the government, the Labor Party, that necessarily we will be doing things which in some shape or form will hurt veterans.' It is quite the contrary. He states quite unfairly—and I think deep down he will acknowledge this—that over the last five years or so we have been decreasing the entitlements of veterans. That is simply not true. It is not substantiated by the available evidence.

Just off the top of my head, with the help of some of my staff, I made a list of the new initiatives since I have been the minister over the last 18 months. We have put $50 million towards aged care. Just recently we have agreed to put in $200,000 for the Hellfire Pass memorial, $200,000 for the construction of a Korean war memorial at Anzac Avenue and a $20 million younger veterans package. We have extended the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, started a PTSD national centre at Heidelberg in Melbourne, provided gold cards for winners of the Victoria Cross and combined four treatment cards now into two. That will mean an extra 120,000 or 140,000 new veterans will come into extended eligibility for the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

We have had new initiatives with the Arthritis Foundation of Victoria, research, as I mentioned, into the Anzac Health and Medical Research Foundation, books and videos on dementia and incontinence. And on and on it goes. I do not know what it is we have got to do to convince the honourable member for McPherson that we are introducing new initiatives all the time.

The member for McPherson also raised a concern about the impact of legislation introduced last year, establishing a Repatriation Medical Authority and a Specialist Medical Review Council to improve the consistency of decisions made by the Repatriation Commission. I know that when we introduced this the honourable member for McPherson was quite concerned about it, but I have to say that that concern is not shared by the ex-service community. There is the odd one, but generally they are not concerned. The reason is that it has been working very well. As the member correctly pointed out—and he has a good memory—at the time the legislation was introduced I promised a review of the Repatriation Medical Authority. And I did. Only today it has been discussed with the Ministerial Advisory Council on Veterans' Issues, which is meeting at Parliament House today, the members of which I will be having dinner with shortly.

I have also been consulting with members of key ex-service organisations and with the shadow minister, the honourable member for O'Connor, on the timing of the review. I certainly have not forgotten about it, and I want the member for McPherson to know that I am looking at it. Just recently I was requested by one of the larger ex-service organisations to leave the review until the Repatriation Medical Authority brings in more statements of principle. In the interim, I have requested that officers of my department prepare a progress report on the Repatriation Medical Authority's operation.

The honourable member also mentioned concerns about the possibility of higher than normal rates of certain diseases among Vietnam veterans. My department is looking at morbidity, general health issues and vocational training and rehabilitation for younger veterans. That will commence this year. The department will also use data obtained from the Vietnam veterans' mortality study to shape these initiatives.

I thank the member for bringing up the issue of motor neurone disease. The statement of principles on motor neurone disease is being reviewed by the Specialist Medical Review Council due to some new information becoming available and the outcome will be known in due course.

Before I finalise this and before we proceed, I want to pay particular tribute to Mrs June Stone. She is one of the leading lights in the ex-servicewomen's organisations in this country, particularly those from New South Wales. She has been one of the most dogged lobbyists—a really strong lobbyist—for the extension of eligibility for defence service home loans to full-time members of ex-servicewomen groups who served during World War II without the necessity of having to have served overseas. I want to pay particular tribute to her, to Amy Taylor and to all those who worked to make this such a reality.
I commend the bill to the House and I foreshadow that I will be moving some amendments which I understand have the approval of the opposition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Markets alone can never produce a completely socially acceptable allocation of private income or corporate investment, so there is always a need in the market economy for a strong regulatory framework. In pursuit of an effective competition policy we must never equate effective competition with a laissez faire approach to ownership or regulation. This is particularly the case in the banking industry, but it is also the case in the petroleum industry. I have spoken many times in this House recently about the need to regulate aspects of banking if certain social and economic outcomes are not delivered.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I want to address the issue of the regulatory framework in the petroleum industry. This industry was subject to an Industry Commission report last year that recommended there be complete deregulation of the petroleum industry. As I said to the Australian Service Station Association at the time:

The draft Industry Commission report, in advocating the abolition of maximum wholesale price setting, quotas on the number of service stations operated by major oil companies and deregulation of all oil company franchising is advocating sending the teams on the field without a referee. We will always need a referee in this industry, but to make the game faster and more competitive we should update the regulations and get rid of the rules which are out of date.
There must be change in the industry, but it must be sensible change that gets rid of ineffective regulation but puts in place a regulatory framework for fair and open competition.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is in the oil companies' interests as much as everyone else that a simple regulatory framework exists so that we can rid this industry of the conspiracies, real and imagined, that bedevil public perceptions. However, I do not believe the total deregulation of the industry is in the best interests of industrial investment, the economy, small business or the motoring public. In my view, deregulation in the petroleum industry would give unacceptable market power to a few and, to this extent, deregulation would not be appropriate.

PARA.TAB: The government said at the time of the Industry Commission report that we would not deregulate but would seek negotiation of a new self-regulatory regime. The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) was appointed to see if such a regime could be negotiated. Unfortunately, I know from representations to me from petrol retailers and their families that, while these negotiations were going on, there has been a parallel push by some oil companies to attempt to restructure the market without a lot of thought for the impact of this restructuring on consumers or station operators.

I am told, for example, that Shell is close to removing 19 out of every 20 of its petrol reseller franchises and Mobil is moving in the same direction. Forcing out franchisees from sites to be run by the companies under different arrangements is happening at the same time as negotiations are taking place. All of this is happening when there is an act of parliament on the statute books which is designed to stop such a thing from happening. If it is true, I could not recall a greater effort at thumbing the nose at the parliament and the government than that, because it is pretty breathtaking. But it is more breathtaking to be doing that precisely at the time when negotiations are under way to remove legislation by which such an outcome would be equitable and lawfully secured.

In addition, we continue to have petrol prices fluctuate wildly between different places. The country-city price disparity is huge and consumers, especially rural consumers, seem not to be getting a fair deal. The problem we have with Shell is that they are trying to eliminate many of their franchisees. The Shell National Action Group has had this to say:
We believe that the potential savings which Shell is claiming will flow from—

SPEECH.PARA: its multisite franchise system—

cannot be substantiated. We know that there is a growing body of opinion within Shell which supports this view. The alternative is not to reduce cost, but to increase control and influence over the retailing of petrol and other goods from service stations, with a view to edging up the margins.

PARA.TAB: If other oil companies follow Shell's lead . . . then collusion on price will be easier to achieve. Moreover, if collusion were to occur, its effect would be instantaneous and spread over large areas. The most probable end result would be a substantial lessening of competition on a scale not yet experienced in this industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the major oil companies are trying to achieve total vertical integration of the industry. That is why the package brought down by the minister for small business, Senator Schacht, last Thursday is so important. Small businesses, including service station owner operators, have welcomed the package. It promises the most far-reaching changes to the Trade Practices Act in a generation in this country to protect small business. That is particularly important for many of these operators, particularly the Shell operators.

PARA.TAB: You would have thought that such a package would have received strong support from the business organisations and from the Liberal Party. It has not received that support from either the Liberal Party or significant sections of business. This is what the Pharmacy Guild of Australia has had to say about the approach of the larger business organisations in this country. Mr Greenwood from the Pharmacy Guild said this when talking about the approach of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to indicate that they represent the big end of town ahead of the interests of small business. Surely that's the role of the Business Council of Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the member for Lilley (Mr Swan) came in this evening to talk about exactly the same subject that I have come in here to talk about. I want to go further than just talking about the petrol resellers. I will go right back to looking at how the consumers in regional Australia are being unfairly dealt with as far as the petrol pricing regime of this country is concerned. Consistently this year, consumers have been paying 77c a litre for their fuel in the city of Port Macquarie, in Forster-Tuncurry they have been paying 77c a litre for their fuel and in Taree, on the highway, 75c a litre; but in South Dowling Street in Sydney, every time that I check it, it is 10c a litre cheaper.

PARA.TAB: A number of things were addressed in the Industry Commission report that the member for Lilley identified. Might I say that the IC report was responded to 18 months or thereabouts after it was delivered to the government by the ministers responsible, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) having responded to that report last week. Another irony is that on Thursday of last week Professor Thomas Parry, who was conducting the New South Wales government inquiry into retail petrol prices in rural New South Wales, came down with his report, which identified a few different things.

Fair enough—that is a wait and see attitude. PARA.TAB: I suppose all that Bob Carr found out in New South Wales—they used it as a bit of an election ploy earlier this year; they would check out the disparity between petrol prices in rural New South Wales and the city—was that the responsibility really lies with the federal government and that the federal government has been sitting on the Industry Commission report on the petroleum industry for the last 18 months. At the moment, we are paying 10c a litre more.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the comments of the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) in question time today, I note that the minister did not question the forensic status of the documents I attempted to table in the House on 5 June and 30 August: nor should he have as the three Suriname letters in particular had been subjected to exhaustive forensic and analytical examination for months beforehand. The matter has therefore been dealt with with great deliberation.

PARA.TAB: By 19 June I had provided the Australian Federal Police with copies of two of the Suriname documents. On 25 August I was informed that the AFP could not assess whether the documents were genuine. On 29 August the Minister for Justice did not refer to the documents as forgeries and asked that I hand all documents to the AFP. On 1 September I handed two more documents to the AFP, including the very complex letter dealing with the Marshall Islands affair.

This, therefore, refutes the assertion of the minister at one point that I had not cooperated with the AFP. On 8 September I was advised by Superintendent Brian Hepworth of the AFP that the documents were thought to be not genuine, though he gave no explanation as to why he was of that opinion.

The previous documents had taken two months to investigate. However, the second letters took only seven calendar days, or five working days, although they involved complicated major crime matters including alleged deposits of funds in an overseas bank, provision of passports to drug traffickers, and the Marshall Island's passport scam involving Graham Richardson.

In view of the contradictory findings of the AFP—contradicting themselves, not me, I might add—I sought the forensic opinion of Mr Neil Holland of Scientific Document Services Pty Ltd in Melbourne who is widely recognised as one of Australia's leading forensic experts. Mr Holland's highly detailed three-page report concurred with the original AFP assessment—he could not prove that the documents were genuine or otherwise. Moreover, he noted that there were no identifiable signs of document interference.

Today the Minister for Justice claimed that the contents of the letters are not genuine. However, he provided no evidence whatsoever that the documents are forgeries. The DPP, whom he quotes with misplaced confidence, is not equipped to deal with such issues. Most significantly, the Minister for Justice notes that he has been advised that the contents of each of the letters is false, although he produces no proof whatsoever for this judgment. The Minister for Justice stated today, `Regrettably, in so far as this investigation proceeds, there matters must rest.' Why?

The present AFP findings echo Operation Wallah which cleared former senator Graham Richardson before the AFP investigation had even begun. The many unexamined roles of the present head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Michael Costello, and Melbourne tax haven expert Mr Mark Leibler are the real issues. All else, quite bluntly, is government contrived smoke and mirrors.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under what terms must Medicare refund medical practitioners to whom they owe money.

(2) Is it a fact that medical practitioners have not been refunded within the specified time limit; if so, (a) what sum in total is owed to medical practitioners, (b) what is the average number of days for which debts are overdue, (c) why has the situation arisen, (d) will the creditors receive interest in respect of the period for which the payments are overdue and (e) what will she do to rectify the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Medicare rebates are payable to patients. Where a doctor bulk bills and agrees to accept the rebate as full settlement the patient assigns the benefit to the doctor.
It is assumed that the reference to "refund" relates to the payment of Medicare rebates. It is not usual for doctors to pay the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) and require a refund.
Rebates are payable if the service provided is clinically relevant, carried out on eligible patients and the service is listed in the Medicare Benefits Schedule.
The Health Insurance Act 1973 does not include any prescribed payment times.

(2) As there are no time limits on the payment of rebates specified in legislation I am unable to provide specific answers to the other questions. However, I would advise that claims are processed in order of receipt and the HIC usually meets the average payment time standards adopted for cash management purposes. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Navy: Vietnam War Awards

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that RAN personnel who served in the Vung Tau area during the war in Vietnam faced the same dangers from mines and missile fire as well as other threats as did land forces.
(2) Is it also a fact that RAN personnel are treated differently from other servicemen in relation to qualifying for the various awards presented by Australia; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Navy personnel serving in the Vung Tau area, for example those serving in HMAS Sydney and its escorts, were exposed to potential risk through there being a continual danger when in the vicinity of the Vietnamese coast and particularly during unloading operations off Vung Tau. Also, the RAN clearance diving team in Vietnam, which served as an element of the United States Navy's Harbour Defence Unit at Vung Tau, faced the same dangers as the American divers.

(2) Conditions governing awards made under the Imperial System during World War II established specific criteria for Navy, Army, Air Force and the Merchant Navy. The question of recognition of service in the full range of campaigns constituting the war was discussed in detail by all the Governments of the British Commonwealth, including Australia, at the conclusion of hostilities. These Governments agreed to the qualifying dates and other qualifying criteria for the awards, prior to the awards being approved by King George VI.

Subsequently, campaign awards for service in Korea, Malay Peninsula/Borneo and Vietnam were expressed in conditions which were common to all three services, that is, service afloat, service ashore and service in the air. Entitlements to awards, therefore, were determined by the environment in which members operated rather than the service to which they belonged.

With the introduction of the Australian System of Honours and Awards in 1975, conditions governing the award of the Australian Active Service Medal/Australian Service Medal are common to all three services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to (a) a media statement by Mr Geoff Roberts of Manidis Roberts, consultants for the plan of management being developed for military land at Middle Head, Sydney, that the land had to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars and that it was a huge, magnificent site and (b) reports in the media that all military land on Middle Head, other than national parkland, would be sold to the public probably around the end of 1996.

(2) Has the Government engaged Manidis Roberts; if so, (a) what precise brief did it give them and (b) will the Minister release copies of correspondence between the Government or its officials and Manidis Roberts relating to Middle Head.
(3) What military land on Middle Head will (a) remain under public ownership and (b) the Government sell.
(4) If the Government will sell land on Middle Head (a) what timetable will it follow and (b) has the sale been included in forward estimates of revenue.
(5) Will the Government sell or give land on Middle Head to Mosman Council for sporting and recreational facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a)-(b) Yes. However, decisions regarding the possible disposal of the land, including timings, will be made following the completion of the relevant studies.
(2) Manidis Roberts have been engaged jointly by Mosman Council and the Department of Defence to undertake the Middle Head Management Strategy Study.

(a) The consultant is required to identify the competing demands for the use of the Middle Head area and provide management options and guidelines which recognise the intrinsic qualities of the area and its importance in local, regional and national terms. It should aim to address the management of environmental and planning issues relevant to the area.
(b) No, this material includes matters relating to the commercial operations of Manidis Roberts and its sub-consultants and is commercial-in-confidence.

(3)(a)-(b) HMAS Penguin will remain as a Navy base for at least the medium term. Decisions on the disposition of other land covered by the Middle Head Management Strategy Study will be made following the outcome of the study process. These decisions will be consistent with Defence's undertaking to preserve areas of natural bushland, protect areas of national heritage significance and have no commercial redevelopment of the Army Maritime School site.
(4)(a) See 3(a) above.

(b) Revenue from the sale of Defence non-bushland areas has not been included in the forward estimates. A notional provision has been included in the later years of the forward estimates in anticipation of the acquisition of the national park areas by the New South Wales Government.
(5) Defence has undertaken to discuss the transfer of Middle Head Oval and Georges Heights Oval with Mosman Council. These discussions have not yet commenced.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Government appointed Colliers Jardine to advise it on the future of defence land holdings; if so, (a) what sum is being paid for the service, (b) what brief did the Government give Colliers Jardine and (c) will the Minister release copies of correspondence between the company and the Government and its officials relating to the possible sale of military land on North Head or Middle Head, Sydney.
(2) Will the Government sell land on North Head; if so, what are the details.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Colliers Jardine was appointed on 1 May 1995 following a competitive tender process.
(a) The contract sum is $518,335.
(b) The advertised brief called for:
(i) the preparation of a strategic overview of the Defence property disposal portfolio in Sydney incorporating some 35 sites;
(ii) a determination of the best method(s) of disposal; and
(iii) recommendations as to the most appropriate management arrangements.

(c) No. Defence has retained the services of Colliers Jardine in a commercial capacity to provide advice to the Department on a range of properties. Accordingly, any correspondence between the two parties is commercial-in-confidence.

(2) It is intended to establish a Committee of Management to address the future development and management of North Head over the coming weeks. It is likely the Committee will adopt similar strategies to those adopted for the Middle Head Management Strategy Study established earlier this year. Any decision to dispose of Defence land will be made in the light of the deliberations of that Committee.
